content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												I think many that level bad scores and a list of complaints at Mass Effect 2 have fallen into the trap of looking at games purely as a collection of mechanics. Sure, it's another cover shooter, which taken alone is merely decent. They're right that the RPG elements are simple and at times are obtuse and too black and white. You can, at least partially, break the upgrade system by grinding resource collection. Given all that it would seem there is no reason to even play this game but you'd be wrong. This game, and the whole series, is trying to be more than just mindless entertainment. It's trying to to tell a deep, rich story, trying to get you to really care about it's characters, and it's trying to get you to think beyond the mechanics, beyond the game even. By no means is this just a story with some game attached, but the story and how your decisions effect it and it's characters are a huge part of this game.When you play this game, because to be clear, you should play it, I would urge you to try and actually role play the choices. This game brings up some pretty serious issues in some of it's choices. Issues that should stop and make you think, not just about how this will effect your game but about how you would actually feel about this in your everyday life. You can always go back and play it again and make all the "good" or "bad" choices but at least once you should really put yourself in Cmd. Sheppard's shoes, make the choices you would be comfortable making outside the game. Don't worry about what the game says your moral score is, play it to learn something about yourself.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												I recommend the game--just not as a digital download. The buying options on Steam are misleading (I don't think this is Steam's fault, I believe it is more of an issue with how Bioware chose to package their content); Buying the "Digital Deluxe Edition" DOES NOT include ALL in-game content. NONE of the DLCs are packaged into the "Digital Deluxe Edition." And NONE of the DLC is purchasable on Steam. This is NOT readily apparent unless you carefully read the description on Steam. Furthermore, to access the alleged extras in this DDE version, you must make a Bioware account, find the proper pages, download the alleged extras manually, and install manually before you can play them. I originally played ME 2 on PS3, having bought a disk edition that had all the DLCs included. That is your best bet for this game unfortunately. If you buy the digital download, by the time you have all the content (vanilla game + DLCs) you will be sinking WAY more money into Bioware's money grubbing hands then this 6+ year old game is worth.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												Did you know there’s a game where you can come back from death, blow up prisons, take on three factions of mercenaries, deal with wars between species, survive a Suicide Mission and get in a relationship with the hot alien you want? Nominated as the best game of the generation, winning 150 awards of Game of the Year of 2010 and building so much hype that its sequel couldn’t be more than disappointing, Mass Effect 2 is a game you have to play.      Even if you didn’t play the first one, you won’t be left in the dark, people will tell you what’s the deal and the codex has all the extra details. If you played the first one, then you’ll enjoy the fact that your choices carry over and have some weight on what’s happening.      The combat involves 3rd person camera, using your class specific abilities and guns and giving commands to your squadmates and it has an interface made for PC. There are 6 classes and each of them are varied enough for every playthrough to feel like a fresh experience. Some are more power based, other weapon focused, but all of them do damage and are awesome and you’ll definitely find your type, whether you like to make shockwaves in the enemy lines, hack the robots, pull them in a singularity, cloak yourself and shoot them in the back or simply slow down time to shoot them while they wonder what’s happening with them. There are difficulties that vary from casual from insanity, so whether you play games for their story or want to dominate the dominators, you’ll find what you want. 


Game Over; for them 
A Screenshot of Mass Effect 2
By: F4rseeR




 Many will say the story is great. I say it’s a good one, but that its characters make it to be one of the best. 80% of it you recruit team members and gain their loyalty(only if you want to). They all prove themselves to be interesting and you’ll have enough dialogue options to find out what makes them tick. On your ship, there is going to be the hyperactive mad(ish) scientist, the hot secretary, the crazy all powerful ♥♥♥♥♥, the assassin with regrets, the best friend who took a rocket in his face and is 99% of the time in the middle of some calibrations, a lizard hulk who calles himself “Grunt”, the gun expert that does 663 abs each day,  the cute engineer whose face you’ll never see and some more. You’ll have the options to get involved in their lives. Some of them will argue and you’ll be the one to settle the conflict. Depending on your gender, some of them are available and open to ideas. 


Now I am motivated to go into the Suicide Mission 
A Screenshot of Mass Effect 2
By: F4rseeR




The last mission a.k.a. The Suicide Mission is what makes everything in the game pay off. It’s the place where the catharsis is unleashed. The place where your love for this game will be cemented.  Whatever you’ve done, there will be consequences and by that time, you’ll care.  If you’ll fail hard, you’ll cry hard. But if you’ve upgraded the ship and made the smart choices throughout the game and in the last minutes, you’ll be overjoyed and feel like you’ve won 1 million dollars.  All in all, Mass Effect  2 is a great experience, when you’ll play it you’ll live your second life, one where you’re saving the galaxy you enjoy being into. 


"We are all in the gutter, but some of us are looking at the stars."
 
A Screenshot of Mass Effect 2
By: F4rseeR

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												If you havent played the original Mass Effect, this game is still a must play. You wont be lost as to whats going on, as long as you check out the codex section on the in-game menu. This game is AMAZING and the story line, voice acting, graphics and overall gameplay are all impressive. This game is ahead of its time, dont miss it.From the ominous opening music, until the final decisions through the Omega-4 Relay are made, the perfection builds every step of the way. Sure, there are many cinematic games that play like a novel and are fantastic but Ive never been pulled into a game with a "need to play" like ME2 has done.The diversity of the characters and backstory make you feel as if this universe has been developed for a long, long time, and you are only now being introduced to it. The characters make you care about them with their depth, and this increases moreso as the game goes on. I've never experienced anything like it, and Bioware really set the bar with dialogue and character interaction. The "choices' you are given never feel like lines from a bad movie, like so many games, but are believable and accurate to the story and what you intended to say.The game itself is an exciting RPG/3rd Person Shooter. When you start you can choose from a few classes. Some are excellent at biotic powers and some are just for shooting things the old fashion way. I chose soldier and because of that I had very little biotic powers. I could slow down time but that's about it. The biotic side of the game for me was my crew mates. You level them up along with yourself when you gain squad points. As you add skill points to a skill it becomes stronger until you reach full potential then you have two versions of it to choose from. The gunplay in the beginning of the game was a little boring but it became really fun once you were able to upgrade and get new versions of your weapons. That added a lot of depth to the combat. There are also different types of ammo to use that increases your weapons attributes. Nothing is more satisfying then freezing an enemy an watching them implode.When a game ropes you in, like this one did for me, and creates that yearning to play, the developer has done their job. This game plays like an epic film, but one that creates a universe that I think is on par with any of the great space-epic movies and tv series, and that alone is something. This game is a pivotal point for me in regards to gaming, and it has changed the way I will evaluate and appreciate all games in the future.Simply put, one of the best game I've ever played...

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
"They tell me it's a suicide mission. I intend to prove them wrong.” I still have vivid memories how, on that fateful day in 2010, the delivery truck pulled up at my home with this game deep within. No ordinary truck, this one was holy white, and the gold delivery logo sparkled like a thousand suns, reflected through shards of the purest ice formed with unadulterated water collected at the beginning of the universe. The driver, clad in a robe, coloured in the softest and purest white I have ever laid eyes upon, floated towards me on a cool fog of a hundred fire extinguishers. He smiled benevolently, like a father looking down upon his only child, and handed me a package wrapped in gold, beaten thin to the point where you could see through it. As I touched the package, our eyes met and my soul was filled with an unearthly serenity, never felt before in my short and humble life. Suddenly we were standing in space, surrounded by the debris of countless destroyed ships and asteroids. At the far distance was a gigantic black hole and I knew with every fibre of body, that this was the destination I had to reach to fulfil my mission. The next moment we were back on Earth, and I did not have to sign, because this angelic being could see within my heart, and knew that – as paragon of the good – I was pure. Upon opening the package, an angelic choir started to sing, and reached a crescendo as I placed the DVD into the drive of my PC. Instantly, my antiquated equipment transformed into the latest state of the art technical marvel. The game knew where to go, and installed itself within a blink of an eye into the right folder without any help from me – all the while, the choir sang praises to the almighty digital god. With trepidation, I clicked on the ‘play the game’ button, and was instantly immersed in one of the most impressive action role-playing games I have ever played, with a brilliant atmosphere and memorable companions, all within the framework of a fantastic science fiction setting.Amusing quotes:“It's so much easier to see the world in black and white. Gray? I don't know what to do with gray.”“Have killed many, Shepard. Many methods. Gunfire, knives, drugs, tech attacks, once with farming equipment. But not with medicine!”“What could I possibly be suggesting? I mean, a young woman gets rescued by a dashing commander who lets her join his crew and then goes off to save the galaxy? How could she possibly develop any kind of interest in him?”“Doesn't matter who you are - you got a gun in your face, chances are good you'll do what the other man says. Only two types don't buckle at that point: trained killers and psychopaths. Lot of people can't tell the difference.”Achievements:The game has no Steam achievements. Chronology: Mass Effect 3 (PC)Third-person action role-playing game(Science-Fiction) – 2012Mass Effect 2 (PC)Third-person action role-playing game(Science-Fiction) – 2010Mass Effect (PC)Third-person action role-playing game(Science-Fiction) – 2008

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 is an adventure I will never forget.In my personal opinion, Mass Effect 2 is one of the best sci-fi RPGs ever made, the world Bioware created is unique, diverse and wonderful, not to say everyone is hugging eachother while hopping over rainbows.The game presents you with many moral and ethical choices, an exmaple is a mission which requires you to blow up a mass relay, but doing so will destroy a colony with over 300.000 residents, but if you don't do it the system will get invaded by the Reapers. (Giant robots with lasers, you have to play the game to understand.)You truly get to form your own personality in the game, do you assert and be a badass, or do you show compassion and be a hero? as you advance in either direction you unlock new dialogue options and actions, ranging from giving someone a hug to kicking someone out of a window.Every crew member has a very devloped personallity, and you will feel attached to most of them, you can even develop relationships and they aren't limited by species or gender (Sadly, you can't be gay, only lesbian, this confused me a little).You can do them personal favors to make them loyal to you, increasing your chance of survining the suicide mission at the end of the game, I have seen some of my beloved crewmembers die in my first playthrough, I was actually crying over the death of a fictional character.But Mass Effect is still a game, not a futurustic dating sim, you can choose to skip the romance entirely, and you don't have to recruit certain crew member sif you don't want.The gameplay is solid, sometimes the 'one-button-does-everything' system gets confusing, running, taking cover and interacting with things is all bound to one button, which can lead to confusion sometimes.When you start the game you get to choose a class, some specialize in weapons, others in tech (this means you get to use combat drones, tech to drain shiles and incinerate or freeze enemies from a distance, and others in biotics (space magic, you get to lift people of the ground, or throw them a few feet away or you can spawn tiny black holes), most of these powers are well balanced and satisfying to use, some of them feel a bit silly though. (I'm looking at you, shockwave..)You can explore a lot of different star-systems, you can scan planets for resources and you may just find a secret side-mission, these do feel a bit cheesy sometimes though. (you enter a hidden facility and the merc leader just keeps saying 'you shouldn't have come here, prepare to die').Whenever you investigate a planet you get a little information about it, like the surface temperature, atmospheric pressure, even travel advisory sometimes, and some even have traces of past civillizations who were space-faring long before that fish with legs on earth crawled out of the water to eventually become a monkey.Mass Effect 2's soundtrack is great, the music in the main missions really made me feel like I was in a dire battle to save the galaxy from detruction, the music that plays during the suicide mission is just.. damn, I still get goosebumps from it, it's truly an epic piece.Sadly, Mass Effect does have it's weak-points, as missions can feel a bit repetitive sometimes, hub-worls are smaller than they were in Mass Effect 1 and DLC is obtained in a very annoying way, you have to make a Bioware account and buy Bioware points with real money, these points you can then spend on the DLC, I would prefer to buy DLC directly through steam without using these Bioware points.If you want to play DLC you need to be online when you launch the game, otherwise it simply won't load or show up.There are also a few annoying bugs that never got adressed, sometimes I run into an object and get teleported on-top of it, then I either have to wait until I die or I have to quit to the main menu and then load the save again, sometimes during conversations characters are facing the wrong person or are doing some really weird stuff with their head.Mass Effect 2 is an epic game, and I would reccomend every RPG or Sci-Fi fan to give it a try, there is a whole galaxy full of different races, friends and foes to explore!

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
 BEST. GAME. EVER. EDIT: I never expected for my review to get to the top of the reviews section of ME2 store page, thank you fellow gamers! That's why I'm adding a few more things to it and separating it in sections. English is not my native language so please note that I'll probably have a ton of mistakes here, and I also have a very limited vocabulary. I'm trying my best. Also please note that you'll probably lose more time reading this review than actually playing the game. :)*** **** ****If you played Mass Effect 1, then I'm pretty sure that you'll like this one even better. Also, if you played ME1, you know the story. If you didn't play it, go and play it. NOW. It's a game that everyone should play atleast once in their lives. I could write a review as long as  "War and Peace"  is about who's your character, what are you up to, what kind of weapons do you have and similar, but still I feel like I just couldn't say everything. This is one of the games you can't experience by just simply reading about it on wikipedia or watching walkthrough videos or reading reviews and deciding is it good enough or not - you just need to feel it.  Bugs and gameplay I experienced zero bugs ! , and I can't say that for the first part. Obvious improvements are made. And finally that annoying elevator music, news, conversations and scenes are in the past! And no more exploring planets by that stupid unstable Mako thing. Combat is improved, much easier, you can use cover much easier, and squad power usage is simplified and very easy to use for fast combo kills. Decisions and storyline The importance of your decisions! I think that's what makes this game so good. I imported a ME1 character and loved how decisions I made affected almost everything I did in ME2. There is almost no right or wrong in this game. You should just play and make decisions the way you think you would if it was real life, and see how would that turn out. Also, ME1+ME2 decisions make a HUGE impact to storyline (main and DLC too) in Mass Effect 3. Unfortunately ME3 is not available on Steam.The story of this game is simply breathtaking. This time story doesn't develop that much around Shepard as it develops around his squadmates and crew members. ME2 is more personal, more sentimental than ME1. Relationship between Shepard and his squadmates is deeper and more complex. Also there are more romance options, and they are great!  DLCs Unfortunately by buying Digital Deluxe on Steam you don't get much DLCs. Also only way to purchase the DLCs that are not included in the DD are through Bioware Blog which is super annoying and super expensive. For example, DD cost me 5 euros, and just the  Shadow Broker DLC  costs 8 euros. If you plan on buying them,  Shadow Broker  is pretty much worth the money. Also  Arrival gives  you a new perspective of the story.  Kasumi's Stolen Memory  and  Zaeed's The Prince of Revenge  are okay, if you want a new squadmate with new combat abilities, but can't develop a relationship or romance. Other DLCs offer alternate appereances, weapons and armors but are not very necessary nor important for the story.  Summary You know it's a good game when the game makes you feel that you want it to be real and to be a part of it, no matter the cost. Well, this game made me feel that way. Only thing I don't like about this game is that it ends. This is, by far, one of the best gaming experiences I have ever had. I even dare to say that it actually is the best.P.S. I am not a very good writer, but I am very passionate when it comes to games so if you want a great story, decent shooting/killing, good graphics, want to feel like a hero and save the galaxy once again, then this is the game for you.

number of helpful: 329 of 458 people (72%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												What no one seems to mention is almost none of the DLC is included even after all this time. Not once, and I don't mean like it feels like it, I literally mean not a single damn time has the DLC ever gone on sale, it's still the same exact price it ever was and you have to go through Bioware.com to get it.You have no idea how much that pisses me off.It's one of my favorite games of all time too, it really makes me sad that after all this time Bioware can't just give us a complete version without needing to drop what is now more then the price of entry to get the full story that can be played. So freaking selfish.Remind me to never buy a EA game on sale without doing my homework ever again, let my failing be your lesson, my friends.Since someone was "nice" enough to ask for it, Here is my full review.                                                Mass Effect 2One of my favorite games of all time. I’ve played it from beginning to end, probably somewhere upwards of three to four times at least. I’ve owned it on both PC and PS3 before. In fact I still have some DLC from both versions through Bioware.comThere’s a lot to love here. It was an expansive sequel to Mass Effect that in your choices from the first game show up here, the gameplay was radically improved upon and the game just looks absolutely stunning!                                                        StoryFrom a storytelling point of view this game is absolutely gaming fodder. In the tradition of the best RPGs you go out looking for your merry (well some of them are merry at least) group of followers. It’s got almost a Seven Samurai vibe going on here. You have to hunt down an assassin whom is forever cursed with the ability to relieve any of his memories perfectly forever. A loyal space marine haunted by the fate of what ever happened to his father. The loyal (or is she?) right hand woman to the corporation that has brought you back from brink of death itself. Old friends and some interesting new ones are met as well.                                   It feels like a good bottle of port.                              Very smooth and relaxing to take it all in.Without spoiling anything major story wise, I’ll just say it added to it in all the right ways. Really made the game shine giving you so much more immersion you really end up wanting to play through to find out how your choices unfold and where these characters might end up.                                   Sets a great stage for the last game.                                                   Presentation                                            Well, it sure is pretty.The difference here is akin to comparing Witcher 1 to Witcher 3. It holds up remarkably well with age. It looks like it could come out today on the PC. My only gripe would be it could with a small update give us a wee bit more access to under the hood settings wise but that may be a tad unrealitic of me of Bioware. The game sizzles with amazing on screen effects, sound is really the main winner here though. Voice acting is the bar other games should set for itself. This game is pretty much one of the best voiced games I’ve ever heard to this day, easily in my top five. Witcher 3 and The Walking Dead season 1 edge it out just barely here in my book.                                                     GameplayOooo, it’s really fun this time around. It’s a cover shooter for sure, it has RPG underpinnings. Think small but powerful skill trees that equal up to either amazing combat abilties or skills to be used in game to help turn events or avoid combat all together, almost somewhere between Deus Ex and Call of Duty. It’s a lot of fun. It’s a squad based game so you almost always have a few allies in the thick of it with you which is really fun and makes combat managable but never impossible. I would say if you like action games, with light tactical consideration this a great contender for you.                                                    Lasting appeal.                                         Well it’s obviously a classic.I don’t particular enjoy the 3rd game which this one builds up towards well. So that's not what hesitates me to recommend this edition of Mass Effect 2. That would be like hating on Empire for Return.  That being said I’ve owned it multiple times which is something I don’t do often. It is a blast to play. But once again, my primary hesitation here is the lack of DLC missing from the current editions. The DLC is amazing content but after so many years it’s still just missing from the game they currently sell via steam and also on consoles. They don't label this at all. Which to me is deceiving. It’s their choice to charge full price after all these years for something that actually fills in plot holes story wise. I really want to recommend this game to you but it kills me a little bit inside how much I and many others have already given them money wise that they won’t just give people this content for free or at least at a huge price cut after almost seven years. I want you to have it I just don't want you to spend almost 30 dollars plus the cost of the base game to get it!   I refuse to pay more than I paid for the game itself for all this content. That and some of the content I bought in the past is missing from my Bioware account no less (not all of it but Lair of the Shadow Broker for example). I would go on but my first review is my honest reaction to buying this game only to find out after the return policy ran out that I have to rebuy content for a seven year old game not via steam but throguh an almost ancient website by todays standards and drop almost thirty dollars for story content (and that's not even all the content). Take what you will from this review and just know that I’m just trying to be honest with you about how this whole thing made me feel so that at the very least you might make a more informed decision then I did.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												The Mass Effect Trilogy is, hands down, the greatest video game series of all time right up until the last 15 minutes, and many consider Mass Effect 2 to be the best of the series.This is a crowning achievement of the RPG, sci-fi, and shooter genres that may never be matched.That being said, there are a few downsides to buying this on Steam vice Origin.First, Origin offers the entire trilogy for around $30, which is $5 less than you'll be able to get Mass Effect 1&2 for on Steam, and identical in price to the ME2 DDE offered through Steam.  Steam is unable to offer any such deal because Mass Effect 3 was hosted exclusively through Origin.Additionally, Origin has a much more convenient system for getting a hold of the DLC, especially if you purchase the trilogy as a set (which includes the two DLC packs for the original game, which have compatibility issues if installed any other way).  There are three large packs of story DLC for ME2 - Overlord, Lair of the Shadow Broker, and Arrival, which amount to around 10-15 hours of additional gameplay depending on your difficulty setting.  Additionally there's a bonus mission in which you [SPOILER ALERT] explore the crash site of the original Normandy. [SPOILERS END HERE]  There are two DLC companion characters, both of which appear in the third game if they survive, and several weapon, armor, and companion customization packs.  None of these are required, though at a minimum I recommend buying Lair of the Shadow Broker and Arrival due to the impact they have on setting up ME3.You should absolutely buy this game.  You just have to decide whether or not you want to go with Origin.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												This is truly one of my favorite games of all time, if not the very favorite. I've probably played through it 4 or 5 times on console and just had to do it again on PC. This game is absolutely incredible. You're seriously cheating yourself out of a great game if you pass this one by. The graphics are amazing, even for the continous progress of graphics in newer games. The soundtrack is unbeatable. Jack Wall did a terrific job on this game and everything you hear fits the atmosphere and intesity of whatever given situation you're in nearly perfectly. The story is inspiring and as deep as you care to make it. I don't want to reveal content, it's best to experience on your own and take it is as you go along. Aside from base story, every character has their own personalities, dialouges, and loyalty missions. You really grow connected to your crew and want to get to know them, and ultimately survive with them. I don't really think you find this degree of character connection anywhere else. Bioware really nailed it. If you haven't played the first game, I recommend it, but it isn't at all necessary. Story is filled in early on and you shouldn't feel confused or lost at all. On top of all this, Mass Effect 2 is completely replayable with different courses of action and character builds. My 22 hours were only a single completion run, and there is room for much more entertainment than that from this game.If nothing else, give this game a try. It's a masterpeice that shouldn't be ignored.

												A title modern, innovative and fascinating, that's what Mass Effect 2, which continues the plots woven in the first chapter, shaking the roots to the canons of Western RPG and finding a balance between action and narrative that certainly leave its mark. Dialogues exciting and epic alternate with discussions of banal everyday life and camaraderie, giving rise to what has become a television series fiction serials, animated by characters full of nuances with which BioWare takes the luxury of tackling any kind of issue with a mature language and ironic. For some, perhaps, the turn from action adventure that took the crew of the Normandy will be a hard blow to be collected, but also for them we do not see sufficient reason why Mass Effect 2 is not a title to play completely.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
Short preview: (+) Enough good story. ✅  (+) Long game-time length. ✅  It was 68 hours for me, with all side-quests “assignments”, and DLCs  (+) Customizable dialogue. ✅  (+) Awesome end! If you’ve arranged the ‘No one left behind’ achievement. ✅  (+) Absolutely good voice acting by every single character! Yes, even the supporting characters too. ✅ (+) You can import your old ‘Mass Effect’ character with your old decisions what you made, and they impact to the ‘Mass Effect 2’ story line! ✅ → Steam-Guide here about it! ←   (-) Sometimes, Sheppard’s head pointed to the ground.  ✗  (-) Too complicated to get the DLCs from the Bioware website. ✗ There’s a → Steam-Guide how to do it here! ← (-) The Cerberus server bugged and you have to login almost every time. → Read about it here! ←[gaming.stackexchange.com]  (-) There’s not enough action, shooting. ✗ But, more than in ‘Mass Effect 1’ were.  Crashes / Bugs / Glitches:In 68 hours game-play, I had three rare game crashes. And Sheppard’s head sometimes pointed to the ground while moving forward. It was sadly strange, but it doesn’t prevent you to play.  My personal opinion:First of all, if you haven’t played and completed yet the first past of the ‘Mass Effect’, then I strongly-strongly-strongly suggest you buy it and complete it! You would miss many funny and serious links in between the Mass Effect one and two if you didn’t do it!  The game improved much since the first part, and, of course, came a few new issues, but non of them serious. → Here is my ‘Mass Effect 1’ preview ← if you interested in it. There aren’t repetitive side-quests, and it works well on ‘Windows 7’ and 10 64bit without hacking.  As it was in the first part of ‘Mass Effect’, at close to the end of the game, the story and the action dramatically blows up, and gives you an incredible interest! For me, the end cutscenes were better than a film! Of course, it depends on your decisions, if you want see the same as I did, then google it the ‘No one left behind’ achievement for more information.  Recommendation:I can recommend it to them who;   Liked and completed the first part of ‘Mass Effect’.  Like Sci-fi stories.  Like to talk with non human species.  Like to behave as you are. (Or at least similar what you are.)  Future atmosphere.  Achievement hunting:There’s no Steam achievements, but there’s in-game achievements. So, your Average-Steam-Achievement-Rate won’t increase or decrease with this game. It was a good news for me. ✅

number of helpful: 33 of 35 people (94%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												If you're here reading this, I'm assuming you're one of two people.1) You heard about how amazing this game is and you're wondering if you should buy it. 2) You played the first ME and are wondering if this one is worth buying. For the first group of people, I have a very simple response. GO PLAY ME1! Trust me when I say you will be grateful that you did. First, it's an incredible game and it won't be a waste of your time. But most importantly, it will make this one feel so much more satisfying. Yes, it isn't "necessary" to play the first game. However, since this game follows the storyline of the exact same character from ME1, I believe it is more than worthwhile to experience the beginning adventures of Commander Shepard. The actions you take and the people you meet in the first game WILL import into this one. For that reason alone it is worth playing ME1 before ME2. If you are the second group, let me highlight some of the key differences between the two. This game focuses a lot less on aimless exploring and more on progressing the story. Some of the quests even have timers on them and force you to progress at certain points. Your party members are an integral part of your adventure and in my opinion, have a lot more to share with you and are able to build better relationships with Shepard. The Mako has been replaced with a planet scanner, yes this means there is a lot less world exploration, but there is still plenty of time consuming extra missions to partake in. You can have pets, whom I killed multiple times. Has anyone figured out the key to keeping your space goldfish alive? And, for my personal favorite...there is no inventory. None. Nada. But, I made my armor purple so that's pretty cool I guess. You win some you lose some. Overall this game is a big update on the first. To me, they felt like two very different games that meet at a central focal point. That central point is Shepard, who stays true to who they were in the first game. And isn't that what ME is all about?

												Negative review regarding completely screwed DLC system not the game itself. As of this past month or so EA has magically made this game along with a crap load of the DLC free WHICH I PAID FOR VIA STEAM AND HAVE NEVER, EVER BEEN ABLE TO ACCESS BECAUSE ORIGIN IS SH!T. You get like three different CD keys for one single game because of course that makes sense. You are supposed to take these over to EA's site and register them via origin, except it doesnt work. The keys provided by steam do not work. Furthermore, getting a steam account linked to origin is an even greater pain and then ascertaining whether all the DLC is actually accesible to run via steam at that point is not something the average consumer should have to deal with. There is no excuse for this. The main story of this game is amazing. I just re installed origin and am currently getting  a free copy of the game along with all the DLC and more than I received here FOR MONEY ive never been able to enjoy because of this convoluted system. Attempting to buck steam and force people to use your lousy proprietary games client is not a good strategy. Releasing something you call a "digital deluxe edition" which does not include every last piece of DLC that has or will ever exist for the game and in fact includes less than 20 Percent of the available expansion content is ethically reprehensible. Is EA really not making enough money? Is ripping off the consumer really necessary just to make a profit? I have now paid for this game in two separate locations. Once on Xbox 360 and again on PC. I received a digital deluxe key for my PC copy on steam but have NEVER been able to access the content and you wont be able to either dont fall for this crap Steam ought to ban EA from selling any game on here again ever for this pathetic system. I am writing this review now because after multiple years EA has done jack all to make their DLC systems more consumer friendly and newer EA games suffer from the same convoluted issues. These measures do not prevent piracy but actually encourage it when paying customers are forced to look for pirated content to supplement the part of their game they were cheated out of. Despite Mass Effect 1 and 2 being my favorite modern science fiction fantasy I have refused to buy three and will likely not buy andromeda either because I refuse to give more money to people who seem so hell bent on stealing it. Dont buy this here. In fact dont buy it at all go download origin EA will give it away for free because their broken DLC model makes it more profitable for them to give you over half the game for free then attempt to nickel and dime you for things that shouldve been included on release rather than just selling a complete and well-polished game for a solid price.

content:
Posted: February 1
Pros:Graphics. This game came out 7 years ago, and it still looks good.Fantastic soundtrack.Writing is phenomenal - The overall story is well thought out, and masterfully paced.Crew characters have an amazing depth to them. Writing and voice acting is on point. Crew interaction and potential romances are well executed.Gameplay is solid. They hit an excellent balance between action and drama.Combat. It's a cover based squad shooter, with various character abilities. Character leveling, plenty of weapons and upgrades. It's a great mix of action, tactics, and RPG elements.Hard choices that actually matter.Cons:DLC - You have to visit bioware.com to download and install DLC, and I'm pretty sure the DLC is the same price it was at launch. 7 years ago.

content:
Posted: February 25
												My review on the first Mass Effect game racked up a bit of a following, so I though I might try a review on the second one. And while I'm at it, I will give out my opinion on the third one, too, as it isn't avaliable on Steam and I can't write a proper review on it anywhere else than here. Well, here it goes.Here's a bit of backstory; When I first heard about Mass Effect, it was just after the third game came out, and everyone was pretty irritated about the ending. I thought, "Hey, this game looks pretty cool, despite what seems to be a pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ending." And thats all I did. I thought. It wasn't till late 2016 that I got a beefy PC, and thought now was a good time to play all the games that I wished I could play earlier but couldn't get the chance to. I bought a few games here and there, but then thought about that game that had an amazing cult following and sexy alien lovemaking. So, I got on here and bought the first two games. All I want to do now, is to spread the love of this game to newcomers, to get people involved with the series. One of the biggest mistakes you could ever make in your career of casual game-playing. would be to skip this series, and not enjoy its marvelous story, characters, and atmosphere. The second one, for me, was amazing. The humor continued excellently, the characters grew in the best way possible, and the story branched out, making it an even better Space Opera. The edition of Squad loyalty missions was a huge improvement, making your journey with your characters sincere and meaningful. Characters from the first game made a comeback too, but some came back changed and different. And if you were sensible and played the first one first, and brought over your save so you could continue your journey to its fullest extent, then you have, quite possibly, the best Space-Action, Story-Driven, Romance-Fueled, Humor-Filled tale around.As for Mass Effect 3, its biggest flaw, for me, was not playing it on Steam. I had to go and download Origin, had to once again come up with a password that I will likely forget in a few months, and buy the game on a platform that I don't know how to  use. But it was all worth it. Mass Effect 3 is, in my opinion, really special. It was the end of the trilogy, and the Reapers (You will all be saying that word in Javik's accent soon enough, don't worry) have finally arrived, and Shepard's story comes to a close. Mass Effect 3's story was exciting, it had all the loveable crew back, and ended the series, in my opinion, perfectly. I won't spoil it for all of you that haven't played it yet, but the ending, depending on your actions, can be either bittersweet, or out-right terrible for everyone in the galaxy. But at the end of the day, the ending is tailored to you, and the choices you picked for Shepard. Due to the ending, the music, the conversations, the story, the romance, and DLC (Even though all the DLC costs more that the game itself, and unrightfully so), made this game my favorite in the series.Please, all of you that have not played Mass Effect, please go play it. It went from being a series that I had heard about, but never really took the time to play, to being my favorite series ever. And to all the people that have played them all, go back and play 'em again. It's worth it. Andromeda is around the corner, and it couldn't hurt to go back and refresh your memory. I'll hopefully see you all in Andromeda!Overall Rating: The whole series deserves a 10. Wouldn't want to miss this experience for anything.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												Mass Effect 2 was the first game in the Mass Effect Universe I ever played. Perhaps as a result of this, it is also my favorite in the entire series. Without spoiling anything for anyone who has yet to play the series, I won't talk about 1 or 3, neither will I discuss the plot, other than to say it is epic, amazing, and drew me in the way Millions were drawn in by Harry Potter. With that little disclaimer out of the way, Mass Effect 2 follows the story of Mass Effect 1, including whatever choices you made, as the consequences are felt while playing Mass Effect 2. If you did not import a save from 1, don't be afraid, you will get some of the backstory anyway. The playstyle, reminds me a lot of Knights of the Republic series in some ways, as you can slot weapons with upgrades, have various types of weapons to choose from, and so forth. Leveling up works in much the same way. Visually speaking, I think the graphics are excellent with Mass Effect 2, though I played it on the PS3 and not the PC yet, so I am unfamiliar with any graphical differences. As you progress through the story you acquire new members to your crew who can be chosen to form your team when landing on planets or going on missions. You are able to explore the galaxy using Mass Effect gates, and can go to individual planets within star systems, as well as moons, ship-wrecks and more. There are hundreds of side quests to do, as well as personal quest chains for each companion you acquire. Your ship, the Normandy can also be upgraded with the resources you acquire. These upgrades are not mandatory, but remember, every choice you make impacts the story in the end.In all, I would say Mass Effect 2 is a fantastic game and should be a part of anyone's library who loves First person, story driven, sandbox universe action. I highly, highly recommend playing the series in order from the first Mass Effect, so that you can have a story carried over through the end of the series based on the decisions you make. This will enhance your immersion in the game and is worth the cost of buying all three. I hope you enjoy this game as much as I have.

content:
Posted: March 14
												A worthy sequel of Mass Effect.This game has much more humour in it. Many new, great and diverse characters (and old ones too). I really liked their interesting and rich backstories.More side-quests. All environments are different and more varied compared to the first Mass Effect. There are no inventory or item drops. You just upgrade the core items (sniper, heavy pistol, heavy weapon, shotgun, assault rifle, submachine gun) with the modifications you find in missions or stores. [Enemies only drop ammo]The action is more fun and varied.The main story is not on the same "wow" level as the first Mass Effect tho. Just a few plot twists here and there. But still, it fills many gaps that were left after the first Mass Effect and expands on it.The only thing I didn't like in this game was a simple and annoying bug (It made me press F5 much more often, because I really didn't want to replay the same things if something went wrong). Your controllable character tends to get stuck above objects. You never know when this will happen. I just learned to avoid walking/running near the edges of objects... But still... very annoying. Especially during missions.And a tip:if you want to unlock the framerates and get rid of the harsh/pitch black/dark shadows, paste this in your GamerSettings.ini file. SmoothFramerate=FalseDepthOfField=FalseTEXTUREGROUP_Character_2048=(MinLODSize=64,MaxLODSize=2048,LODBias=0)TEXTUREGROUP_Environment_2048=(MinLODSize=32,MaxLODSize=2048,LODBias=0)MinShadowResolution=128MaxShadowResolution=1024You can find the file here: C:\Users\%username%\Documents\BioWare\Mass Effect 2\BIOGame\Config\GamerSettings.iniEDIT:Just finished Mass Effect 3. What an awesome last game of this trilogy. Really recommend to get it on Origin. You will not be disappointed at all.The very first minutes will make you say: "oh crap, the sh|t just got real!".The animations and gameplay are much more fluid and responsive than in Mass Effect 2. The sound effects and the massiveness of the enemies/surroundings leaves you in awe.The graphics improved too. Weather effects (storms, rain, dust, etc.) are gorgeous. I think this game has the best dialogues between the characters in the series. There are so many good and funny remarks/situations.Didn't experience any game breaking bugs or crashes. Just some tiny glitches, but nothing bad really.I don't know why the ending was so criticized by the media and players.., I really liked it (just don't shoot anything at the very end, just a tip ^^). What an awesome trilogy. One of the best games you can experience to this date.p.s. make sure to edit the same file in ME3 too, if you want to unlock fps and get rid of the dark shadows. Copy and paste these lines in C:\Users\%username%\Documents\BioWare\Mass Effect 3\BIOGame\Config\GamerSettings.ini:bSmoothFrameRate=FALSESmoothFrameRate=FalseDepthOfField=FalseShadowFilterRadius=3.500000MaxShadowResolution=2048"I'm Commander Shepard, and this is the end of this review"

Posted: November 9, 2015
												This game was the most amazing RPG I have ever played! 31 hours full of emotional story, action and exploration. This Game is by far one of the best games here on Steam and everybody should play it!This Game has features of the Tell Tale Games but with actuall consequences. Unlike the tell tale games, choices here do matter. Which gives this game a huge replayability. You can also choose to be either way male or female and the outcome with all the characters will be different. So go back and play it again to see what you can make different this time!The Gameplay itself is very good and responsive. Altough sometimes I got a bug where I got stuck and couldn't go anywhere else. What this bug looks like you can see here ->  Mass Effect 2 Bug  But this hardly happened only 3 times I believe. To fix it simply reload your latest save or restart the mission.The Voice acting was rather impressive and the music as well. I also enjoyed very much that I could devcide what outfit my character is wearing and which color it should have. The Ship and Guns/Armor are upgradeable which makes it alot of fun to farm for rescources.I am personally not a very big fan of space game and doubt that I would off liked that game, but after giving it a chance I just fell in love with it and couldn't stop playing, Everything on it is wonderful and I could not find anything negative at all on it. I can recommend this game to anybody for its full price.

												Mass Effect 2 is the second part of one of the best game series that exists and I've played it twice to see which actions affects which part of the game and I would play it again. After playing ME1 it wasn't an big question for me to play the ME2. The story, the characters and atmosphere were too good in ME1. Mass Effect 2 unfolds the mysths about the Reaper and what happend to the Preatorians.I don't want to spoiler anyone so that's all I am saying about the story.Some parts were better in the first game, for example: The CitadelThey decreased it's areas you are able to explore from game to game. In ME1 you are able to go anywhere.But the developers changed the focus from a explorational to a more action-rich gameplay.The battle controls haven't changed at all. You can give orders to your squad-mates to attack someone, taking cover or using their special abilitys. I do recommend to talk to your whole team for an loyalaty bonus!But be careful sometimes you have to choose one side in an discussion which affects the manner of someone to you. Just like in real life.Overall Mass Effect 2 is an great game with beautiful graphics, an interesing story and characters.Totally recommended!Oh and you better play Mass Effect 3 Extended Cut too. Just to get the whole story.

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 28, 2016
												While I've my fair share of criticisms of the series as a whole and both the 1st and 3rd entries, I count Mass Effect 2 among the best games I've ever played and believe it not hindered at all by the imperfections of its predecessor nor its sequel.Oh hey, I'm going to spoil some stuff by the way so careful reading. You've been warned.It is, with some caveats, a masterpiece in writing, cinematic presentation, character design, middle-entries-in-trilogies, world-building and tight, focused gameplay.For the most part, it's also pretty and varied in its art style and variety of environments, the only rough bits to look at are the splotchy textures on a few things that look like they're from ME1.The soundtrack is incredible and memorable, and I count it as being among the best game soundtracks. Perfectly matches mood and builds suspense.Fair to note at the outset I've got 130 hours logged on this copy and an additional 130 on another copy, so a little over 250 total.Shooting and cover are responsive and enjoyable. While ME2 lacks the cover-rolling and melee maneuvers of ME3, I'd argue that the health systems, enemy types and level designs make for much better shooting and gameplay in the 2nd title than the 3rd.ME3 segments enemy health into blocks or chunks, ME2 displays it all as one bar continually draining, the same applying for your health and shields. Very clear how much progress you're making towards killing a target.More importantly though, most of ME2's engagements can be handled with methodical patience and careful use of cover and squadmates -- it makes even the hardest difficulty a joy to play on all but some of the collector missions.ME3, on the other hand, is filled with missions involving reaper-type enemies that run at you and force you out of cover and involves more luck than it does method or thought. It was only after running through ME3 a couple times I realized just how well-designed ME2's experience is.You'll get more frustration-inducing kind of difficulty out of ME3's experience than you will the kind of careful, well-designed and enjoyable difficulty you'll get out of ME2.Of course, one can also look backwards and respond to the opposite complaint about this game's sheer divorce from ME1's RPG mechanics. If you want to argue ME2 has departed from ME1, you'll hear no argument from me.Given what an awkward, bumbly experience ME1 was though, I don't think it hurts ME2 at all being a responsive, well-designed third-person shooter with RPG elements. I'd rather it was that than ME1 -- a third-person shooter that isn't sure if it wants to be a shooter or an RPG and just ends up doing the shooting, cover and RPG elements wrong.(Hey, I can see those fanboy tears welling up in your eyes! Before you start writing some inane comment telling me just how wrong I am, I recommended ME1 too.)I mentioned caveats, let's cover those. For those who did the majority of the side quests in the first game, you know that Cerberus is an evil human-supremacist group willing to do horrible things to achieve their ends.In a fantastic writing twist, that same group decides to recover Shepard's body after he dies and reconstruct him, bring him back to life, make him into an effective tool both for humanity's interests but also their organization's.In a not so fantastic writing twist, Shepard seems pretty chill about this. The player is given some opportunity early on to object but for the most part Shepard seems pretty okay with cooperating.Given Shepard's history with and knowledge of the group coupled with his loyalty to the Alliance and affinity for not being a terrorist, you might think Shepard might look for more ways out or the game might present the player with such an option. At a minimum, it seems strange that we are basically funnelled into this path with little recourse in an RPG.There are compelling reasons why Shepard might cooperate. They might feel, rightly, that they owe a debt to them for resurrecting him and they might also be tempted by that shiny new Normandy and the support of former allies Cerberus recruits. They also might agree, as the Illusive Man argues, that Cerberus is the only organization that recognizes the reaper threat at the moment, and will help him/her investigate and stop them.That's all fine and dandy, but the player is mostly left to decide whether they accept these reasons in their head, There's not a lot in conversation and dialogue involving Shepard that makes it clear Shepard understands or accepts any of the implicit or explicit reasons for accepting their present situation.However, that all being said, ultimately the choice the writers made to take the narrative in this direction pays off. We're presented with a complacent and careless galactic government that won't acknowledge countless colonies dropping off the map.Cerberus recognizes it though, and has given you the resources and people to investigate. They suspect it's the 'Collectors'. A mysterous race that most have never seen that dwells beyond the equally mysterious Omega 4 relay. Of course, no one has ever returned after going through this particular relay.Once this is all confirmed, the game sets you into a broader framework of building a team, one that is in it to go through the relay and stop the Collectors.The team you build must be perfect, include the best, most committed and skilled operators the galaxy has to offer.The Council has pretty much disavowed you at this point, and, even if you're nice to them, don't really want to see you poking your nose where it doesn't belong in Council space.All of this sets things up perfectly for the game's setting: an adventure through the dark, criminal underworld of the galaxy. It gives the writers opportunity to flesh out new characters, species and places. Stark tonal shift from the first game. It gives them, basically, an opportunity to hugely expand the depth and breadth of Mass Effect's world. And this they definitely do.Missions span hubs like Omega, Illium and the Citadel to war-torn Tuchanka to mercenary-infested Korlus to distant, hazardous Haestrom. Many more. You're introduced to a lot of corruption and dirty, self-interested politics and characters. Mercenary groups. Extortion. Racism. Murder. Not that you participate in these things, but you see them happening.This dirtier, darker galaxy immerses the player quite well and really sucks you into the subplots of the places and people it affects. You'll care about the people and places of this world.Many more varied places and situations to discuss, not enough space here to write about them.In the context of these dark, horrible places, you're introduced to characters new and old and even the old ones are given new stories, as time has passed since you last saw them. You see characters evolve, change attitude and outlook. Great writing.Past the old characters, the new ones are compelling and interesting. Everyone loves Mordin. Okay, not Jacob. He sucks.Each potential team member is given their own mission with a completely unique level design, objectives and context surrounding their recruitment. Missions are varied and replayable.The team that you build though, after all this world-building and character development has occurred over the better part of the game, is meant to undertake a suicide mission in going through the relay.To say BioWare excellently builds up to this climax wouldn't do it justice. Your choices and the amount of time and effort you invest into the team you build play a decisive role in the outcome of the mission and you get a strong sense about how everything has built up to this point.There are few moments in gaming that I can think of that compare to ME2's suicide mission.There's so much more to say about this game and how amazing it is, but Steam recommendations have character limits.

number of helpful: 24 of 34 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												The original Mass Effect isn't very fun. The lore and universe it sets up are amazing, but your inventory fills up so fast that micromanaging it becomes necessary at annoying times, sometimes it feels like you pick up more junk items here than in Diablo, the romance options were pretty lame, the combat was just lame, vehicular segments were the worst (climbing up tall hills/mountains at -just- the right angle to try to get over them, copy/pasted buildings on various planets with very slight differences to their arrangement of furniture and such, side quest overload at the Citadel with almost no side quests anywhere else in the galaxy, and...yeah, it just wasn't very good. I'm glad it happened, though, because it meant Mass Effect 2 happened, and boy did I have a good time with it. Oh, and the ending song on Mass Effect 1 is totally great in my book. <3Mass Effect 2 doesn't do much for the lore, in all honesty. You get a little more info on mercenary groups and an organization called Cerberus, and that's about it. Mass Effect 2 is all about gameplay, and it fixes everything I complained about above. Those things are either gone or made better so that you have a good time. Far more romance options with more interesting characters, all fresh maps, the vehicular stuff in DLC is easy to maneuver around in, side quests are all over the place instead of conglomerating 75% or so of them into one map you pick them up at, the combat lets you use special abilities more often while still balancing it out and making it so much more fun with shields, barriers, and armor on the enemies, and instead of mountains of useless items, you pick up a gun, and it's added to your loadout you can choose from on a mission. That's it. No tiny incremental stat gear like in Mass Effect 1 where you waste your time dealing with paltry differences in gear.Mass Effect 2 is head and shoulders above Mass Effect 1, and it is the best game in the trilogy for me. Mass Effect 3's ending was a travesty, and though it had some solid gameplay, I still enjoy 2's better somehow.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												This game is such a huge improvement over the first game in which especially the vehicle parts were very dull. In this game you play as Commander Shepherd again after being brought back to life after the incidents in the last game, you can also choose to have all the choices you made in M.E.1 be carried over to this game as you start.The most amazing thing about this game is the story, it is very immersing and rich, and I kept just wanting to find out more about what was going on, the same can be said for Mass Effect 1, which was also amazing story-wise. Other than that the combat is quite mediocre, its okay I mean, but not the best ever. Movements etc are kind of clunky. But as I said you will play this game for the story, and you will love it for the story.Pros:+Amazing story+Semi-Open world+Choices which really change things+Multiple Endings+Well written dialogue and very well voiced.Cons:-With a 2016 viewpoint the combat system leaves a lot to be desired-Squad members are kind of useless-Combat just becomes a means of reaching the next bit of story or lore.-Again, combat is repetitive.-Movement is clunkySo I give it; 8/10

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												Oh, Miranda. Oh, dear Miranda...Mass Effect 2. You've had to have heard those words at least once in your gaming life. Whether if it was a Youtube video, or maybe just chatting with a friend. You had to have heard of this legendary title. Well, I'm here to say that Mass Effect 2 is EASILY one of the finest games of last generation.I'll start with the visuals. I have to admit, the visuals in this game are still very impressive, even after nearly four years. If you are a friend of mine, you would probably notice that I frequently take screenshots of in-game stuff, usually something about it's beauty. Now, I've played numerous games that are really stunning, but I haven't taken this many screenshots for a game since Skyrim. I'm HIGHLY impressed with this game's graphics.The gameplay is a very strong point in the game. Mass Effect 1 was more tactical and people didn't like that, along with squadmate abilities, some in-game choices, and more. However, Mass Effect 2's gameplay was much smoother, even if lots of ME1 RPG elements were taken out. The gunfights were heated and awesome. Choosing squadmates and using the abilities they have make the game have a slightly more strategic approach. However, when you could actually have an option to do something else. In one mission, one of my squadmates said that we could sneak past the enemies, but when I attempted to do so, there was no way of actually sneaking past them without triggering the alarm, thus making some missions pretty linear.The story is a step down from the first Mass Effect and even the third Mass Effect. It goes completely off topic. But, there's a reason why I'm praising the game in the "story" section. It's simple. The lore in this game is INCREDIBLE. When you search planets for resources to survive missions, you need to scan the planet and send probes to retrieve your materials. Before you do scan though, there is a decent sized blurb that describes life on the planet and lots of facts about the planet. There's lots more, too. However, you'd just have to buy the game so you can be amazed by that. Also, the CHARACTERS. The best part about this game is the CHARACTERS. Tali is a little clumsy, especially around me. Grunt has an aggresive attitude and lusts for bloodshed. Mordin is crazy, and seems like he cares little for death, and talks in an extremely fast pace. Should I describe anyone else? I didn't think so. Although the plot was rather off-topic and poorly done, I praise this part of the game highly for lore and characters.The audio is just alright. It seems like A. The same music is played over and over again or B. All the songs sound the same. This is probably the weak point to this unforgettable RPG. Even friends of mine agree, the music in this game is just meh. However, I do think the voice actors did a strong, strong performance for their roles. The replayability is actually pretty good. Beat the game? Play as a Renegade, or maybe play as a heroic Paragon. Play as the opposite gender. Side with someone else. "Do it" with another romance option. There's lots to do, and there's even some DLC you can download. You have quite a bit to do. The key problems to this game include the following: Lots of glitches, the space bar seems to be overused, making cover/run/interact/etc a bit clunky. The game is somewhat linear. That's about it!In the end, Mass Effect 2 is one of the best RPGs of last gen, but also one of the best GAMES of last gen. It's amazing, and I highly, highly, highly recommend it. Go "do it" with Miranda, would you?Graphics- 9/10Gameplay- 8.5/10Story- 10/10Audio- 7/10Replayability- 8/10**GANDHI GAMING PERSONAL PICK**.:9.4/10:.+Amazing characters+AWESOME final mission+Lots of lore+Good gameplay+Stunning graphics+High replayability-Relies heavily on space bar, makes controls a bit clunky-Numerous glitches-Somewhat linear

Posted: February 4, 2016
"They tell me it's a suicide mission. I intend to prove them wrong."Chances are that when asked about games you consider to be classics or personal favourites, you have a handful that you fondly remember and can still pick up and play even today. As such, Mass Effect 2 is, by no means, a perfect game nor the "greatest" game. It suffers from issues that have polarised many in the community, from the supposedly awkward combat to the infamous elevator rides. Yet even after nearly 5 years and dozens of playthroughs, (across multiple platforms), it still remains a personal favourite.Though released under the thumb of everyone's favourite publisher, the period around the release of Mass Effect 2 also saw the equally excellent Dragon Age: Origins appear, marking the triumphant return of BioWare and Western RPGs in a whole new way. You are once again placed in the boots of Commander Shepard and are weeding out the remnants of indoctrinated Geth when a new threat, known as the Collectors, reveal themselves, turning the tables on you and your crew in an incredible opening sequence. Abandoned by The Council and now working under the orders of the pro-human extremist group Cerberus, you must once again build yourself up from nothing, gather your crew, prepare yourself and travel through the Omega-4 relay to end The Collectors once and for all."We're all asking you to do the impossible, Shepard. No pressure."A heavily stylised and cinematic experience, BioWare's so-called space opera features some of the best writing around, easily quotable and frequently amusing. Regardless of your opinion of BioWare and the controversies in recent years, it is difficult to deny the depth of characterisation and investment that the studio has brought to the Mass Effect series. From the opening titles all the way to the end credits, Mass Effect 2 has a quality that others still aspire to and fail to achieve. You will grow attached to your crew but in different ways compared to other playthroughs, especially with the romance and loyalty mechanics. The game allows for what can only be described as true role-playing, in a more accessible medium than that of pen-and-paper.From the character customisation to the dialogue wheel to the open-ended Paragon/Renegade morality system, you are free to shape your Shepard however you wish and determine the fates of not only your crew but the galaxy itself. With the addition of the import save file feature, playing through the series carries further weight as for every choice there certainly is a consequence; many of which are severe and often unexpected, especially in the final mission where everything and everyone is on the line. Successfully pulling off the aforementioned Suicide Mission without a single death is truly epic and will stay with you long after the credits roll and Jack Wall's excellent soundtrack finishes. As it is action-oriented, the squad-based gameplay features an impressive range of enemy types and classes, six of which are available to Shepard and complement specific weapon loadouts and cross-class abilities with your team of four per mission. Although the game goes to great lengths to encourage experimentation with a good range of weapons, you'll most likely have a loadout well and truly established for each character within a few hours, with exception to the researched upgrades later in the game. Finite magazines have replaced the overheating component of previous weapons, which significantly affects the style of combat between the two. You'll be taking cover and pausing more often, relying more on biotics than the first especially to get through the various layers of protection. The tactical UI has been cleaned up a bit and there are other significant changes from the first game. For one, there isn't an inventory or loot system. At all. The top-of-the-line weapons are simply found, bought or researched. Weapons are assigned prior to missions and medi-gel is frequently littered throughout levels, now used only to revive teammates. Shepard's N7 is the centrepiece in terms of armour, featuring modular customisation, but other parts and sets can be found or bought. Over all, combat is certainly more streamlined then the chaotic firefights of the first game, but feels more realistic and enjoyable. Shepard no longer feels like a demi-god, instead like the lone soldier fighting tooth-and-nail against all odds that they're meant to be."The Collectors are about to find out what happens when you♥♥♥♥♥♥me off."The galaxy map and vast array of missions will take you from the heights of glorious Illium to unsettling space stations to the seedy underbelly of Afterlife and Omega. In terms of graphics, Mass Effect 2 isn't the best looking game for its time, choosing more of a gritty, contrasted artstyle that BioWare's heavily modified version of Unreal Engine 3 allows for but still looks great all the same.. even when wandering around the Normandy for the umpteenth time. AI is surprisingly quite good, significantly better than a lot of other games, with only the rare kamikaze or doorway block. There were occasional minor framerate drops and in terms of bugs, I encountered some clipping and camera issues but nothing significant or game-breaking. A quick reload usually fixes most of the few that remain. Having played this for hundreds of hours on the PlayStation 3, the experience has been pretty good on both platforms. The only major criticism here is due to the Steam version, rather than the game itself, and the lack of DLC. Already having owned all the available DLC on console, the Digital Deluxe edition contains the "Cerberus Network" DRM, (which, at the time of writing, apparently has been shut down), with the only meaningful addition being Zaeed Massani as an additional companion. The best content, like the Lair of the Shadow Broker, Kasumi and The Arrival, costs more than twice the initial price of the Steam edition, let alone when it's on sale. Besides the fact that this is overseen by Electronic Arts, the fact that DLC costs more for a game that is over half a decade old is unacceptable."Just once I'd like to ask someone for help and hear them say, "Sure. Let's go. Right now. No strings attached."Do I recommend Mass Effect 2 for everyone? No. In fact, I know many people who hate it with a passion, and that's fine. It certainly isn't for everyone. But this is a Steam review, so let's continue in the not-so-objective manner. It is a captivating ride from start to finish with thousands upon thousands of lines expertly delivered by the cast, bringing Shepard's crew and the complexities of the alien worlds and relations to life. The triumph of Mass Effect 2 is that it captures not only the sci-fi epic but the humanity that underpins it. The love and effort that BioWare have put into crafting this is second-to-none as the game constantly drives you into exploring and, above all, determining how you play. For a genre that is so overused, parodied and often mishandled, Mass Effect 2 is a truly epic example of a game done right and the pinnacle of the BioWare RPG. How much enjoyment and investment you get from this ultimately comes down to personal preference, though coming from someone who knew nothing about the series going into their first playthrough, I'd ask that you give it a chance. Even just on sale, it's worth it.Though I'd recommend that you experience the trilogy from start to finish, this also stands proudly amongst the best in its own right. This and Dragon Age: Origins may be a far cry from the days of Baldur's Gate or KOTOR but still remain a personal favourite. Just like old times. Cheers for getting this far, reader, as this review is certainly long enough. I should go.

												So I picked up this game a while ago and it kinda sat in my library for a while because I bought ME 1 around the same time, so I play all the way through ME 1 and get to know all of the characters. Later on I learned that one of the former squad was in love with me since ME 1 and that I had been ignoring them the entire time. Then more towards the end something catastrophic happened and a lot of people that I had now grown closer to died. The ending was extremely satisfying and very emotional based on who died.10/10 would cry from a fictional character death again.

												The whole game convinces emotionally and brings to continue to play. One lives, and feels like in a breathtaking movie. If not, you even feel yourself in the middle of Space. Mass Effect 2 is for me the best part, since I find that this offers the most leisure time and play time. One can land on many Planets with its space ship, and this exploration. You can personalize and customize your Character according to your own wishes. Regardless of appearance, or Armor. Mass Effect is a madness game!I split my opinion into the following categories:-GraphicThe graphics are excellent for an already older game, and it does not consume too much hardware performance. However, Mass Effect looks very good, not more.-SoundThe sound is a part of many that makes the game so class! The sound effects sound realistic. It is not a simple shooting of a laser beam that delivers a gun. There is something more behind it. Everything feels very real. The music and the soundtracks in the game are bombastic. They make the entire game more emotional and genuine. It's like in a movie.-ControlMass Effect 1 Players have to adapt very much, since the control has been completely revised. For example, it is no longer possible to jump to Shift. This is done by pressing the empty button while running. The control is however not bad, or spongy.-AtmosphereThe last and most important category in my report is probably the atmosphere of the game. The whole galaxy is open to you! It is a beautiful image, if you are not on a mission, for example, and simply looking out of the window in your space ship.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2015
												Just go buy this game. It's the best thing created by a human ever. Except for Breaking Bad. Both are amazing...not convinced? Damn. Well, let's review Mass Effect 2 then.A hundred and fifty years in the future, humanity has figured out FTL travel and has found their place in the galaxy among the numerous alien races. A rogue Spectre nearly brings on the end times by summoning giant robots that wipe out all life called the Reapers, barely being stopped by another Spectre (yes, that is you and yes, this took place in the last game), proving humanity's worth. You play as Commander Shepard... until he or she gets spaced. This isn't really spoiling since it happens in the first five minutes. But a group called Cerberus decides to bring Commander Shepard back to life to fight the Collectors, a mysterious race of aliens who have been abducting human colonies. Shepard agrees to work for it, though he or she is a bit hesitant since Cerberus is barely a step above a terrorist organization. The story then follows you recruiting numerous people with various talents for a Suicide Mission against the Collectors, where your decisions there and your team decides whether everyone lives or everyone dies. Good luck, Commander.Gameplay is fantastic. The combat is a lot better than ME1, instead of the overheat system, you get the traditional gun system, and I like this more than the overheat system. There's also now a reason to use powers, even if you have awesome guns, you'll still need to use them on some enemies, compared to ME1 where once you got some good guns, it didn't really matter if you used powers or not. Squadmates are also a lot more useful, the 6 in ME1 (5 in the end... sometimes 4... spoilers?) gets boosted up to 10 (12 if you have the DLC), all of which are very good and have distinct personalities. Plus you can bang some of them, so that's nice.  All hail dat Quarian booty! There is also a good upgrade system, although in order to get the materials to do so, you have to do a kinda boring scanning minigame, which is not that fun to do. There are six classes (Soldier, Adept, Engineer, Sentinel, Vanguard, and Infiltrator), all of which are a lot more distinct than in ME1. I for one prefer Vanguard, but all classes are overall decent from what I hear. There are multiple conversation branches, a Paragon/Renegade morality system that is affected by dialogue and interrupts that you take, and loyalty systems, which once you do a mission for a character, they become loyal, making them more likely to survive the Suicide Mission and gets that squadmate a new loyalty power. Gameplay is fun, that's all that matters.Characters are likeable for the most part. Shepard is customizable, letting you choose his/her looks, gender, and backstory. The squadmates you'll get, Miranda, Jacob, Garrus (returning from ME1), Jack, Grunt, Mordin, Tali (also returning from ME1), Thane, Samara, Legion, Zaeed (if you get the Cerberus Network DLC) and Kasumi (if you get the Stolen Memory DLC.) Your pilot Joker, played by Chris Griffin (Seth Green, but I call him Chris Griffin), is basically comic relief, however he and the banter with the AI is actually pretty funny. You'll encounter your previous ME1 squadmates who won't join you, Liara, Kaidan/Ash, and (if he's alive) Wrex. Wrex and Liara have some good scenes, but Kaidan or Ash... don't. The Illusive Man, who's the head honco of Cerberus and awesomely played by Martin Sheen, is probably one of my favorite villians of all time. All the characters are well written, are well voice played, and I can't really hate these characters. My personal favorites are Garrus and Tali.Criticisms? There are some kinda baffling plot details, Shepard's revival making no sense being my biggest complaint. The scanning minigame I mentioned earlier isn't very fun. There's hacking, which I hear a lot of people hate, I didn't... that much, at least, but I see where people come from when they say it's lame. Also, there aren't very many weapons, which is kind of lame, to be honest.Still, this is an awesome game that everyone should play in their lifetime. 10/10, if you have the money, buy it. Now. Get the other two games in the trilogy as well, ME1 is on Steam as well, but you have to deal with Origin for ME3.
