 Mass Effect 2  This is not a ordinary game, it is a masterpiece. I personally went through all the parts and it is one of the best series for me. Mass Effect 2 is a continuation of Commander Shepard's story. This time our hero is rescued by Cerberus and with the help of the Illusive Man and the team of humans and aliens our aim will be to stop attacks on human colonies in the Terminus System. The game offers a great soundtrack, character, ship and squad development, travels through the Milky Way galaxy, and performs a great story and loyalty missions, side missions and resource gathering and many interesting characters and planets. For me it is not just a game it is a masterpiece that everyone should experience. Production in which for the first time our choices matter. If you have not played yet, you definitely should.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
Definitively RecommendedOne of the most amazing games I've ever played. Mass Effect 2 (And the entire trilogy - in general) gives you an epic space experience. Be the badass Shepard of your dreams and go Renegade. Or be a nice, peaceful Shepard and go Paragon. You can choose many different choices that >will< affect the story later on. And whats epic is - it has dynamic endings, which means your endings are based on what choices you make and what you do (I am serious on this). Cons*Awesome space experience!*Romance - You can even romance a cricket hitman! (Not literally a cricket, but close enough). *Numerous charcter-creation and choices, lots of classes and the ability to give your character *some backstory. *Heart-touching story.*Lots of dialouge and dialogue options. *Rich story.*Paragon/Renegade system. *Dynamic story-line and ending (Your choices affect how the story goes and how it ends).*Slightly more content than Mass Effect 3 (Resource gathering is something Mass Effect 3 doesn't have). Cons *No Mako. Sadly this wonderful vehicle isn't drive-able in Mass Effect 2. *Scary flying horrifying Scythe♥♥♥♥♥♥ *Confusing covers and controls. Ratings!  Aspect Rating   Graphics 8.1/10   Gameplay 7.9/10   SFX 8.9/10   Story 9.2/10 Overall - 9/10

content:
Posted: October 25, 2013
												IF you didn't buy this when it was on sale make sure you do next time, BUT make sure that you buy Mass Effect and play it first. The gameplay in ME2 is much smoother and will make ME feel really dated and clunky in comparison imo. Many people like the more RPG aspects and upgrading of weapons in ME, but I found ME2 to be more streamlined and perfectly fine. The gameplay and combat I defintiely like better. I fell in love with all of my crew and couldn't wait for ME3. I also highly recommend the DLCs for Kasumi, and the Shadow Broker DLCs as they add a decent sized quests for SB, and add a phenomenal member to your crew with Kasumi, not to mention one of the best weapons in the game.Note that if you want to play the Mass Effect series you really should start at ME and go through all 3. The games are tied closely toether with decisions from previous games and to get the full experience you need to actually partake in it from the beginning! From people that you save and will remain with you until the end, to romances you have that can chancge the way crew members feel about you. If done properly things you did in ME will shcarry all the way over to ME3. It truly is an amazing accomplishment I think for this series and as a gamer consider it a must play series. Of course you can find save files around the net that can be placed in the game folders to pretend that you played MAss Effect already with the decisions you wanted, but that's pretty lame isn't it? haha

												ᴡʀɪᴛɪɴɢ ᴛʜɪs ᴀғᴛᴇʀ ᴛʜʀᴇᴇ ᴘʟᴀʏᴛʜʀᴏᴜɢʜs. ғᴇᴡ ɪssᴜᴇs ᴛᴏ sᴛᴀʀᴛ ᴡɪᴛʜ -   > ᴄᴀɴ'ᴛ ᴛᴏᴘ ᴍᴇ1's ᴀᴛᴍᴏsᴘʜᴇʀᴇ> ɴᴏ ᴄʀᴏᴜᴄʜɪɴɢ > ɴᴇᴇᴅs ᴍᴏʀᴇ ʀᴘɢ ᴇʟᴇᴍᴇɴᴛs > ғᴇᴡᴇʀ sᴋɪʟʟ ᴛʀᴇᴇs ᴀᴠᴀɪʟᴀʙʟᴇ ᴛᴏ ᴜᴘɢʀᴀᴅᴇ  > ʀᴇsᴛʀɪᴄᴛᴇᴅ ɢᴀʟᴀxʏ, ʟᴇss ɪɴᴛᴇʀᴇsᴛɪɴɢ ᴡɪᴛʜᴏᴜᴛ ᴘʟᴀɴᴇᴛ ᴇxᴘʟᴏʀᴀᴛɪᴏɴ > ᴘʟᴀɴᴇᴛ sᴄᴀɴɴɪɴɢ ᴍɪɴɪ-ɢᴀᴍᴇ: ᴡʜᴇʀᴇ ʏᴏᴜ sᴛᴏᴄᴋᴘɪʟᴇ  ᴇᴇᴢᴏ ᴀɴᴅ ᴏᴛʜᴇʀ ᴍɪɴᴇʀᴀʟs ᴛᴏ ᴇxᴄʜᴀɴɢᴇ ғᴏʀ ᴄᴏᴍʙᴀᴛ / sʜɪᴘ ᴜᴘɢʀᴀᴅᴇs (ʟᴀᴛᴛᴇʀ ʙᴇɪɴɢ ғᴏʀ ᴠᴀʀɪᴀᴛɪᴏɴ ɪɴ ᴛʜᴇ ᴍᴀɪɴ sᴛᴏʀʏ) ғᴇᴇʟs ʟɪᴋᴇ ᴀɴ ᴜɴɴᴇᴄᴇssᴀʀʏ ᴄʜᴏʀᴇ.  > ᴇxᴘᴇɴsɪᴠᴇ ᴅʟᴄs (ᴀʀʀɪᴠᴀʟ, sʜᴀᴅᴏᴡ ʙʀᴏᴋᴇʀ ᴀɴᴅ ᴏᴠᴇʀʟᴏʀᴅ ʙᴇɪɴɢ ᴛʜᴇ ᴏɴʟʏ ᴏɴᴇs ᴡᴏʀᴛʜ ʙᴜʏɪɴɢ ɪᴍᴏ).  ᴏɴᴛᴏ ᴛʜᴇ ᴘᴏsɪᴛɪᴠᴇ ʙɪᴛs -   > ᴛᴇxᴛᴜʀᴇ ᴘᴏᴘ ɪɴ ᴀɴᴅ ғʀᴀᴍᴇ ʀᴀᴛᴇ ɪssᴜᴇs ʀᴇsᴏʟᴠᴇᴅ > ʙᴇᴛᴛᴇʀ ɢᴀᴍᴇᴘʟᴀʏ ᴀɴᴅ ᴄᴏᴍʙᴀᴛ ᴄᴏᴍᴘᴀʀᴇᴅ ᴛᴏ ᴍᴇ1. ᴄᴏᴠᴇʀ sʏsᴛᴇᴍ ᴠᴀsᴛʟʏ ɪᴍᴘʀᴏᴠᴇᴅ > ʀᴇᴍᴏᴠᴀʟ ᴏғ ᴍᴇ1's ᴄʟᴜᴛᴛᴇʀᴇᴅ ɪɴᴠᴇɴᴛᴏʀʏ sʏsᴛᴇᴍ  > sᴛᴏʀʏ ʜᴀs ɢᴏᴏᴅ ᴘᴀᴄɪɴɢ ᴀɴᴅ ғᴇᴇʟs ɴɪᴄᴇʟʏ ᴡʀɪᴛᴛᴇɴ.> ᴀᴡᴇsᴏᴍᴇ ʟᴏʏᴀʟᴛʏ ᴍɪssɪᴏɴs ᴀɴᴅ ғɪɴᴀʟ ʟᴇᴠᴇʟ.> ɴᴇᴡ sᴘᴇᴄɪᴇs ᴀɴᴅ ᴄʜᴀʀᴀᴄᴛᴇʀs ᴘʀᴏᴠɪᴅᴇ ᴇxᴄɪᴛᴇᴍᴇɴᴛ ᴀs ʏᴏᴜ ʙᴜɪʟᴅ ʏᴏᴜʀ sǫᴜᴀᴅ > ʀᴇᴛᴜʀɴ ᴏғ ᴄᴏᴅᴇx ᴇɴᴛʀɪᴇs ᴀɴᴅ ᴘʟᴀɴᴇᴛ ᴅᴇsᴄʀɪᴘᴛɪᴏɴs ᴍᴀᴋᴇ ғᴏʀ ɪɴᴛᴇʀᴇsᴛɪɴɢ ʀᴇᴀᴅs.  ᴏᴠᴇʀᴀʟʟ, ᴛʜᴇ sᴛʀᴏɴɢ ɢᴀᴍᴇ ɴᴀʀʀᴀᴛɪᴠᴇ, ᴡᴇʟʟ-ᴡʀɪᴛᴛᴇɴ ᴄʜᴀʀᴀᴄᴛᴇʀs ᴀɴᴅ ɪᴍᴍᴇʀsɪᴠᴇ ʟᴏʀᴇ ᴍᴀᴋᴇ ᴛʜɪs ɢᴀᴍᴇ ᴀɴᴅ sᴇʀɪᴇs ᴡᴏʀᴛʜ ᴀᴛ ʟᴇᴀsᴛ ᴏɴᴇ ᴘʟᴀʏᴛʜʀᴏᴜɢʜ.  9/10

												ᴡʀɪᴛɪɴɢ ᴛʜɪs ᴀғᴛᴇʀ ᴛʜʀᴇᴇ ᴘʟᴀʏᴛʜʀᴏᴜɢʜs. ғᴇᴡ ɪssᴜᴇs ᴛᴏ sᴛᴀʀᴛ ᴡɪᴛʜ -   > ᴄᴀɴ'ᴛ ᴛᴏᴘ ᴍᴇ1's ᴀᴛᴍᴏsᴘʜᴇʀᴇ> ɴᴏ ᴄʀᴏᴜᴄʜɪɴɢ > ɴᴇᴇᴅs ᴍᴏʀᴇ ʀᴘɢ ᴇʟᴇᴍᴇɴᴛs > ғᴇᴡᴇʀ sᴋɪʟʟ ᴛʀᴇᴇs ᴀᴠᴀɪʟᴀʙʟᴇ ᴛᴏ ᴜᴘɢʀᴀᴅᴇ  > ʀᴇsᴛʀɪᴄᴛᴇᴅ ɢᴀʟᴀxʏ, ʟᴇss ɪɴᴛᴇʀᴇsᴛɪɴɢ ᴡɪᴛʜᴏᴜᴛ ᴘʟᴀɴᴇᴛ ᴇxᴘʟᴏʀᴀᴛɪᴏɴ > ᴘʟᴀɴᴇᴛ sᴄᴀɴɴɪɴɢ ᴍɪɴɪ-ɢᴀᴍᴇ: ᴡʜᴇʀᴇ ʏᴏᴜ sᴛᴏᴄᴋᴘɪʟᴇ  ᴇᴇᴢᴏ ᴀɴᴅ ᴏᴛʜᴇʀ ᴍɪɴᴇʀᴀʟs ᴛᴏ ᴇxᴄʜᴀɴɢᴇ ғᴏʀ ᴄᴏᴍʙᴀᴛ / sʜɪᴘ ᴜᴘɢʀᴀᴅᴇs (ʟᴀᴛᴛᴇʀ ʙᴇɪɴɢ ғᴏʀ ᴠᴀʀɪᴀᴛɪᴏɴ ɪɴ ᴛʜᴇ ᴍᴀɪɴ sᴛᴏʀʏ) ғᴇᴇʟs ʟɪᴋᴇ ᴀɴ ᴜɴɴᴇᴄᴇssᴀʀʏ ᴄʜᴏʀᴇ.  > ᴇxᴘᴇɴsɪᴠᴇ ᴅʟᴄs (ᴀʀʀɪᴠᴀʟ, sʜᴀᴅᴏᴡ ʙʀᴏᴋᴇʀ ᴀɴᴅ ᴏᴠᴇʀʟᴏʀᴅ ʙᴇɪɴɢ ᴛʜᴇ ᴏɴʟʏ ᴏɴᴇs ᴡᴏʀᴛʜ ʙᴜʏɪɴɢ ɪᴍᴏ).  ᴏɴᴛᴏ ᴛʜᴇ ᴘᴏsɪᴛɪᴠᴇ ʙɪᴛs -   > ᴛᴇxᴛᴜʀᴇ ᴘᴏᴘ ɪɴ ᴀɴᴅ ғʀᴀᴍᴇ ʀᴀᴛᴇ ɪssᴜᴇs ʀᴇsᴏʟᴠᴇᴅ > ʙᴇᴛᴛᴇʀ ɢᴀᴍᴇᴘʟᴀʏ ᴀɴᴅ ᴄᴏᴍʙᴀᴛ ᴄᴏᴍᴘᴀʀᴇᴅ ᴛᴏ ᴍᴇ1. ᴄᴏᴠᴇʀ sʏsᴛᴇᴍ ᴠᴀsᴛʟʏ ɪᴍᴘʀᴏᴠᴇᴅ > ʀᴇᴍᴏᴠᴀʟ ᴏғ ᴍᴇ1's ᴄʟᴜᴛᴛᴇʀᴇᴅ ɪɴᴠᴇɴᴛᴏʀʏ sʏsᴛᴇᴍ  > sᴛᴏʀʏ ʜᴀs ɢᴏᴏᴅ ᴘᴀᴄɪɴɢ ᴀɴᴅ ғᴇᴇʟs ɴɪᴄᴇʟʏ ᴡʀɪᴛᴛᴇɴ.> ᴀᴡᴇsᴏᴍᴇ ʟᴏʏᴀʟᴛʏ ᴍɪssɪᴏɴs ᴀɴᴅ ғɪɴᴀʟ ʟᴇᴠᴇʟ.> ɴᴇᴡ sᴘᴇᴄɪᴇs ᴀɴᴅ ᴄʜᴀʀᴀᴄᴛᴇʀs ᴘʀᴏᴠɪᴅᴇ ᴇxᴄɪᴛᴇᴍᴇɴᴛ ᴀs ʏᴏᴜ ʙᴜɪʟᴅ ʏᴏᴜʀ sǫᴜᴀᴅ > ʀᴇᴛᴜʀɴ ᴏғ ᴄᴏᴅᴇx ᴇɴᴛʀɪᴇs ᴀɴᴅ ᴘʟᴀɴᴇᴛ ᴅᴇsᴄʀɪᴘᴛɪᴏɴs ᴍᴀᴋᴇ ғᴏʀ ɪɴᴛᴇʀᴇsᴛɪɴɢ ʀᴇᴀᴅs.  ᴏᴠᴇʀᴀʟʟ, ᴛʜᴇ sᴛʀᴏɴɢ ɢᴀᴍᴇ ɴᴀʀʀᴀᴛɪᴠᴇ, ᴡᴇʟʟ-ᴡʀɪᴛᴛᴇɴ ᴄʜᴀʀᴀᴄᴛᴇʀs ᴀɴᴅ ɪᴍᴍᴇʀsɪᴠᴇ ʟᴏʀᴇ ᴍᴀᴋᴇ ᴛʜɪs ɢᴀᴍᴇ ᴀɴᴅ sᴇʀɪᴇs ᴡᴏʀᴛʜ ᴀᴛ ʟᴇᴀsᴛ ᴏɴᴇ ᴘʟᴀʏᴛʜʀᴏᴜɢʜ.  9/10

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Mass Effect 2 hat es bei Release im Jahr 2010 auf Anhieb in meine persönlichen Top 10 der Games geschafft, die ich in all den Jahren gespielt habe.Optisch ist das Spiel dank Unreal Engine ganz gut gealtert. In seltenen Fällen stört der für diese Engine gewohnte, übermässige Glanzeffekt, welcher selbst an Stoffen auftritt ( aktuelles Beispiel: Batman Arkham Knight bei Joker's Verbrennungsszene ). Beim Missionsdesign bemüht man sich im Vergleich zum Vorgänger um Abwechslung - insgesamt gelingt das auch, wenn man mal von dem Planetengescanne absieht. Mich persönlich hat es nie gestört.Was dieses Spiel so herausragend macht, ist die grandiose Inszenierung. Die Story ( die gemeinsam mit dem ebenfalls empfehlenswerten Teil 1 ein großes Ganzes bildet, welches im März 2012 seinen krönenden, aber auch kontroversen Abschluß mit Teil 3 fand ), das intuitive Kampfsystem, die eingstreuten Zwischensequenzen, der ohrwurmverdächtige Soundtrack & die liebgewonnenen Charaktere, das alles fügt sich so gut ineinander, dass man unbedingt wissen möchte wie es weitergeht.Beim ersten Durchgang habe ich Mass Effect 2, abgesehen von den Collector´s Edition DLCs, ohne jeglichen Zusatzcontent gespielt, den es mittlerweile gibt & die Story ergibt auch so 100% Sinn. Man verpasst also nichts. An Spieldauer werden einem rund 30 Stunden geboten, wenn man nur strikt der Hauptgeschichte folgt.  Allerdings verpasst man dann vieles von den Quests der Nenebchraktere & wird das große Finale je nach Verbesserungen des Schiffes relativ einsam bestreiten müßen.Aber: Man muß sich, wie auch schon bei Dragon Age: Origins, mit seinem Bioware- bzw. EA-Account einloggen , um die DLCs nutzen zu dürfen. Mass Effect 2 bietet sogar einige kostenfreie DLCs, welche insgesamt unterhaltsam sind & die Story bereichern. Gerade die DLCs, welche einiges an Story mitbringen ( Kasumi, Shadow Broker,)  sollte man gespielt haben.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												Mass Effect 2 is a great game, a fun story that drags you along and engulfs you, but has a few plot holes in the context of the series story. The Shooting and combat were fine tuned and made excellent at the cost of more of the RPG elements of the first game. The tone of the story shifts from the world building and hard sci-fi of an Asamov novel to the more adventurous and fast paced sci-fi of a John Scalzi one. This is not a criticism as I enjoy both, just be aware of the change in tone if comming in from the first title.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												The original Mass Effect was something of an enigma when it came out in 2007. Then an Xbox 360 exclusive, Bioware’s tried and true Knights of the Old Republic character development formula mixed with an action-oriented shooter setup. You could spend time grinding, and yet it still boiled down to aiming a gun and pulling the trigger. You could pump all the points in the world into increasing your health, but forget to take cover and it’d all be for naught. While most hybrid games lean a little bit more in one direction, Mass Effect stood stubbornly on the fence between shooter and RPG.It seems that the complaints – which were at the time, minimal – about Mass Effect‘s indecisive design really got to Bioware. Nearly every issue the community seemed to have with the game has been fixed. The number-crunching RPG elements are gone. The floaty Mako driving segments are gone. The barren side-quest worlds are gone. The indecipherable inventories are gone. The cutting and trimming has left Mass Effect 2 in a rare situation: a genre shift. Granted, at first glance everything seems to be in order; however, when the rubber hits the road and it’s time to play, the game feels very, very different.Mass Effect 2 is no longer an RPG. At least, it’s not an RPG in the sense that the first one was. There is now a simple skill tree system instead of a fully blown stat sheet, and the action now plays out like a third-person tactical shooter. What remains of Mass Effect is the excellent conversation system. The already impressive presentation has also gotten an upgrade, leaving the first Mass Effect behind in a trail of dust. It’s really quite bizarre to see a sequel to a game so well received to change so much.Honestly, though, for as many things Bioware changed, the game still feels solidly planted in the universe Mass Effect presented. Even if the gameplay is different, everything has a sense of familiarity, right down to the synth-infused soundtrack and 1970s aesthetic. Mass Effect 2‘s story picks up two years after the end of the first game. By default, Shepard’s choices left the Council to die, putting humanity in control of the galactic government. Importing a save from Mass Effect is a much-touted feature; however, the timespan between the two games makes the impact of Shepard’s earlier choices fairly minimal. It might be nice to see an old friend or two, though.Instead of continuing the story directly, Mass Effect 2 is the start of a new conflict between Commander Shepard and a new enemy. After being attacked by an unknown vessel in the fringes of space, Shepard is killed while attempting to save his crew. Brought back to life by The Illusive Man, the leader of a human-supremacist organization called Cerberus, Shepard is tasked with unraveling the mystery behind The Collectors – a race of aliens that are showing up in human colonies and stealing away their inhabitants. It makes for a much darker adventure than the first game, taking you to planets around the♥♥♥♥♥end of the Milky Way to construct a team of the best possible warriors to confront this threat.The characters are the game. Building this team isn’t just one quest; it’s the lifeblood of Mass Effect 2. Each one out of the twelve (thirteen, sort of) characters has a lengthy story to tell, and there are dozens of side characters with almost as much detail. The game builds a rich history for each person, making the time spent with them much more interesting than the original six party members from Mass Effect. In action, the game plays like a story-oriented tactical shooter, funneling Shepard and his entourage through conversations and choices before plunging them into firefights and chase sequences. Shepard can take cover behind walls and other objects, popping out to blast a few rounds into enemies before ducking back down. Instead of Mass Effect‘s infinite ammunition, Shepard’s guns take “thermal clips” of energy that effectively work like magazines in any other shooter. Different types of ammo can be loaded into guns, tailored to damage different kinds of enemies. Biotic and Tech powers are now hotkeys that can be pressed to unleash instant attacks on foes, ranging from physics manipulation to active camouflage.Off the battlefield, The Normandy spaceship has received an overhaul, acting as much more of a hub than it did in the original game. The huge cast of characters can be spoken to, and some will offer suggestions for ship upgrades, or reveal personal missions they’d like Shepard to take them on. The Normandy feels more alive than it ever did in Mass Effect, thanks in part to frivolous additions like Shepard’s quarters and bathrooms, as well as background characters that provide endless chatter. It’s the little details that count; even the elevators are gone, replaced with – shocking, I know – loading screens, which take about a third of the time to complete than any lift ride did in the first game.Still, with all of these atmospheric expansions, it’s clear that the actual game has been trimmed quite a bit. Instead of allowing Shepard to hop into the Mako buggy and drive all over random planets, Mass Effect 2 only features a mining minigame, used to find minerals to upgrade various weapons and ship parts. Occasionally, the scanner will yield an anomaly, which translates into a side mission; but for the most part, the planets are there strictly to be combed for resources.While the choices Shepard made in Mass Effect don’t have too much weight, Mass Effect 2‘s own array of decisions are always interesting, and some may lead to intense consequences in Mass Effect 3, if Bioware keeps its word. While the line between Paragon and Renegade is still quite clear, there are many situations where the Paragon sense of charm can be used to do Renegade-ish things, and vice-versa. Shepard can use his charm to convince hostage-takers to drop their weapons in exchange for their lives, only to blast them anyway as soon as they do; likewise, players can threaten prison guards to force them to stop beating a helpless convict. The progression of each conversation feels much more natural in this regard, creating a grey area that Mass Effect often lacked.On the PC, Mass Effect 2 really shines. The interface is slick, allowing players to hotkey their powers; the control scheme is also quite simple by default. It also looks fantastic on PC, and scales fairly well to older computers. At its highest settings on a good gaming rig, the game is a total joy to watch in motion. The gorgeous character models animate perfectly, and the overall direction has taken a step up from its already admirable presence in Mass Effect.Mass Effect 2 is quite clearly the middle game in a trilogy. The actual story takes a backseat to character development, spending 25 hours introducing a motley crew before wrapping everything up with a jaw-dropping final mission and cliffhanger ending. The experience is worth playing through at least twice for the Paragon and Renegade choices; maybe more for those who want to explore every nook and cranny of the game. Mass Effect 2 is a triumph of an action game, blending satisfying shooter levels with dark themes and hours of heated debate.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												The Mass Effect series has been my all-time favorite video game series ever since the first one.Let's start with the obvious, which are the downsides:Mass Effect 2 is unlike the first one, and consequently is less of a BioWare game at heart than it could be, clearly showing the signs of transition between pre- and post-EA acquisition.World exploration has been highly minimized in favor of action sequences, whether centralizing scenes with shootouts or with much more intense scenarios for the vehicle sections.Going from point A to B revolves more around the action of that path, rather than a combination of full control, observation and going in unprepared.The RPG elements are also dumbed-down, in particular with the equipment by making minimal changes between outfits and weapons, leaving only the character-building experience with dialogue sequences.All this being said: the improvements definitely make up for most — if not all — of these downsides.The enriched universe shown in the first game is still present in this title, which still leaves you with the same amount of awe.The dialogues, despite feeling like two robots speaking to each other most of the time, is filled with character, where each line tells you just enough about the world you're playing in, and they're super well delivered thanks to the amazing voice actors like Jennifer Hale (if you played femshep), or Mark Meer (maleshep), or even the other awesome members of the main cast, including and especially Martin Sheen. Sure, the exchange between two parties doesn't feel like two human beings talking, but their amount of detail definitely make up for this fault.The characters themselves are mostly unique; they have many facets to themselves that are progressively presented to you as you develop tighter bonds with them, and generally never feel unnatural.Finally, despite the locations being abruptly cut in portions (sometimes by giving you menus of where to go next), they don't cut too much to prioritize cinematic display, which although is something inherent in video games nowadays and they're specially gorgeous in this one, is something that easily breaks the pacing. Mass Effect tackles this appropriately since most of the cinematics involve player prompts, so there's never a moment where the game forces you to put down your controller (or stretching yourself in your chair) unless you want it to.All of this while you experience an epic story of a Commander that participates in something much more interesting than a mere "saving the Galaxy" (which the 3rd title unfortunately definitely uses as the main theme), by jumping between solar systems.I'm a video games fan, so I'll play mostly anything, even if I end up highly disliking a game; before I judge them critically, I must give all a fair chance by at trying to play it from beginning to end.Mass Effect 2, however, is the only game in my library and past experience that gives me a profound amount of pleasure while playing it.If I was allowed only one part of my memory wiped, I would definitely use that to my memories of this series, so that I could re-experience it "for the first time" all over again.

content:
Posted: April 24
												Once again, Bioware comes out with a successful 2nd installment in the Mass Effect universe. Removing old features, yet replacing them with more convenient and better ones. The story takes you as Commander Shepard once more, you and your crew have managed to defeat Saren and save The Citadel. Your mighty vessel, the Normandy, is under attack by a Collector ship and you must abort, resulting in many crewmen dead, your companions make it out, but not you. You suffocate in your own suit in the void of space, losing contact with your crew. For the next 2 years, you are taken under safety by Cerberus, a pro-human organization with a shady past but good intentions of saving humanity from the Collectors. Cerberus, has plans for you.PROSImproved Combat System - No overheating, just reloadingEnd game continuation - Unlike in Mass Effect 1 where if you beat the main story, it's over (I hate RPG's that do that♥♥♥♥♥♥ this Mass Effect let's you complete quests and do whatever you want after the main story as if it was just normal.Armor Customization - Very immense and diverse armor customization, each piece is important.Companions - Not one companion seemed to lack any character, you could distinguish each one with ease and it felt like Mass Effect 1 all over again. Each character gives you the chance to gain their loyalty via completing a briefly long story related to their past. Which then most will branch into Romances, more down below.More Romance Choices - Where there were only 3 Romance choices in 1, in 2 there are 9 in total.   MaleshepMiranda LawsonTali'Zorah vas Neema/Normandy (My waifu, kek)Jack FemshepJacob TaylorGarrus VakarianThane Krios Fem/MaleshepKelly ChambersSamaraMorinth(Sorry, can't ♥♥♥♥ a krogan yet...dammit lol)Story - Bioware does an amazing job reeling you into the risks of your mission, becoming attached to the cause every step of the way, keeping you interested.Exploration - Bioware takes a step further with MASSIVE exploration, finding planets and mining them for resources in which you can use to upgrade your abilities, armor, and weapons.The feeling of nostalgia - This one is a personal bit, but I think that if you play Mass Effect 1 and finish it, import your character, and experience Mass Effect 2, it really is an emotional trip. I only managed to beat both Mass Effect 1 and 2 in a span of a month, and I still felt so attached to the characters as if I was waiting for the next Mass Effect game in 2007, it's a great experience.CONSEA - EA decided this time to be more interfering of Mass Effect 2 with you having to make an EA account, you really don't need to make one, but you can if you want more DLC I suppose. I did, and it bugged me every time because I'd have to login every time I played. It's a real shame Bioware is getting flogged by EA so much with RPG's, this comes from their newest Mass Effect: Andromeda, which I have no desire in playing anytime soon if not ever. This is honestly more of a complaint towards EA rather than Bioware.NIT-PICKSSquad Commands - Few moments have I experienced very frustrating squad commanding, It's really nothing to worry about, but it is a slight improvement from Mass Effect 1's squad commanding.Renegade/Paragon choices in dialogue - Bioware adds more to the dialogue system with increased emotion and meaning between Paragon and Renegade. Renegade in my opinion is the coolest way to go, but because of my general kindness towards people, I always go Paragon. Best way to approach this system is to just play the game how you would play in a real situation. Get immersive, it's an RPG after all.Controls - The controls for keyboard are a bit strange, but you can easily find a mod such as Intuitive Controls mod to fix it.Graphics - Graphics aren't bad, there good, they can be better with ALOT (A Lot Of Textures) for Mass Effect 2Origin - Origin is a client based PC gaming service distributed by EA and is used to sell and digitally distribute EA's published games, it's an ok service, but it's a shame that they never decided to bring Mass Effect 3 here on Steam. So if your done with Mass Effect 1 and 2 like me and want to play 3, Origin is your only option. I look to add Mass Effect 3 somehow on steam via non steam game and will do screenshots to show more of my adventures.Mass Effect 2 is a great sequel to the legendary first one, definetly recommend it to anyone looking for a great RPG series.

Posted: October 17, 2014
												I wasn't at all a fan of how many of the RPG elements of the first game got axed, and the switch to a more shooter-centric combat system made the already strict freedom of movement feel even more constrained. The story and character development is rather jarring compared to the first as well, but is totally self-redeeming and very much worth it. In the end, this game somehow managed to finish with even more of an addictive quality than the first. The thing that makes the series really great is how important it makes your actions feel. They have weight, you get to see their effects, and the story remains very engaging and powerful.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												I don't even know where to start. At first I thought I'd get a typical space adventure with laser beams and stuff, but what I actually got was beyond all my expectations. First of all the story is great. It keeps gradually developing between the games and keeps the player intrigued at all times. We all have played at least one of those games that keep you wide awake through the whole night, and this truly is one of those. Even after finishing the game there are loads of fascinating lore waiting to be read and trust me, it's worth it.Sadly if you're not interested in talking to people wholeheartedly or just don't care about the dialogue that much, you'll miss most of the game's charm since most of the important stuff happen during conversations. Some things tend to get complicated really fast if you decide to skip even a few important dialogues. And sometimes just listening to random NPCs was enough to keep me entertained, even if it didn't have anything to do with the mission itself. The amount of work that has been put into the dialogue really pays off, and I barely remember times when talking with someone didn't put a smile on my face.Probably the thing that made the game for me were the characters. I found something intriguing in all of them (even if Kelly Chambers deserves death for "you have new messages" when there are none) and I couldn't wait for getting to do their loyalty missions and actually making them my friends rather than just comrades during the war. Only some of them started to grow on me. The more I talked with them the more I started to love them to bits... especially Tali, Garrus and Mordin. I actually started to feel like I wanted to keep them alive and protect them at all costs, and that's when you know they're well made.After playing the first game the controls feel so smooth and not complicated at all, so there's nothing to complain about. During combat the only flaw I found was that at times Shepard seemed to be unable to follow the instructions and just died without jumping over a simple obstacle, but those things happen. Also the AI might seem a bit idiotic, but that probably can be corrected by choosing a higher difficulty setting.And oh god, the replay value. The possibilities are almost endless when it comes to how you want to play. Different classes, gender, decisions, romances... everything can be played differently and affects things in different ways. In most games the only thing you can affect is whether you want to be the good samaritan or not, and that's it. This is the first time I've ever felt that by replaying I might actually achieve something I didn't the last time I played, even if it'd take another 30 hours of my life.The graphics were really good too, even if Bioware still tends to overuse the blur effect. Overall the game is pretty and really pleases the eye. There simply aren't reasons why someone shouldn't at least try the game out - except if you aren't ready for the bumpy ride Mass Effect 1 first wants to offer you. tl;dr Awesome calibrating simulator. 95/100

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												9/10 Overview RPG/Third Person Shooter The Good: + 6 Character builds to choose from: Soldier, Infiltrator, Vanguard, Engineer, Biotic, and Adept. Each one specializes in different abilities, skills, weapons and each class feels distinct. + The combat is excellent as each weapon feels different, the controls are tight and the third person cover and shooting mechanics are solid.  + Both artistically and technically the game is visually appealing especially when you visit outdoor locations. I particularly like how each of the major cities in the game feel distinct from one another. The bright/light colors of Illium contrast the dark red hues on Omega for example. Just by the appearance of certain locations you can easily get an understanding of what the place is about and what to expect.  +Like the first mass effect, the scope of game is equally impressive. Everything this game has to offer, the characters, races, locations, missions, cities, etc is designed to make you feel like you are part of an epic science fiction adventure.+The story is more self contained than the first and third game, it certainly doesn't feel as big in scope to the other entries but that doesn't make it is any less interesting or fun. The story focuses more on individual characters rather than a grand narrative and because the characters are so good it makes the overall game better.  +Bioware's strength is writing detailed, interesting characters and this game is no different. The NPC's that you find and join you are some of the most interesting characters you will find in the entire series. Speaking to them and learning about their lives is interesting and adds an extra layer of believability. +Arguably the single greatest improvement over the first game is the side quests. This time around they are varied, fun , provide interesting back-story to many of the characters and locations and overall make you feel like you are part of a much larger universe. Side quests come in two types. The first is loyalty missions for your crew aboard the Normandy. These missions flesh out more of the characters history and most of the time involve you shooting many enemies. The second type involves you scanning planets to find an anomaly which leads you to the planet's surface to investigate. Most of the time these mission are self contained, however sometimes these types of missions will lead to other side missions. +Soundtrack and special effects. The Average:Probably one of my bigger disappointments with the game is the lack of rpg elements. Rather than improve some of the mechanics of the first game (inventory, UI, exploring planet on vehicle etc.) Bioware simply removed them completely. Even the character classes themselves have been streamlined with each class only have 4-5 skills. The game could be considered a third person shooter with some rpg elements rather than a full blown rpg. Its great that your choices from the first game carry over. It adds a bit of continuity to the story. The problem however, these choices don't really amount to anything other than a few changes in dialogue. In would have been nice if the choices you made had a much bigger impact in the following games. The citadel is suppose to be the major hub of the galaxy where all the trading and races come together, yet the design of the citadel feels small and cheap compared to the first game. The citadel is a few floors consisting of shops The series STILL lacks of controller supportA few crashes  The Bad:- This is more a fault on EA than the game. Under normal circumstances, when you buy a game on Steam with any dlc or bonuses everything gets downloaded at once, at least that is what I thought. Not with this game. In order to get any of the DLC, you first have to create an account with EA, log into the bioware social website, download each individual piece of dlc and then install each one separately....Thanks EA. - The game introduces planet scanning to find resources. These resources are used to upgrade weapon damage, biotic powers, upgrade the Normandy etc. This itself would not be a problem except for the fact that scanning planets is repetitive and boring. You are commander Shepard savior of the galaxy, speaking to different races, saving people, exploring planets, fighting dangerous missions... and all of that comes to a grinding halt when you have to stop and scan planets to upgrade anything. It sounds like something that was good on paper but failed in execution. -I found it odd that the only way to compare weapons is by reading the weapon description. There is no way to compare weapon damage, rate of fire, reload speed, etc.ConclusionThis is a worthy sequel to an already great game. I just wish they didn't have to sacrifice so many RPG elements to make it.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Bioware did some big favours for themselves with this release.The combat has been completely redone which was my biggest complaint about ME1, and while it still isn't as satisfying as a dedicated TPS like say, Resident Evil or Max Payne, its an admirable effort for a hybrid RPG, and most especially from a studio that's usually stuck to D&Desque rules for combat.The graphics, style and presentation have all been kicked up a notch, and the world and scope of the game has been vastly expanded.The story however, is a little underwhelming, and almost insignificant compared to the first game. Where ME1 was concerned with the almost extinction of all sentient life in the galaxy by an ancient evil force, ME2 is about some kind of splinter remnants kidnapping a few hicks on the outskirts of space AND ONLY YOU CAN STOP THEM.More than that though, the structure of the story is a bit too straightforward. The game is about recruiting people in your team, and then going to kill the bad guys. That's basically it.It's a bit unfair to simplify the game as such, as there is some decent writing concerning your ship mates (some of which return from ME1). And the presentation and emotional investment of the final mission in the game really is quite an experience.There's plenty of content to be had, with my blind insanity playthrough being almost 50 hours. However this is including all the side missions, which consists of exploring lots of boring empty space for a blip on a radar, that leads to an underwhelming and somewhat pointless mission (usually just give you some negligable amounts of money and xp)As a sequel, the game is a fantastic continuance of Shephard's journey, but on its own merits as both a TPS and an RPG, it may leave some people wanting.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												TL;DR A worthy sequel to ME1. The grittier feel extends to all areas, including a shift from 'futuristic blue' menus to 'diarrhea yellow' menus. The simplified mechanics are a mixed blessing.Mass Effect 2 is very much the 'gritty second installment' of the Mass Effect series. Think The Empire Strikes Back compared to A New Hope - the whole game takes a darker tone, from the locations you visit, the characters you meet, the urgency of the story and the significance of the choices you make. A warning, though - there is much more language and blood/violence.Due to a surprise attack by an unknown spaceship at the beginning of the game, you are forced to work for the pro-human activists Cerberus. Remember those guys from the first game? They did genetic experiments on aliens and killed a pro-alien human officer who got in their way. Things are a little awkward as you, erstwhile saviour of the galaxy take up arms alongside the space-Nazis.Having defeated the lone Reaper in the first game, the Council believes that the Reaper threat is over, and refuses to acknowledge there are more out there. However, since they are sending their minions to capture human colonies, Cerberus sends you to investigate. In the course of your adventure, you visit all sorts of places, from the poorer areas of the Citadel to the Krogan homeworld, the corrupt but glamourous Asari world of Illium and even the notorial criminal capital of Omega. You recruit a new team, composed of some of your old comrades, but also a whole host of new characters. Some of the new characters are not as developed as the old ones, but on the whole, the calibre of storytelling is consistent.The combat system has been completely revamped, and the controls alone can take a couple of levels to get used to, but overall, they're mostly an improvement, as things are generally simplified. The loot/inventory system has also been changed. Instead of picking up millions of useless weapons, you research new types at your ship, which can then be used by anyone. The weapons are all subtly different, even within a certain type - ie, instead of each successive sniper being marginally more powerful, the first is a standard rifle, the second is a higher capacity one which fires 3 shots at once (useful for groups) and the third is a slow firing but amazingly powerful anti-material rifle.A new feature is research. In a special lab in your ship, you are able to research upgrades for you and your squadmates weapons, armour and abilities. Armour upgrades are different, in that you can switch components like your helmet, shoulder pads, leg armour, etc for ones with different bonuses, rather than the whole suit at once. You can also buy research from shops, unlike the first, where I never used a shop at all!Research takes minerals/rare metals, and this leads us to one of the worst elements of the game. Mining. You take the ship into orbit, and fire probes at a planet until it's depleted. Over. And over. And over again. I preferred the Mako.The game has also been divided up into 'hub' type areas, where no enemies ever appear, and 'mission' areas, where everyone you meet is an enemy. I feel this is a bit of a step backwards. Fortunately the tactical combat part of the game is significantly better, so fighting is much more enjoyable.One of the best bits of the game is the final mission. it, again, follows a general storyline, but depending upon choices you made during the game and during the last mission itself, there are any number of interesting variables. One interesting thing is that you can die and still beat the game...I've not seen that often in video games.

I look forward to Mass Effect 3 that I just picked up...

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												And so i sit here at the end of the Mass effect Trilogy with manly tears in my eyes :'( and a large amounts of joy in my heart :D . What a ride... What a ride.... i'll keep spoilers to a minimum but by the Protheans what a tale. This isn't like Fallout 4 in which all of the character are paper thin. There is real emotion and story behind each character my personal favourites being well, ALL of them! :D . The gameplay gets better and better with each game all complex but concise and easy to understand. The Plot, well let's just say the council should have listened and heeded the warnings ;) . As for Mass Effect 2, i believe that this is the best out of the series. There are minimal faults in this game and possibly the best plot out of the trilogy as well. And don't even get me started about Suicide Mission probably the pinicle of the series. The combat is great in comparison to Mass Effect 1 with a few tweaks and advancements here and there. However the star of the show is the interaction between you, your squadmates and the crew. So much depth to everyone whilst adding a few new characters here and there. Solid 9.5/10. Go do yourself a favour, buy the Trilogy and experience the Mass Effect universe a story like no other.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
Rank: 9/10Recommendation(s): Play Mass Effect 1 to port your gameplay results to change plot, port saves into that legal copy of Mass Effect 3 on Steam, and play with 3D Vision assisted by Helix Mod.Major Theme: Well balanced Sci-Fi RPG designed and built by Bioware with  just enough EA meddling.Bought at Price: $35 (for Mass Effect 1 and Mass Effect 2 Deluxe)Bioware is an interesting studio. They have pushed out some very note worthy titles such as SWKOTOR (Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic) and Dragon Age: Origins. They are both worth a go, but are not for "modern" gamers who like action packed games.If you have played Mass Effect 1, you will find that Bioware had moved on from the classical "RPG" elements such as attributes (Dexterity, Strength, etc.) and inventory (limited slots, customization items take space). You will also discover that you can port your save game data and input the results to affect gameplay in Mass Effect 2.The stripping of core RPG mechanics was done to allow for as many people to enjoy the game as possible. The plot was re-designed to make it more action packed. The 3 plot necessities were focused, being: gore, sex, and humour. This unfortunately causes a problem for some; there's more on this later.


I think this planned... Somehow... 
A Screenshot of Mass Effect 2
By: DarK_St3alth




The result was a much more interesting, action packed title which should allow anyone to play it.You should however, take into account that Unreal 3 is more of a console porting engine. You can see this with the lower quality textures, limits on the detail of scenes, field of view (FOV), hidden frame rate smoothing, and loading in between decks of the Normandy.


Mass Effect 2 
A Screenshot of Mass Effect 2
By: DarK_St3alth




When I think of consoles, one of the first things I think of is DLCs. While I describe them to be the evil of all evils to some, there are some ok "patches" such as the Shadow Broker, which adds to the story, save porting abilities, and even highlights the back story that I wasn't aware of from the comics. Another issue with porting is that meaningful keyboard shortcuts and keys are not used. This is where the concept of "spacebar does everything" comes in. While most games use the "e" key for interactions (failing that, the "f" key), Mass Effect 2 uses the spacebar. This is quite the switch from the original Mass Effect.Comparing to another successful title such as Dragon Age: Origins, you can see how the game has improved and worsened.Improvements range from not being so dry thanks to humour, to less about fine tuning character attributes and more enjoying the story.The list of things that you can say have become worse include: "The getting laid simulator" romance mechanic, the plot is too simple, and that the game is generally "dumbed down".Side Note: It should be up to you to evaluate what is important to you, but I will make as side note here to say that the game has replay ability. You can even replay Mass Effect to change how the story unfolds in ME2 and ME3.Another point that should be made apparent is that the 80% process is used.Due to the 80% process, cut scenes don't use weapons assigned by you. While not a “game breaking” issue, just could have been worth the weight (thanks gabe for the comment). In this process, studios finish things to 80% and move on, hoping to come back and finish them later. Sadly, most of the time this means picking the more meaningful features before shipment.Stereoscopic 3D done via Nvidia's 3D vision and improved via Helix Mod, really make this title a treat and greatly improve immersion.To end this off I will say this. The beauty of Mass Effect 2 (as with the others) is that you can play a different style or character the next playthough. Go with male Shepard once, then with the Female another. Things change, and thus I have played 4 times all the way though. Yes, you will feel like doing that one day. Maybe Romance Tali in one, Garrus the 2nd, or Miranda in the 3rd.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												The essential link between Mass Effect and Mass Effect 3. Mass Effect 2 is less focused on the general story background, but puts building a team and relationships into the focus of its story line. Apart from the introduction of the "Collectors", there's isn't much added to what has been learned about the reapers in Mass Effect 1.Mass Effect 2 is best enjoyed with an imported save game, giving away bits and pieces about what happened to all the colorful persons the payer met in the first game. Combat has been drastically simplified, giving way less emphasize on building the character and outfitting them with gear. With speed of the encounters picking up, the tactical impact of squad utilization has been dropped seomwhat in favor of putting the player's reaction time more into focus. It's not necessarily a bad thing, but won't appeal to those who wish for a less hectic approach to combat.While enjoying ME 2 greatly at the first time, I personally didn't find the second playthrough of ME 2 as rewarding as it felt for ME 1, because of the rather thin story development. While building relationships with the NPCs feels rewarding, it comes somewhat short in terms of depths. Less squad mates with more character development would have been preferable.Bottom line: Essential to (re)live the trilogy, but feels slightly like a stretch for those who already know about the dramatic developments of ME 3.PS: Don't miss updating the game with a HD texture modification! Due to technical limitations the developers did include low res textures only! The screenshots I have taken showcase HD textures for all squadmates. IMPORTANT:  Despite being published by EA, Mass Effect 2 DOES NOT require Origin to play. BUT: You are able to register your Steam copy of ME 2 at Origin as well, which enables you to download the DLC you're already eligible for by purchasing the special edition of the game.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 is just a great game, with very few draw-backs. If you haven't played the first Mass Effect game, go play it! If it weren't for the b*llsh*t DLC situation, Mass Effect 2 would easily be worth the standard retail price.You can view the opening of the game here.Presumed dead by the Alliance, Shepard is given backing by the human-first extremist group Cerberus to investigate a strange phenomenon: whole Alliance colonies are simply disappearing. Investigating the disappearing colonies and a strange new enemy are the primary missions of the game that stretch from beginning to end; it's the core narrative that makes the game work. Within that framework, you as Shepard put together a combat team of the galaxy's most elite operatives - literally a sort of intergalactic "Dirty Dozen." Each team-member has a recruitment mission (required if you want them in your squad) and loyalty mission (not required, but ignore at your own risk!) The final mission is a masterpiece of programming and pacing. You'll want as many squad-mates as possible. Who is loyal and who isn't is a crucial factor in determining who lives or dies. Choosing the wrong squad-mates for support duty as Shepard and 2 others fight the (very creepy) final boss can result in more deaths. Decision making and laying the groundwork (ie loyalty) are crucial. Choices made throughout the game were never more consequential.The graphics still look great for a 2010 game. The music soundtrack is superb. There are some new minigames, like hacking wall safes and datapads. Both are fairly easy and don't slow down game-play that much. Scanning planets for resources, quickly devolves into a chore; you have to do it, though, to research improvements for your ship, guns, and armor. Planetary exploration from the first game is gone, which was disappointing to me. There are a LOT of side-missions, which are great if you just want to tool around the galaxy looking for stuff to do. And, yes, squad-mate romance is back. An added bonus are some fantastic actors to voice important characters, including Martin Sheen as The Illusive Man (yes, THAT Martin Sheen!), Yvonne Strahovski as Cerberus officer Miranda Lawson (from the TV show Chuck), and Carrie-Ann Moss as Omega gangster / ruler Aria T'Loak (Trinity from The Matrix). While the first Mass Effect was a great RPG, Mass Effect 2 focuses more on story and action at the expense of customization. It's like watching a favorite movie play out, except you are IN the movie, making the choices. A great story-based and combat-based RPG / FPS hybrid with high replayability. One of my all time favorites! Because of the DLC situation, though, only purchase the game when on sale at 75% off.A note about DLC:The DLC situation is, frankly, b*llsh*t. Once the game is fully assembled it is truly superb; but save your money and get the game on sale, because to acquire ALL the DLC will cost around $40 at this point.The Digital Deluxe Edition includes the Cerberus Network Add-on. The Cerberus Network provides access to the following DLC: Zaeed - The Price of RevengeFirewalker PackNormandy Crash SiteCerberus Arc ProjectorCerberus Weapons and ArmorThe Cerberus Network requires that you to create a profile on Bioware's Social website. Once your purchase of the Mass Effect 2 Digital Deluxe Edition is verified, you will be provided links to download .exe files (hosted on EA's severs) that will install the DLC. These will work on a Steam installation, and do NOT require the installation EA's Origin software. Purchasing additional DLC (which can be done on the Bioware Social website) follows the same pattern.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2013
												Have you ever wanted to be the captain of a space ship but Star Trek is too nerdy for you? Well now you are in EA Presents Bio BeWare Mass Effect 2: Axe Effect. Take on the role of commander Shepard and be you in space. Or be Shepard in space. It’s whatever. Best friend of waist high walls, you shoot your OWN path through predestined story missions. Talk to some bros and listen to banter in space in this Sci Fi mans shooter. In space, all of the shooters are mans. There are aliens that don’t look like mans but they don’t shoot thank goodness. I really get to feel like it’s cold blood murder in space and the action is visceral even when poor humanoid robots shoot me. To be fair there are also space spiders and space dogs so geeze I guess it’s not a total copy and paste skeleton job!The gameplay is cover man shooting but it is also talking to people in towns and making numbers get bigger. You will be playing an RPG sometimes, but then you are working for the establishment  and gunning down mens next thing you know. What genre of game are you even playing? We’ve all played a game before so the rest of this review is not about gameplay.The star of the show is codex talk man. At any time you can pause to stop playing the ♥♥♥♥ing game and go through menus to listen to a smooth talking gentleman chat about the game. You may be familiar with codex from Drag on Age or Final Fantasy XIII 1-3. but this time the codex is the highlight of the game as you sit back and get read the game to you. Over the course of the game you will get more bros for your ship and redder guns but the new codex entries are what pull the player along. For all you creepers out there you can have a romantic relationship with all sorts of space dudes and ladies. But not dude on dude because that is gay. In this Mass Effect no one is gay in space. Except women sometimes. But that’s not gay in space.Resource farming minigame? Lockpick minigame? We got it all here folks! Why don’t you slide up behind a turret or bap some heads off? But before you say seen this and peace out you get psychic abilities. If you are Vanguard (only be Vanguard folks) you can flip guys up to slow motion gravity and be goku instant transmission across the battlefield in space. You get some slaughterpals like Space Mad-Scientist Frog and Bald Girl Wanna Kill Things just to name a couple murderbuddies.Mass Effect 2 has a revolutionary choice-O-meter. You are red or you are blue and you cut yourself off from future opportunity just like in the real world. You can scratch the code off of your Doritos (™) Shepard’s Favorite Chips On The Citadel (™) chips to get more empathy points to spend on your dating harem if you choose to play the game like a weird alcoholic space pimp and not a serious professional going about saving the galaxy. Paragorn Mountain Dew for blue bloods.So strap on your watch which is a computer asap at your your local Valve Steam store. You are the telekinetik undead military captain rockstar and everyone loves you when you pull the trigger in space. Big Man OR Big Woman power fantasy in the hot game on a spaceship in space: Mass Effect 2: The Mass Effects.Has:- The Choice. The Impact- 18 DLCs. The future of Gaming is here.- Vehicle Sections! Gamer’s favorite- Dating Element. It’s not LovePlus so it’s okay.- Online Multiplayer. Shoot your bros.!Lacks: Well there you have it folks! The perfect game!11 / 10 No questions asked.-- IGN.comFive… Out of Five. “Played a Video Game” --Xplay Morgan Web97/100 “Numbers get bigger. Tentacle head girl. Western Tho.” -- Famitsu10/10 “I luv 2 laugh. Fun Video Game.” -- O prah Magazine10/10 “Beautiful. Stunning. A living dream of diamonds on ebony.” -- National GeographicIf you like this review leave a comment below and you could win a FREE GAME.Tell your friend and don’t forget to unsubscribe.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2012
												I have a hard time speaking in a balanced manner about Mass Effect 2 because it's one of my single favorite video games of all-time. There are so many good things to gush over, but the bad pieces are really, truly bad and do a lot to ruin the experience of actually playing the game. The most concise way I can describe it is 'flawed masterpiece'. It's a game propped up by fantastic art and sound design and far better overall writing than the much maligned Mass Effect 3, but at the same time, the gameplay is nowhere near as tight and the overall design is way rougher -- To the point where I'd criticize the combat as being unfinished.To start, the graphics and the engine run pretty smoothly on the PC. It runs easily enough -- I see around 110-120 FPS on my 120hz 1440p monitor, but the textures are often muddy and low-res, a curse of the title being designed with far outdated consoles in mind... Even back in 2010. I had a similar experience with the first Mass Effect, though that game is even rougher-looking than this one is. The textures here are, on average, higher res. It helps that the lighting is far better designed than the first game (goodbye, ham-fisted lens flare!). There are a great many visual bugs, though. Far more than the console version. Glitches with the eyes, characters model inexplicably spinning, etc. But it's saved mostly by the beautiful art design. The use of colored lighting really adds a great touch, and the environments are unbelievably vibrant. There's a lot to 'feel' here just by looking at skyboxes. It's indicative of good art design and adequate design on the technical side to support it. The art team is the MVP here.The sound! Where to start? Jack Wall is absolutely fantastic, almost up to the level he was in the first game. He's at his best when he's laying down eerie music for the tense missions (Collector Ship, anybody?), but he does a great job with handling the huge change in tone from the first game. Mass Effect 1 was carried by a super-techno, futuristic style soundtrack, whereas this one has touches of futurism but mostly just feels brooding and dirty. It fits the art direction of the game perfectly, and even a minimalist track like the droning that plays during the loading screen really does a fantastic job to impart and augment the overall 'feel' of this game, which is a big part of what I find so enticing about Mass Effect 2.The writing is probably the games single strongest aspect. I don't mean to exaggerate, or to gush too much here, but there are some of the most well-written characters in any video game I've ever played. It's clear that Walters, Karpyshyn, and the rest of the writing staff were going for a Dirty Dozen, Wild West type feel with the characters and settings here, and they've succeeded in spades. There are a lot of characters that might even fit into a cliche, but the dialogue is so well-written and the voice acting is so superb that the game manages to skip that pothole and cruise along. Thane Krios, the spiritual, regretful assassin, is a stand-out among a cast of solid personalities. His discussions with Shepard and his dealings with his son Kolyat are excellent. Garrus is far more fleshed out here than he was in the first game (in which I found his character to be disappointingly underdeveloped), and the writing here creates a bridge to his being so likable in the third game. Legion, a character who arrives unfortunately late in the game, is another stellar twist and an amazingly well-written and impresses in unexpected ways. It's hard to go into detail without spoiling anything, but suffice it to say that his obsessive 'complex' is wholly unexpected and goes on to completely destroy any expectation I had when I initially learned of the characters presence in the game.There are some pitfalls here, unfortunately, mostly in the form of Jacob Taylor. He always came off as completely unlikable to me, though that's more a personal feeling and not a general criticism. I think he's a poor character simply because there's not really much there to dig into. He's got some father issues to deal with that feel crammed in mid-game and seem to hover around the outside of his character rather than fleshing out his core, like so many of the other characters side missions are intended to do.Now that I've gushed over the good things, let's talk about some of the bad.The game plays as if its half finished, particularly during combat. There's a nice idea and an adequate core design here, but it seems like it could have used far longer in the QA process than it actually had. The core mechanics of taking down the enemies shields/barriers, armor, and then health are really excellent. Each is weak to a different type of weapon, ammo, and power, so each encounter becomes a sort of puzzle where you're evaluating which enemy is the most threatening and thus must be dealt with first, and by using which power or weapon to do so. It's incredibly complex but relatively simple to learn, and getting through some of the more difficult encounters on hardcore or insanity difficulty is amazingly satisfying.Sounds great, right? Unfortunately, while the game is at its best on the two hardest difficulty modes, it also suffers the most on those modes due to extremely buggy cover mechanics and unbelievably poor friendly AI. The AI is absolutely abysmal, and if you want that Insanity trophy you better be ready for some frustration. It's necessary to completely micomanage your allies by controlling where they're taking cover at all times. The problem with cover also manifests itself here, as there are many times when allies simply refuse to listen to you and wade out into enemy fire only to die immediately. It's so frustratingly idiotic that I find myself wondering how the game ever shipped in this fashion. It's a mess, and having to babysit your idiotic, suicidal squadmates really destroys what would have been an otherwise fantastic gameplay system. The general design is there, but the technical execution is utterly terrible and enough to make you bash your head against a wall. It's much more passable on Normal and Casual, but if you're gunning for Hardcore or Insanity, get ready for a headache.The overall design of the game, despite these poorer aspects, is excellent. The episodic style of gameplay in which you're recruiting allies just feels right, and the game feels far more organized and direct than the first game ever did. On the harder difficulties you really get a sense of it being a race against time. You've got to plan out what missions you're doing at what time, because upgrades are incredibly important and if you find yourself trying to take on Horizon or the Collector Ship without the good ones, you can actually get completely stuck and be forced to start over. While this sounds frustrating, it actually does a good job to suck you into the situation that Shepard and the crew find themselves in. They've got to get all of this done, and quickly, because the Collectors are on the move and they aren't waiting for you. This episodic style is paced perfectly, and you never seem to experience any of the drag that you see in the first game when you get dropped onto the Citadel after Eden Prime only to find yourself immediately bogged down with a huge area to explore and dozens of sidequests to tackle. It does a far better job with making sure you never feel overwhelmed than the first game. It's open-ended enough without stranding you in a sea of objectives -- You've always got a handful of options of what to do next, and it's up to you to decide which seems to be most important.All of the gameplay here comes to a head in a fantastic final act that sees everything you've done so far in the game build up to one massive conclusion. The suicide mission is truly excellent, and caps off a must-play game for everyone interested in RPGs.Insanity gameplay video: 


YouTube™ Video: Mass Effect 2 Insanity, Episode 5: The Price of Revenge

content:
Posted: July 21, 2012
												I have a hard time speaking in a balanced manner about Mass Effect 2 because it's one of my single favorite video games of all-time. There are so many good things to gush over, but the bad pieces are really, truly bad and do a lot to ruin the experience of actually playing the game. The most concise way I can describe it is 'flawed masterpiece'. It's a game propped up by fantastic art and sound design and far better overall writing than the much maligned Mass Effect 3, but at the same time, the gameplay is nowhere near as tight and the overall design is way rougher -- To the point where I'd criticize the combat as being unfinished.To start, the graphics and the engine run pretty smoothly on the PC. It runs easily enough -- I see around 110-120 FPS on my 120hz 1440p monitor, but the textures are often muddy and low-res, a curse of the title being designed with far outdated consoles in mind... Even back in 2010. I had a similar experience with the first Mass Effect, though that game is even rougher-looking than this one is. The textures here are, on average, higher res. It helps that the lighting is far better designed than the first game (goodbye, ham-fisted lens flare!). There are a great many visual bugs, though. Far more than the console version. Glitches with the eyes, characters model inexplicably spinning, etc. But it's saved mostly by the beautiful art design. The use of colored lighting really adds a great touch, and the environments are unbelievably vibrant. There's a lot to 'feel' here just by looking at skyboxes. It's indicative of good art design and adequate design on the technical side to support it. The art team is the MVP here.The sound! Where to start? Jack Wall is absolutely fantastic, almost up to the level he was in the first game. He's at his best when he's laying down eerie music for the tense missions (Collector Ship, anybody?), but he does a great job with handling the huge change in tone from the first game. Mass Effect 1 was carried by a super-techno, futuristic style soundtrack, whereas this one has touches of futurism but mostly just feels brooding and dirty. It fits the art direction of the game perfectly, and even a minimalist track like the droning that plays during the loading screen really does a fantastic job to impart and augment the overall 'feel' of this game, which is a big part of what I find so enticing about Mass Effect 2.The writing is probably the games single strongest aspect. I don't mean to exaggerate, or to gush too much here, but there are some of the most well-written characters in any video game I've ever played. It's clear that Walters, Karpyshyn, and the rest of the writing staff were going for a Dirty Dozen, Wild West type feel with the characters and settings here, and they've succeeded in spades. There are a lot of characters that might even fit into a cliche, but the dialogue is so well-written and the voice acting is so superb that the game manages to skip that pothole and cruise along. Thane Krios, the spiritual, regretful assassin, is a stand-out among a cast of solid personalities. His discussions with Shepard and his dealings with his son Kolyat are excellent. Garrus is far more fleshed out here than he was in the first game (in which I found his character to be disappointingly underdeveloped), and the writing here creates a bridge to his being so likable in the third game. Legion, a character who arrives unfortunately late in the game, is another stellar twist and an amazingly well-written and impresses in unexpected ways. It's hard to go into detail without spoiling anything, but suffice it to say that his obsessive 'complex' is wholly unexpected and goes on to completely destroy any expectation I had when I initially learned of the characters presence in the game.There are some pitfalls here, unfortunately, mostly in the form of Jacob Taylor. He always came off as completely unlikable to me, though that's more a personal feeling and not a general criticism. I think he's a poor character simply because there's not really much there to dig into. He's got some father issues to deal with that feel crammed in mid-game and seem to hover around the outside of his character rather than fleshing out his core, like so many of the other characters side missions are intended to do.Now that I've gushed over the good things, let's talk about some of the bad.The game plays as if its half finished, particularly during combat. There's a nice idea and an adequate core design here, but it seems like it could have used far longer in the QA process than it actually had. The core mechanics of taking down the enemies shields/barriers, armor, and then health are really excellent. Each is weak to a different type of weapon, ammo, and power, so each encounter becomes a sort of puzzle where you're evaluating which enemy is the most threatening and thus must be dealt with first, and by using which power or weapon to do so. It's incredibly complex but relatively simple to learn, and getting through some of the more difficult encounters on hardcore or insanity difficulty is amazingly satisfying.Sounds great, right? Unfortunately, while the game is at its best on the two hardest difficulty modes, it also suffers the most on those modes due to extremely buggy cover mechanics and unbelievably poor friendly AI. The AI is absolutely abysmal, and if you want that Insanity trophy you better be ready for some frustration. It's necessary to completely micomanage your allies by controlling where they're taking cover at all times. The problem with cover also manifests itself here, as there are many times when allies simply refuse to listen to you and wade out into enemy fire only to die immediately. It's so frustratingly idiotic that I find myself wondering how the game ever shipped in this fashion. It's a mess, and having to babysit your idiotic, suicidal squadmates really destroys what would have been an otherwise fantastic gameplay system. The general design is there, but the technical execution is utterly terrible and enough to make you bash your head against a wall. It's much more passable on Normal and Casual, but if you're gunning for Hardcore or Insanity, get ready for a headache.The overall design of the game, despite these poorer aspects, is excellent. The episodic style of gameplay in which you're recruiting allies just feels right, and the game feels far more organized and direct than the first game ever did. On the harder difficulties you really get a sense of it being a race against time. You've got to plan out what missions you're doing at what time, because upgrades are incredibly important and if you find yourself trying to take on Horizon or the Collector Ship without the good ones, you can actually get completely stuck and be forced to start over. While this sounds frustrating, it actually does a good job to suck you into the situation that Shepard and the crew find themselves in. They've got to get all of this done, and quickly, because the Collectors are on the move and they aren't waiting for you. This episodic style is paced perfectly, and you never seem to experience any of the drag that you see in the first game when you get dropped onto the Citadel after Eden Prime only to find yourself immediately bogged down with a huge area to explore and dozens of sidequests to tackle. It does a far better job with making sure you never feel overwhelmed than the first game. It's open-ended enough without stranding you in a sea of objectives -- You've always got a handful of options of what to do next, and it's up to you to decide which seems to be most important.All of the gameplay here comes to a head in a fantastic final act that sees everything you've done so far in the game build up to one massive conclusion. The suicide mission is truly excellent, and caps off a must-play game for everyone interested in RPGs.Insanity gameplay video:

content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 is a cinematic, story driven game with superb character development, sound and fun gameplay, and an explorative galaxy to boot. As Commander Shepard, you can create your own character, modify how they look, choose their class of biotics and combat tactics, as well as shape your own personal view on the galaxy, either being a kind and forgiving Paragon, or a guns blazing no bull Renegade. As previously mentioned, the characters (which there are plenty of, more if you count DLC from the Deluxe Edition) and they all have great story arcs. The voice acting is superb by both Shepards, male and female. It has expansive codex's to inform those if you havn't played the first game, which you should definitely do as the saves carry over between the games. This is a 10/10 for me, and easily one of my favourite games of all time.

												The Mass Effect series has probably been the most rich and emotional trilogy of games I've played since I've started my 'gaming career'. While the current RPG market is oversaturated with boring, shoot 'em ups, and your choices have little to no effect in the games currently on the market. Yes, Mass Effect's main game is a shooter, but Bioware makes up for those rough edges with a fantastic narrative, amazing soundtracks, characters who feel real, and choices that feel satisfactory while having big impacts on your next campaign in Mass Effect. Simply put; this trilogy is a masterpiece.As the iconic Commander Shepard, will you save the galaxy and all of its inhabitants, or doom them to extinction?10/10.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 sees you, yet again fighting to save the galaxy from the mysterious, alluring Reapers.Human colonies are disappearing and you are sent by the shady Illusive Man (Martin Sheen), the leader of the Pro-Human organization,  Cerberus  to find out what is going on, on the way you'll rediscover the new Normandy SR2, rebuilt by Cerberus after the devestating attack in the prologue. On your epic journey across the galaxy you'll meet powerfull allies, old friends, and dark enemies, on your mission to stop the Collectors and thwart the Reaper's plans.Mass Effect's story is one of sheer brilliance, the characters, location, soundtrack and intricately detailed codex will leave you enchanted for weeks. With moral choices that can leave you either stricken with guilt or brimming with a feeling of goodness, you can be sure that Commander Shephard is at the forefront of the fight. With detailed locations and quests you can be sure of a long, rich, gameplay experience that you may find yourself playing after your first playthrough.Mass Effect 2 once again employs the Renegade and Paragon speech options, this means that you can either pick the good option, or bad option when in conversation with a character, this can then, later on affect the choices you can make and the reaction of different characters upon meeting you.In the end, I can not possibly try and sum up Mass Effect 2's brilliance, it is my favourite game of all time, and is a story telling epic, it can and will more than likely leave you in awe and will want you cming back for me, with thoughts of "Just one more hour" becoming frequent. There is nothing more for me to say really than buy the game, I urge you, you won't regret it, and for the next 2 days is 75% off!EDIT: In case you're wondering why my play time is so low it's because I own Mass Effect 2 on the Xbox 360, and have played through it around 4 times :D(Mass Effect 2 is a Sci-Fi RPG)

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Mass Effect 2 is the greatest game of our time. Never before in the history of gaming has an individual had so many different choices as to what kinds of extraterrestrial to have sexual relations with. Although the romance stories are quite engaging and emotional, and the cut scences leading up to the implied intercourse quite titilating, I am always left scratching my head. It is not explained thuroughly enough how said conjugations works. How do the parts fit together? Can  commander Shepherd become pregnant? Why are the aliens so attracted to women while I am not? These are questions that are left unanswered. My first love was a krogan, and he will always be closest to my heart. But inspite of my intimacy with Grunt, I was ultimately confused by the biology involved. I understand that krogans posses four gonads but what isn't explained is how large or what shape their members are. One thing I know for sure is that the krogon would likely be on bottom as their sheer mass may very well crush the human involved. The previously mentioned questions perplexed me so much that I wrote my term paper in Human Sexuality class on them. Inspite of it being excelently written I recieved very sharp criticism from both my peers and my mom, who's help I enlisted in editing my paper. Innovators will always be persecuted and misunderstood by the thralls of the ignorant. Love is free. The rules of biology should not limit one's sexual desires. Just as the Supreme Court ruled for marriage equality, one day I would hope they will grant rights to those of us who wish to share physical intamacy with those of another species from another planet. Until then I will fight on with pride in my heart, knowing that being a xenosexual is not a sin, nor a lifestyle. And knowing that is more important than knowing how a krogan's parts fit with a human's parts, and in that lies the true value and lesson in Mass Effect 2.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2011
												Mass Effect is one of the most immense, well written and interesting story based game sagas I've ever played. If you haven't played the first one, you're missing a LOT, especially since all of the choices you've made in the first game can be ported over to the second game to change the experience. The combat's more crisp and cover based, and with cover based combat, my old enemy, "regenerating health" came with it, but it's varied nicely through six different player classes you get to select, ranging from abilities in tech, biotics, or good old fashioned, "Shoot it even harder." On a better note, the tedious inventory management is gone, as well as that stupid Mako vehicle. The story and atmosphere feels darker and more compelling, but will feel a tad slower in this one compared to the first, because much of the game is spent preparing you and your very likeable crew's survival odds for a final mission laid out early on. If you're a story nut, this series is where it's at!
