												Mass Effect 2 [9.5/10]BioWare had made a lot of improvements in the second game. While Mass Effect 1 was a great game, this sequel really just improves everything !-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Mass Effect 3 [9.0/10] (endings [0/10])Mass Effect should be a near masterpiece of a video game series. Sadly, the ending almost ruined the series. because no matter which ending you choose, all of the choices you've made in Mass Effect 1 & 2 leading up to the final moments mean nothing and have no effect on the final outcome.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
rating: worth buying at full pricescore: 10/10 - masterpiecesimilar games: Deus Ex, The Bureau, Dragon Age: Origins, Spec Ops The Linetags: story-rich, action packed, epic, character development, choicesMass Effect 1 was an okay game, it had dull gameplay but a good story and cool characters. Mass Effect 2 does not simply improve everything ME1 did, the devs completely overhauled the whole thing like they build it from scratch, this time with much more budget and a longer deadline. Whats impressive about this is the size of the game and the quality of everything. It is very rare that a big game like this, an open world game or RPG, is so well designed in every area. If you think about it there is always something which is not really fleshed out in some game you think are great, of course they are just small things, but that is the difference between a masterpiece and a very good game. For example look at the trading system and shops in most RPGs. Probably the shops will sell random equipment and you can sell everything you find there, and you probably will get tons of loot you never need.In Mass Effect 2 you get no loot, except money and resources. There are only some moments in the game where you find an upgrade or an alternative to an existing weapon. Giving the player tons of loot like in other games (also in Mass Effect 1) just doesnt make sense, because it does nothing except wasting your time because you have to compare it to your existing loot to see if its worth it, if not you will sell it. That also breaks the balance of money the players gets in most games and to counter that the developers balance the shops in a way that you rarely find something useful to buy. Because the money you get in ME2 is more controlled and shops have only specific items they sell only once (you only need them once), everything gets better. Exploration and hacking is more rewarding, because the money you get is more useful. Visiting shops is worth doing because EVERYTHING you can buy is worth it, you just need the money for it. And it opens more flexibility for the devs to design their missions, or just small things like giving you opportunities to get discounts which wouldnt be worth getting in other games. All that is just a tiny fraction of the game, I just want to explain to you to how fleshed out and well designed this game is.Bioware didn't care about genre conventions or did things only because this game is supposed to be an RPG, every decision they made is because it makes sense for the game, nothing else. Another example for that is the inventory system, you have no inventory actually. You only need to find one copy of a weapon, it will be available for all squad members. That removes the really annoying fiddling around with the inventory crap in ME1. They also moved the ammo upgrades from the inventory to the skill menu, which means they are skills now and every crew member has maybe 1 or 2 ammo upgrade available to him, which also gives you more criteria to pick your party-members. There are also other criteria to pick party-members apart from who is the coolest, which was really the only criteria in ME1, skills of your crew didn't really matter. Every party member has set weapon-types he can use, set abilties and strengths which can synergy with others or be redundant.Also there is a mission every crew member will have for you. Doing these will not only make them loyal, they will also unlock an extra ability for them and also matter for the story (no spoilers), but its not just "doing" these missions, you can fail them and then they are gone and you have to live with the consequences.In Mass Effect 2 you get your crew members much faster than in ME1, which is good, because it gives you more variety early on and there are more crew members in total, all of them very different and interesting in their own way. There was only 1 character which I hated and is cliche in my opinion (Jack). Actually the conversations with the crew members were the most fun part about ME2 for me, the dialogues were really interesting but not just exposition or alibi character development and all of it is optional, which is great for several reasons. There are many things in Mass Effect 2 which are optional, I think if you do only the must-do things, you could finish this game in 5 hours or so. It took me 25 hours and I know that there were easily 5 more hours I could put into it, but I don't recommend doing everything you can, it could get tenacious. Luckily unlike ME1 where every side-quests was obvious filler, every side mission in ME2 is unqiue and meaningful and you get useful rewards for them. They even managed to make the exploration of planets fun. In ME1 you just clicked on every unexplored planet and you got some text. In ME2 you have a scanner and have to scan the surface manually to find resources. That process is not boring because it is presented very nice and it is very rewarding, because the resources you find are crucial to get upgrades, and the upgrades themselves are also crucial. Still you are not forced to do these scans if you don't want to, there are enough upgrades you can buy and find and you also sometimes find resources on missions.The combat got the biggest overhaul, it is actually fun and challenging now. The AI is improved greatly compared to ME1, but your party sometimes still does stupid things, but you can control them much more easy now and still more flexbile just with 1 button for each party member, and managing them is more important now, because of their powers. Shephard also has powers now depending on the class you pick, most of them you already know from ME1 (they are still cool), but there are also some new powers. These are not only useful and necessary, they are also really fun to use thanks to really good sound-design, animations and hit-feedback. Bioware also proves that you can make satisfying gunsounds for sci-fi/laser weapons. Enemies aren't bullet sponges anymore, if you know how to bring their shields down, they react to your shots, fall down, scream because you burn them or if they are mechs they loose an arm or something. Your shots just have more impact now which makes combat more fun overall. The only thing which could be improved is the enemy design, the enemies are cool and there are a good number of enemy types, but the tactics you fight them with are not much different. With more diverse enemy types the combat could have more variety, which it does not really need though. I'm not a fan of regenerating health, because it makes the outcome of a fight irrelevant for the next fights, it only matters that you win the fight, but regenerating health makes sense for this game and works.I don't want to talk much about the story, because I don't want to spoil anything. What really surprised me was the amount of elements which carry over from ME1 and how many choices you have in general, these not only have impacts on small side-stories, but also on the ending of ME2. The ending alone of ME2 is a masterpiece. There are so many variables in the ending it easily surpasses the amount of choices you have in other games, and in most games your choices don't really matter anyway. I'm really eager to see how the consequences will affect ME3. There were parts in the game where I really had to think about my decisions, rarely the choices are black and white, sometimes you might not even notice that something is a "choice". Especially one decision kept me thinking for a very long time, and I still don't know what the right thing to do was (probably because there is no simple right and wrong for that question). The story is much more engaging and the dialouges much more interesting than in ME1, because they properly animated the cutscenes this time. Characters don't just stand infront of each other like robots, they move around, do things, even Shephard does. I have no more characters left for this review.

												El mejor Sci-Fi RPG que jugué en mi vida... una excelente historia, muy de película, bastante sombría y dramática.El gameplay es más dinámico que el Mass Effect 1, pudiendo hacer una enfrentación sin tener que pausear para que la squad use sus poderes bióticos, o sin tener que pausear para cambiar el tipo de munición.Los gráficos son más oscuros y nítidos en color, eso le da una linda atmósfera, sintiendo estar en otro juego, sacándote la idea de una expansión del 1.¿Si necesitás haber jugado el primero para entender el segundo?Para nada, aunque algunos personajes vuelven, las decisiones que tomaste (las cuales cambia todo, ya que incluso hay decisiones de vida o muerte, tanto de la squad como propias) se mantienen, aunque si no importás el savegame del primero, las decisiones serían las "default".Explorar la Vía Láctea, conocer e interactuar con otras razas, explorar planetas y lunas (incluso nuestra Luna), con una fantástica historia. ME2.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												Having just recently replayed Mass Effect 2 I was shocked at just how well everything has held up. People praise ME2 for being one of the greatest games made and it's hard to argue. Mass Effect 2 is a truly remarkable game and what makes it that way isn't any one aspect, but the interplay between all the systems that has allowed it to shine. Only by skillfully weaving the elements of combat, story, art and sound together did the men and women of BioWare create such a remarkable experience. But there's one additional system that has helped elevate Mass Effect 2 to such a timeless classic. The players. By adding our own personal stories to the tapestry already laid out by BioWare did each and everyone of us create their own indelible experiences that will always hold up to the test of time. Mass Effect 2 respects the player's choices and because of that it will ALWAYS be that good.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
SummaryHonestly, doing a review for such an already ubiquitous game may well be a pointless exercise, but to be honest I just played this game for 40 hours in 3 days and I wanted a place to put my thoughts. The game isn't perfect, but it's damn good. The few flaws are mostly a consequence of the development being focused towards consoles, but they aren't game destroying.Also I'm writing this withough having read any other reviews - it was a bit of an impulse buy - so apologies if I repeat everything you've already read, or completely miss the point somewhere.Pros:Immersive worldFantastic writingVoice actingShootingCons:Texture quality/general graphics optionsVariety of combatKeybindingsFacial expressions made by ShepardStory (Spoiler free)Frankly, this is the only reason anyone should get this game. If you have no interest in storytelling whatsoever, there are much better shooters out there; if you have no interest in shooters, it's not worth being put off. The story is very immersive, with an incredibly fleshed out world, and more than makes up for any flaws the game has in other areas. Characters don't feel neglected, although sometimes there isn't quite enough content for a character you want to experience more of. (Side note: You may get a mixed first impression of "The Salarian", which could prompt you to stop going out of your way to talk to him. This is the sensible option if you wish to preserve your sides later in the game. Some of his lines are just golden.)If you haven't played Mass Effect 1, I would recommend playing it first, even if it is mechanically slightly inferior to it's sequel, and you can play it without. However, a lot of enjoyment can be derived from taking a single Shepard, with all his actions, choices, and in my case, awful facial hair, through the series.CombatSatisfying, though slightly repetitive. The cover system can be awkward to use at times, thanks to Use, Sprint, and Take Cover all forcibly bound to the same action - by far the ugliest scar from the console port. If, like I did, you want to play with the same controls as every other PC shooter in the universe, the easiest fix is to use the primary and secondary keybinding functionality to bind the do-everything button to both what you want the Use and Sprint buttons to be. Often you'll be sprinting into cover anyway, so it kind of works, but it's definitely not ideal.There's a lot of variety to be had in terms of the ways you can build Shepard, but during a single playthrough it can get fairly restrictive, especially if you want to play optimally. That said, the variety in squadmates can allow a few different tactical approaches for the same Shepard, even if you only get to experience their skills and playstyle via the tactics interface, which carries over nicely from Mass Effect 1.Roleplaying and MoralityThe morality system is extremely black and white, which can be an issue, but if you stick to any non-gamey moral compass for your Shepard, it will probably see you pick up a good few Paragon and Renegade points each. Some important dialogue options require many of one or the other, though, so it's difficult to play a middle man, which is a little disappointing. Additionally, some choices don't really fall under stereotypical "good" and "evil" labels either way, but they assign Parargon and Renegade points to them anyway, so it doesn't always make sense. I didn't find it really hindered me in any way though. The feeling of decisions having an impact in the world is always great, though.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												If you haven't played Mass Effect 1 then stop reading this review AND GO PLAY THAT FIRST to have the best experience! Mass Effect 2 takes many of the rpg elements from Mass Effect 1 out but solidifies the gameplay more and trims out all the fat from the first game so you get nothing but pure meat.The exploration is gone but in return you get better dialouge and better combat. The characters are more diversed and flushed out and I thought they were better due to personalities and more backstory into them, If you are into sidequests over main missions then ME2 does a way better job than ME1 in that respect and the main quest is still really good but the side missions mostly involve loyalty missions to give your crew members more story and helping them out. Would I reccommend ME2 over ME1? No because I believe that you have to play all 3 games to get the full experience but IMO the gameplay is a lot better than ME1 but less tactical and more action. It still feels like a choose your own adventure game and has that 70's, 80's Space opera feel that the first one has but adds more spices to it like Omega which is heavily inspired by the film Blade Runner. It's well worth a buy and you will love every minute of it. Suicide mission is also one of the best end missions I have ever played, I felt really engrossed and felt like I was in a daredevil mission with the odds stacked against me. It's hard for me to choose between which I like more in Mass Effect 1 or 2 because they are both awesome but this game is worth a playthrough and It is one of the best sequels ever.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												This is a fantastic game. The gameplay is fun, and has a clean layout bar for all your biotics. There is alot of fun to be had. The story took me around 25 hours to complete, and it was epic from start to finish. The pacing of it is also really good. The share of time with the story and gameplay are near perfect, and Bioware definetly knew their strong points in the developement. The RPG factor of this game is also really well made, with dialogue options that progress into relationships and story, and an interesting karma system similar to SWTOR and Fallout: New Vegas that unlock more dialogue options. The graphics are pretty good too, but I'm not gonna go into detail about that since this is a 5 year old game. The sound design helps set the theme for a futuristic galaxy very well, and there are a few songs from the official soundtrack that I really like. Now... technical issues. The game crashed on me twice. I don't know why, but they did. Also one time, I was floating in the air walking around, which was hilarious until I found out couldn't get down. Luckily I could just load the previous autosave. Seriously though, this is still a fantastic game. There's a HUGE galaxy to explore, and a ton of planets to visit or even mine resources from. Even when you finish the storyline and feel those chills from that EPIC ending mission, you can still continue travelling around the Milky Way completing sidequests. Not only is Mass Effect 2 a fantastic game, but it is now one of the best games I have ever played.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												Finished the game with insanity difficulty yesterday (and started with it ^^) and now I'm going to the new game+ in casual, damnly hilarious!This game has pretty much everything for itself, the gameplay's wonderful, the graphics are very good, it has boobs (and sex somehow) and guns, there are aliens. The syfy part is really intersteting and every planet has its description. You have many many choices during the game which, for most of them, does truly matter for the rest of the game. There are many possible classes, though as I just ended the game with one of them I can't really talk about it. Though, I suspect it is a good point. And way, much more... ^^ (such as hacking, bypassing... Reminded me of Alien Isolation, loved it) The bad points will take me more times, but it's because I don't want to spoil any of the game. I insist this is a wonderful game, I rarely end my games and I'm about to do it a second time. It's just that I found intersting to explain what can be bad, for two reason. First, because it's important for you to know if there are thing you can't live with (but I doubt it'll be the case here), and second because other people will be able to contrast my opinion. ^^There are some bad points too. Glitches, damn I was almost at the 400th save cause even when no battle was excpected, I feared to start flying or to get stuck in wall or similar weird behaviors. These does not happen often, but as there sometimes are no way to get rid of them if not reloading a previous game, it can be really really annoying. (It has never been for me as the first time it happened to me I started saving as I was breathing, but no doubt it can be) Another glitch which is quiet weird but is not a problem at all is that sometimes characters don't have their proper voices (and no, I'm not talking about mike going weird, there's that too I know it's normal), this isn't exactly a bad point as it's even funny sometimes.Another bad point is the money. You're limited in money by the money you get from your missions and this isn't enough to buy everything, I think it's possible through new game+ though, I'll see that soon enough. Quiet the same, but some people will probably prefer it this way, it's not possible to level paragon and renegate to the max. It's though probably to have one to the max if you foccus, but you can't try to have always all choices, or if it's possible, I clearly missed something. (If that's the case, please tell me that, without telling me what this is, wanna find out by myself)And there is that keybinding that made me mad more than once. the SPACEBAR which became LEFTSHIFT to me is used to, well, everything. Interaction, picking up, talking, hiding, crouching, running. This is conveniant, but also very annoying. You're just trying to running from those enemy of yours, you just slip for a bit on the left and there you're now hiding in plain side which is a suicide move. And there lots of other ugly situation this is causing. Another thing, and if you've never play the game it's important you hear that, the tip at the beginning of the game ain't dynamic. So if you change you're keybinding's settings these will still point you to the default settings, so be sure to remember really well after changing you biding that you'll be able to know how to use them.And one hell of a bad point... You can't have a lesbian relationship between Shepard and Miranda. (damn! xD)Oh another bad point I'm starting to experience, I yes I know manipulating the file it is possible, but you cannot skip the long, long introduction of the game. And when you wanna restart it, this is becoming a real pain in the <3. ^^I'd like to add that I didn't play Mass Effect 1  (yet :p), and this isn't really annoying, the game kinda "remind" you of what happened in the first game, though I think it'd be better, but that doesn't have to stop you.About difficulty, this isn't a realy hard game. As I said, I started the game with the insanity difficulty with no previous experience in the mass effect franchise and I managed to keep it isane 'till the end of the game. Not that insanity is not hard (it is ^^), but the game is quiet intuitive, it's easy to find how to handle a battle and if you're not to bad at aiming, this isn't that hard. I can't advise any difficulty as I only know insanity (and a bit of casual now).I'm disappointed there's only a "yes/no" notation on steam, I'd like to put a ten to this game! :D

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												After finishing Mass Effect 1 a couple of days ago, I was eager to start playing Mass Effect 2 as soon as possible. Expecting more of the same, I was in for a few unpleasant surprises. So much has changed that it almost feels like a different game. CONTROLS:The controls are so radically different from ME1 that it actually got me killed on several occasions. I felt like my arms had been cut off and then sewn back on backwards! I know that eventually I'll get used to the new controls but they still feel super weird.WEAPONS:Reloading? Seriously? Can't buy new weapons, only the blueprints? Really? While I'm happy that I don't have to manually customize every single weapon on every single squad member, this is a bit too simplistic.MAP:There was nothing wrong with the maps in ME1. The map in ME2 is hard to read and too colourful. It looks like somebody just resized all the locations to 20x10 pixels and made them into a map. What happened to the ability to add waypoints?HUD:Why am I able to "light up" objects through walls? It's distracting. The colour and thickness of the rectangle make things easy to miss. In the first ME game everything stood out great when you placed the crosshairs over an item.CHARACTER SKILLS:What happened to all my skills from ME1? Puff! Disappeared into thin air! Now you only get five. Yay! Thank you, Bioware!PROFANITY:I don't remember hearing much profanity in ME1. While I'm not against it per se, I didn't expect this from ME2 judging by the tone set by ME1. Completely unnecessary.Overall I can't say it's a bad game and I'm curious to see how the story develops. However, compared to ME1, I can't help but wonder: WHAT WERE THEY THINKING!!?

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												A must-have sequel to original Mass Effect. Not that it is particularly great - in my opinion, it doesn't measure up to its predecessor nor to the trilogy's finale - but it's a necessary part of the story and it's definitely worth playing.The second part of ME franchise puts greater accent on squad interaction. In fact, you can get as much as a dozen companions, and missions related to their backstories occupy most of the game. It might be a turn-off for some, but if you felt immersed in the first Mass Effect, you should find most of those characters and missions quite enjoyable, at least during the first playthrough. I promise you're going to love some of your new squadmates, who will make you laugh and cry, and it seems that your old friends haven't forgotten about you after all.The main storyline is consequently even shorter than in ME1, though with all the other assignments it shouldn't be a problem. One's for sure - I'm not going to spoil the climax, but it's as epic as the battle with the Sovereign. Mass Effect series didn't lose its scale and there are still moments that make you turn up the volume and sit at the edge of your seat. The ground battles have a whole new quality to them (finally Mass Effect has elements of a proper shooter - ducking behind cover and shooting seems more real and exciting than in the first part of the series), though perhaps you're going to miss the Mako.A few words about the equipment system - it's much simplier than in the first game and I personally consider it an improvement. If you enjoyed comparing stats, shopping, and painstakingly equipping every single member of your squad, you might be disappointed, but if not, here's good news. The whole equipment system has been replaced with several items of weaponry, a few customizable elements of armor for Shepard, and a variety of upgrades giving bonuses for Commander or the whole squad. You may like it or not, but it's definitely easier to deal with. Leveling system has been simplified as well - maybe even too much - but it's now more intuitive, and it doesn't take 40 levels to get you the skill you want anymore.My biggest pain with this game lies within DLC-s, which cost more than the game itself (especially when it's on sale), but when you finally play them, they seem essential to the story. It might be a pain in your wallet, but the sad truth is that some content has been apparently cut from the game and sold in separate bundles. Mass Effect 2 is still a fairly good game by itself, but it feels somehow incomplete without that additional content.That said, it's still Mass Effect, and thus it's a part of one of the greatest stories I've been immersed in. Don't forget to check digital deluxe edition available here for the same price... and have fun!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19
												With Mass Effect Andromeda on the near horizon, I wanted to go back and replay the original trilogy.Mass Effect 1 was a truly fantastic game and so I eagerly looked forward to the next installment in the series.The talented folks at BioWare did not disappoint. ME2 has a great compelling story complete with rich  characters and the right amount of action.I thoroughly enjoyed the adventure, but as P.T, Barnum/Walt Disney once said, “Always leave them wanting more.”And I want more.Is it wrong of me to want more? Has BioWare spoiled me so much that when they offer me a grand feast I find fault with the tablecloth? Shame on me, I know, but I make these observations out of love – like a doting parent over their gifted child. “That was GREAT BioWare, but deep down, I know you can do better!”The graphics are stunning and beautifully done. I marveled at just how immersive they were.It was very cool that you could (relatively) easily import your original Commander Shepherd from ME1 into ME2 along with all the choices that you made in ME1. The fact that those choices MATTERED and came back to impact ME2 – that was very satisfying.The game was rock solid. Not once did it crash on my computer. I did experience two small bugs during the main game. At one point I was unable to back-out of scanning a planet for valuable resources and had to drop out of the game to restart. Later in the game, my Commander Shepherd character sat down INSIDE a desk and looked up, over his shoulder at the other character speaking.Later during the Firewalker expansion, the game froze for approximately ten seconds, but then resumed. Also my re-mapping of the controls had an adverse impact on controlling the hovertank – drilling for research. I had to set them back to default in order to continue the mission.All in all, these were very minor complaints. The backdrops were gorgeous and many times I had to stop and look around just to take it in. The combat was good, with the right mix of intelligence and furious firing. The Heavy Weapons are a welcome addition.  I thought the AI was very well done. The enemy took cover and tied to get behind your cover to fire at you. Also your companions intelligently sought and used cover very well. As a whole, I thought the use and ease of cover was excellent! Very seamless and extremely useful!There were a few puzzle-solving missions where you never fired a shot – I enjoyed the variety. It felt good to mix things up.The “heat sinks” for the weapons were a step backwards in my humble opinion. I felt like we went from a truly futuristic idea of not needing a ton of ammunition to reload the weapons, to having to constantly look and find these generic heat-sinks. Why not just say we needed regular ole ammo again?I also missed being able to customize my weapons with different types of ammo and weapon mods. Yes, it was neat that there were seven steps to progressively upgrade the weapons, but it did not quite come across the same to me. In ME1, you could have customized weapons and ammo load-out for different members of your squad. Now, you had to rely on a class skill upgrade giving you access to a type of ammo. It didn’t make much sense and it didn’t feel as customizable. I will admit that the upside was the ease in which could direct characters to change specialized ammos in ME2.However, I loved the ability to modify your armor and customize the colors – that was very cool!I thought that the game could have benefited from more variety in the lock-picking/hacking mini-games. Why couldn’t we bring back some of the old classics from ME1? I did appreciate being able to buy mods which allowed me more time to solve them – that was nice!I really liked being able to purchase special ingredents to improve the quality of the food and give crew morale a boost. I thought that being able to upgrade the Normandy was a great new concept. Having those additional enhancements ultimately helped you to succeed and emerge victorious in the final conflict. However, I was hoping for more ability to add things that would be a bit more useful during the early and mid-game. Perhaps like a firing range, where you could improve your team’s combat skills over time or perhaps allow them to be able to learn different weapons throughout the game. Maybe you had the alternate choice of adding a biotics lab.  Maybe a running track or fitness room which allowed characters to train and gain more hit points. How about adding an arcade or bowling alley to improve crew morale? Shepherd himself comments about adding a bar in the observation lounge – a nice nod to Star Trek TNG. I kept wanting to do more to keep the crew happy and efficient. One trip to the provisioner in the Citadel wasn’t enough for the good Commander Shepherd in my mind. The little devils at BioWare might make these things expensive for us, or add quests for materials or missions for those who would make the modifications all the while forcing you to make tough choices because there wouldn’t be enough room on the Normandy for all the things that you want.The ability to find/buy things to customize your captain’s cabin was great! I just wanted more and more! Perhaps a robot that would feed my fish for me.The story and the dialog were excellent! I wish there had been a little more dialogue and interaction between the other characters, which is what BioWare is so famous for. I thought there was too little of that.It also seemed to me that the designers listened to the player feedback about the pacing of ME1 and made modifications. In ME1, I felt pressured to rush through the main story line to save the galaxy. In ME2, the pacing has been modified so that I could explore, gain the loyalty of my crew and undertake the side missions without feeling that I was failing the main story.I appreciate a company that doesn’t shrink from making a game for adults. The content, the decisions, the relationships, the colorful language – it all helps to build a terrific and immersive world that you don’t want to leave. Maybe I can’t travel the stars and save humanity, but BioWare allows me believe that I can – and that’s just as good.The final battle was a tad disappointing in my humble opinion.[SPOILER ALERT]A giant terminator robot – really? That’s the best boss-creature we could come up with? I was a little confused – I didn’t think the thing had legs yet, and yet it was able to stand up 80 feet on its metal spine, fight me and my squad on a floating platform and duck and weave like a professional boxer?[/spoiler alert]Ah well, I still loved the game. I put in between 40 and 50 hours playing it the first time and I haven’t finished the Firewalker missions yet.I don’t know whom to credit the recent trend of unlocking “achievements” in a game, but I like it! It’s like an addicting hobby collecting pins. I am motivated to unlock things and earn “badges” of honor. It inspires me to go back and try and get the ones that I did not complete on my first go through.In conclusion, I thought that ME2 was a terrific game; A worthy successor to the excellent galaxy-building work done by BioWare. I can’t wait for Mass Effect 3, and 4 and beyond! It is a terrific franchise and I hope that it continues to improve!

content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												One of the best RPGs. Offers a lot of dialogue and different outcomes to more than just the ending. The game makes sure to reward the player for their efforts, and there is a lot to do. What stops this game from being legendary is the developers not taking enough time to perfect everything, but considering that this is just one of many Mass Effect games I can understand if this is to be seen as just one piece of the story. I have not played any of other ones yet, but I probably will!The things that amazed me: The unique design of all the main areas (there is even good music!) The talented team that reflects through all of the characters in this game - their personalities as well as their appearances The lore in this game, it's massive, almost overwhelming if you haven't played Mass Effect (1), but thats a good thing! The dialogue.The things I personally appreciated: The great introduction to the game, and friendliness towards players who haven't experienced the first game. It's ability to get me hooked. Dying to get to the next dialogue, mission or whatever. The difficulty, and the ability to prepare in many ways and even make it harder for a better reward/outcome The complexity, the emotions, the many endings.Things that I experienced and found negative: How the game gets easier with time How some decisions have a tremendous impact while others (that you think would matter) don't really matter The unexciting ending which dissapointed How there are patterns that when you notice them the game becomes predictable9/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Played 20+ hours of this in a single weekend, I literally could not put it down. The possibility of creating your own character and dictate it's decisions and personality provides for one of the most immersive gaming experiences you'll ever have. This is what games should always be, an interactive media where, instead of just inputting action, you're writing your own path and telling your own story, molding the framework the developers created into your liking. This is what a true interactive media should be like.Mass Effect 2 is a masterpiece, filled with the most interesting characters and settings I've ever seen in a video game, stellar gameplay, amazing storytelling and music and the most rewarding - and thrilling - choice mechanic. I cannot praise it enough. A true masterpiece that shows what video games are capable of as a true artform, building upon cinematic language and adding interactivity and the instrument of choice to become the ultimate storytelling medium.To sum it up, don't waste an opportunity to experience Mass Effect 2 at least once in your life. (P.S.: I recommend this specially to Star Trek fans, trust me on that one)

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												The first thing you notice about this sequel to Space Marine Inventory Manager 2007 is the complete lack of having to manage your space marine's inventory, which oddly enough improves the game no end!You've played the first Mass Effect, right? If so, you know the drill. ME2 delivers more of the good stuff, refines or removes the not-so-good stuff, gives you prettier visuals, etc. BioWare/EA once again test the patience of PC gamers around the world by not bothering to implement gamepad support and offering a DLC purchasing system so terrible that you'll think twice about throwing money their way.But, despite all of that, ME2 remains one of the most impressive action RPGs of the past decade, delivering an interesting gallery of characters, a better-than-average script and art design that puts many blockbuster sci-fi movies to shame.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												The direct sequel to the blockbusting science fiction RPG hit by Bioware, Mass Effect 2 picks up on and improves everything that made ME1 so memorable.Just like the first game, Mass Effect 2 has a very high immersion factor thanks to givin the player every opportunity to step into the shoes of the now legendary Commander Shepard, a completely customizeable protagonist in whom the player can all but become the savior or the scourge of the galaxy. Thanks to the save-file transfer system, all the major and even a few minor choices the player made in the first game will carry over into this game and change how the galactic community views you and the human race. The story has evolved quite a bit and at this point in the series is beginning to unfold into something grand and sinister, upon learning that your quarry from the previous game was nothing more than a mindless puppet being used by an even greater threat, the Commander has had difficulty convincing the council of this looming presence (ah yes, "reapers") and is instead being sent out to clean out the remaining synthetic soldiers used by Saren. Until a massive twist in the form of what looks suspiciously like a floating space turd attacks your ship and kills you in the process, but fear not, because you are revived at no small cost by Cerberus, an extremist pro-human organization that is officially labelled as a terrorist group. They explain that the space turd that killed you is related to a systematic series of abductions of human colonies, they believe something greater is at work and that you are the only one who can do anything about it.The combat mechanics have improved tenfold since the previous game, the cover system is much more fluid and dynamic and gunfights are intense, fast paced and mind boggling. The gameplay factor has also been completely amped up by the removal of the Mako and the horrendous inventory management system that plagued the first game, simplifying the inventory system and adding resources to collect via exploring the galaxy that can be used to research upgrades for your ship, armor, weapons and abilities. Like the previous game, the dialogue is highly varied, offers different outcomes based on your behavior and adds a good replay factor to the game. Being respectful or a complete jerk adds to a "paragon and renegade" score that can unlock further dialogue options that can make certain missions go a lot smoother, as well as adding a paragon-renegade interrupt indicator during conversations which can make the commander perform a heroic deed or a reckless decision. The choice, and consequences, are completely up to you. The squad has increased dramatically, with DLCs maxing out at 12 squadmates to choose from on missions. Each squadmate also offers their own personal mission which when completed earns you that particular squadmate's undying loyalty and unlocks a new ability and outfit for them.However, Mass Effect 2 also has more than it's fair share of graphical bugs that can break the immersion, as well as the occasional game-breaking glitch where the commander floats up to and gets trapped in the ceiling for no expliciable reason, forcing the player to reload their game and avoid the area where it occured. The level design is also far more linear than the previous game, and feels like a bit of a hand holder throughout as a result. All things considered, with a large experience that can easily max out at over 15 hours per playthrough depending on how much you want to experience the game, Mass Effect 2 is a deserving addition to the series and remains one of the best games I've played. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Wow.It's hard to overstate how much I enjoyed this game. It is masterful on every level - story, writing, scope, decision making, combat, environmental design, artwork, lighting effects, cinematography, musical score, sound design, and virtually any other area I can think of. It is, without exaggeration, that good.(mini spoiler) And the last mission - any team member you have come to know in the game can die a very permanent death based on your decisions, giving the finale a weight and consequence rarely experienced in video games. (end mini spoiler)What is perhaps most staggering is that even after a 50-hour playthrough (DLC included), you can be sure that you have seen far less than even half of the possibilities that the game has to offer. The original game isn't nearly as perfect, but still worth a run-through for the storyline and decisions that will carry over into the sequel.No, the game is not without faults. For one thing, it's overly easy and overly simplified compared to the original.It doesn't have the same level of cinematic polish that we've come to expect from AAA titles in 2013 and beyond.It gets excessively talkative and stale in certain areas.Much like the previous game, the romance subplots are stupid. If you want your Commander Shepard to get some quick and casual sex, it's not gonna happen. It's deep love or nothing. And that deep love comes out of nowhere, since your intimate conversations with any given love interest are extremely limited.But by far the worst of Mass Effect 2's problems is the very time-consuming process of grinding for resources, which isn't any fun at all. There are nearly endless amounts of resources available, but the game doesn't tell you how many you need. While there are ship upgrades available later in the game to make these processes quicker, the game doesn't tell you about them, and so you may waste much time in the first half grinding before acquiring them. My advice: grind at a minimum until you get the upgrades, and then only focus on "rich" planets, since there are more than enough to get you through.(Issues)I want to mention a few minor issues that you might run into. I frequently clipped through objects and got stuck, forcing a reload, and there are a few missions tied to DLC that resulted in game-breaking crashes. The latter problem was easily rectified by creating a shortcut to the .exe and putting -nomoviestartup in the parameters. One last very strange glitch resulted in my player character stretching her arms out to the sides, unable to shoot or interact anymore, solved only by reloading an earlier save and trying different dialogue choices before the bug. With a game this big, my recommendation is to keep numerous save files and save often.Overall, Mass Effect 2 is definitely one of my favorite games of 2010, matched only by Red Dead Redemption. In my book, that's saying a lot.9/10

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 did a good job of continuing the series. The RPG element is well preserved from the first game, and interesting new characters are introduced as well as familiar faces returning. But the highlight of Mass Effect 2 is the very memorable final mission, and the decisions and consequences that are encountered. number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												One of my favorite games ever. Mass Effect 2 makes massive strides towards fixing the issues with it's predecessor while also creating a fantastic cinematic experience for your average gamer. pros +Great combat especially in comparison to the previous game+Clear how each level will effect your character+Very large pool of squadmates larger than both ME1 and 3.+Loyalty missions help give depth to each character.+Overall fantastic story; however, it is a bit disappointing that some of the original squad members only make minor appearances+One of the greatest soundtracks in history.+Absolutely stunning ending that will leave you excited for the sequel. Cons - A distinct lack of rpg elements. To me ME1 seemed to have some pointless customization and rpg elements that bordered on annoying. While you can tell they tried to address this the game does feel shallow in some of it's out of combat mechanics unlike ME1 or ME3. I do feel like ME3 finds the medium the best.-The number of squad members although nice does somewhat make it hard to share a bond with all of them leading to me not caring about some as much as I had in the previous game.- Although the combat is very improved as long as you are patient as far as when you go out of cover the game can be a breeze because enemies have limited tools to force you out of cover which is added in Mass Effect 3.Overall fantastic game in the series which I know some hail as the best in the series. It was a giant leap on it's predecessor and a fantastic entry to the series; however, it does have some flaws and that is why I do keep it slightly behind ME3 despite the endings shortcomings.It's also hard to recommend this game without the willingness to play the other 2 so I recommend you pick those up as well. Note: Mass Effect 3 is not available on steam and must be purchased through EA Origin.

Cons - A distinct lack of rpg elements. To me ME1 seemed to have some pointless customization and rpg elements that bordered on annoying. While you can tell they tried to address this the game does feel shallow in some of it's out of combat mechanics unlike ME1 or ME3. I do feel like ME3 finds the medium the best.-The number of squad members although nice does somewhat make it hard to share a bond with all of them leading to me not caring about some as much as I had in the previous game.- Although the combat is very improved as long as you are patient as far as when you go out of cover the game can be a breeze because enemies have limited tools to force you out of cover which is added in Mass Effect 3.Overall fantastic game in the series which I know some hail as the best in the series. It was a giant leap on it's predecessor and a fantastic entry to the series; however, it does have some flaws and that is why I do keep it slightly behind ME3 despite the endings shortcomings.It's also hard to recommend this game without the willingness to play the other 2 so I recommend you pick those up as well. Note: Mass Effect 3 is not available on steam and must be purchased through EA Origin.

												You won't know the true meaning of cinematic story telling unless you have played this game. The setting, the art style, voice acting and the pace is just: https://i.redd.it/vmaai3h6j8ix.pngThere is an interactive galaxy map where you can fly your ship from planet to planet, or use mass relays and teleport from one point of the galaxy to another. Each planet that you land feels so different and alive. Gameplay is fun, fresh and exciting. They give you 6 classes to choose from that suits all type of gameplay.I was so obsessed with preparing for the sucide mission that I had forgot to romance with anyone in this game. So no comment there.A recap on Mass Effect 1: 


YouTube™ Video: Mass Effect Synopsis/Summary (HD) 

			Views: 18,716		

			This is the Mass Effect "Story so far.." from Bioware's Website. It's a quick Mass Effect digest video summarizing what happened leading up to Mass Effect 2.		

Sypnosis of Mass Effect 2: The game starts off with the Normandy being attacked by an unknown ship and Shepard being killed in action. He was later on brought back by Ceberus, lead by the Illusive Man, who assigned him on a mission to investigate why the humans colonies have been disappearing. After discovering that it was the Collectors who are behind these abductions, the same species that are responsible for the destruction of Normandy and Shepard's death, the commander must scout the galaxy and build the best team to take the fight to the Collectors.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2012
												This game is a masterpiece. ME1 was great, but this just builds on it and expands...a lot. If you thought the world was big in the last game, then expect the world to explode. You get to visit a much darker side to the galaxy. The graphics are amazing, a definite step up from the first game. I loved seeing the familiar faces, and liking the new comrades brought in. While you will definitely have your favorites, there is no doubt that Mass Effect 2's characters are distinct and memorable. For those who love romance, there are more love interests available. Trying to save the world is the best time to find the love of your life. The world is beautiful to look at and there is a lot to do aside from the story. There are tons of side quests to do with your companions and trips to planets to find minerals that will decide the loyalty of your comrades to who will survive through the game.  I believe that it is the strongest game in the trilogy. I've enjoyed multiple playthroughs and I know that there will be more to come. This game is just about perfect.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
   My Playthrough   Youtube Playlist    The Review Mass Effect 2 is an interesting case. While this game does add a lot of things like more exploitable cities, more companions, and a much bigger ship. They also removed some content as well like exploring uncharted worlds with the M35 Mako, the 60 level cap, a lot of talents, and worse of all the ability to talk to your companions at any time. This game does have some pros like the story is still good and the companions are well written and voice acted. The gamEplay is still the same as the prequel but now their is ammo and weapon restrictions. The cons are mostly all the things that Bioware removed from Mass Effect but a big one is that this game is far more linear than ME1. Now you can recruit any companions that you want and you have to wait for specific points to recruit your favorite companions. From all the negitives that I listed you are probably wondering why I am still recommending this game. Well while this game is not as great as Mass Effect it is still a good game and I recommend playing it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												Once upon a time, Bioware made a Space RPG that was incredibly EPIC. Mass Effect was its name, and it would be filled with many characters and character archetypes that I am still very fond of almost ten years later. The first one would have some kinks to work out, but the second one....the second one they would get almost completely right. Join Commander Shepard and his motley crew of misfits as you sail across the galaxy on your beloved ship (maybe loved by the fans more), fighting gangs, Geth, weird lizard things, oversized rodents, giant frog creatures, and all kinds of other insane races that Bioware has created, with loads of rich backstory for each one (via the codex). This game was so ahead of its time. With Voice actors like Jennifer Hale as Femshep, and Martin Sheen as the mysterious Illusive Man, it was almost impossible for this game to fail.What else can I say about this classic game. With some of the best voice acting even today, it stands above most other RPG's as a solid example of a great formula for a game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 adds another chapter in the Mass Effect trilogy, and it does so pretty damn well. It's been argued this game has the best plot out of the three games, and I'd say that's a fair statement. They really liven it up compared to the first Mass Effect. That being said, you'd be doing yourself a great disservice if you didn't play the first game before this one; you won't understand what ANYONE is saying. More importantly, you'll be missing out on crafting your very own story, making those important decisions in ME1, and that's what really stands out about this series. The gameplay is more refined, and smoother than the first, but dumbed down. A lot of the RPG'ness is sucked out of this one, which some people like. You can't customize your weapons or armor as extensively as you could like in one, but it isn't a complete loss; the game is still utterly fantastic and worth your time. All in all, this is an important step in the story of Commander Shepard, and until you beat it, you'll be absorbed.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2011
												A great sequel to an excellent sci-fi game.  I personally recomend playing the first one as that is still a great game unless you are more a shooter fan than an RPG fan in which case I woudl start here.  The combat is perhaps the biggest improvement and brings the game up to par with lots of other action games.  The characters and side quests were also improved over the original.  The main downsides are the story which very much has that "middle chapter" feel but is still good and the rpg feel which was dialed back too much for my tastes and may turn off other rpg fans.  But especially at today's prices this would easily be one of the first games I would point you to if you were looking for a great sci-fi game to play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2012
												Mass Effect 2 is an amazing action-rpg with great third person shooting mechanics.  The combat is very fun but not what makes Mass Effect so unforgettable.  The highlight is the characters, the way you interact with them, and the choices you make.  The characters are fully fleshed out and many of the game's missions are dedicated to gaining your allies' loyalty and learning more about them.  The ways you interact with them and decisions you make in the game, or have made in Mass Effect 1, have consequences both grand and subtle.  They combine to make the game one of the most personalized gaming experiences out there.Many triple A games aim to deliver an epic experience, and I won't claim that they fail.  But Mass Effect 2 is probably the most epic game I am familiar with.  Its epicness cannot be overstated and in fact its epicness is quantitatively thrice as large as the epicness of other triple A games whose epicness is the main selling point.  Yet despite the incredible epicness of Mass Effect 2 (and I am in no way discrediting the power of epicness), it doesn't neglect to add incredible depth to its characters and choices.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												I have not finished playing Mass Effect 2, however I applaud it and its predecessor for its creative use of modern physics to penetrate, if only slightly, the vast distances that lie between stars. Mass Effect 2 also adds more realistic flight sequences, as one has to calculate how much fuel will get them to their destination, acknowledging that fuel is, in fact, a finite resource. However, it does to some extent ignore Newton's first law in that one slows to a halt the minute the ship ceases to accelerate, however, there are worse gripes to be had about a video game than "It follows Aristotelian physics," as Aristotle essentially laid the groundwork for all modern thought.One of my favorite things to do as Commander Shepard was to probe undiscovered worlds, as this was something that I did in real life with the Voyager Probes. However, I doubt that these probes contained anything like the Golden Record that we put together, as First Contact has already been established in the Mass Effect universe.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												This is honestly one of the best games I've ever played.  It's main flaws are outside factors, such as hard to access DLC, with major features locked behind paywalls.But overall, the game is solid, focused and tells a story that is easy to get invested in.  You come to know your squadmates well, and the game encourages you to explore your relationships.  And of course, there's plenty of character building and shooty action.  But there's a lot of RP in this RPG, and that's in stark contrast to some newer games that claim that genre.If you like scifi, epic storytelling, romance subplots, third person shooting, or games that let you make meaningful choices, ME2 is a game for you.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												The sequel to the game that launched a universe and an epic franchise. Mass Effect 2 expands upon its origins with tighter gameplay and smooth visuals. A stripped down version in some respects compared to the first game, but not to its detriment. Gone are a lot of the more fiddly micromanagement RPG elements of sorting out gear for your teammates, as well as the long driving sections. The only tedious aspect of the game are the scanning elements of planets, but even things like this are sometimes helpful in drawing you into the universe growing before your eyes. Now if only EA would be Mass Effect 3 on Steam...

												I don't like Mass Effect! Something about it turns me off, and I can't say whether the brunt of it is the bland sci-fi that nerds love or the ♥♥♥♥ing lame cover shooting mechanic. But what do I know, because I sat through the entire ♥♥♥♥ing thing and played it without quitting, so it's doing SOMETHING right. This iteration has that weird alien dude called Mordin (probably the only character I've ever liked), boring planet probing for resources instead of boring lore-filled vehicle sections (you have to collect most of the resources for the best toys, so pucker up), more cover shooting, and while it fails to be compelling... well, I sat through the entire thing. So it's doing something right. Good ambience, maybe? ♥♥♥♥ if I know, I'm not playing this again or Mass Effect 3 under threat of being smothered into unconsciousness by boring gameplay. You figure out what it is.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												I don't understand why would anyone check the user reviews of this game. Dude, this game is one of the best games out there. The Mass Effect trilogy is, in my book, the best one in the entire gaming history. By far. I don't care what anyone have to say about the third game. These games made me cry like a little b*tch.Well, let's see:PROS: Amazing and breathtaking prologue (Trust me on that one) and an incredible story. Old and new companions. Each one with an amazing back story that will make you love them. Customizable armor. Impressive armory with new awesome weapons. The perfect mix between RPG and TPS. The best game of the trilogy (And I'm not saying that the other two are bad at all). Biotics and powers are much better than ME1. Of course, all the choices you made in ME1 will be crucial in this game and you will continue your story depending on what you did in the previous game.CONS: Downloadable Content is not included in this version of the game and it's incredibly expensive to buy through BioWare Store, sadly (Story DLC's like Kasumi's Stolen Memories, Project Overlord, Arrival). Exploring the galaxy and probing for resources can be a little tiring.If you want to enjoy the game even more, play it on Insanity difficulty.

content:
Posted: February 3
												I cant think of another example of how gaming could be done right, better than the Mass Effect series.An epic trilogy that spans three games in which you are in control of how the story evolves around you.Mass Effect 2 lived up to everything that was expected of this great space epic and is an amzing sequel to the its predecessor.Pros:-Ability to import ME 1 character and profile-Very good animation and graphics, voice acting is great-Great Combat with new powers and weapons-Streamlined Upgrades and Weapons-Your choices shape the story (especially the ones from the first game)-Even more characters, with interesting backstories-Side quest are more tied in and diverse-Very engaging story-REPLAYABILITYCons:-Planet Scanning for upgradesBioware did a great job taking Mass Effect to the next level and clearly deserves better than being owned by EA, but the Mass Effect series is sill the best example of how passionate game making is done right.

Posted: August 15, 2015
												Part 2 of an awesome Mass Effect game. Improved in many ways over the original, with new story to keep you occupied for many, many hours. You continue as commander Shepard and his crew in this new story, with somewhat unique start. You meet a lot of old characters from first game as well as new ones on your journey. Make sure you kept your saves from ME1, so you can transfer your choices and story to this game. It will give you a lot of sweet flashbacks on what you did in first game, in form of mails, unique character dialogues or on the local news. It's the sequel of an incredible game that don't disappoint. Game has great visuals, voice acting, animations and character design. Enjoy.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												This is honestly one of the best games I've ever played.  It's main flaws are outside factors, such as hard to access DLC, with major features locked behind paywalls.But overall, the game is solid, focused and tells a story that is easy to get invested in.  You come to know your squadmates well, and the game encourages you to explore your relationships.  And of course, there's plenty of character building and shooty action.  But there's a lot of RP in this RPG, and that's in stark contrast to some newer games that claim that genre.If you like scifi, epic storytelling, romance subplots, third person shooting, or games that let you make meaningful choices, ME2 is a game for you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2012
												Mass Effect 2 is an amazing action-rpg with great third person shooting mechanics.  The combat is very fun but not what makes Mass Effect so unforgettable.  The highlight is the characters, the way you interact with them, and the choices you make.  The characters are fully fleshed out and many of the game's missions are dedicated to gaining your allies' loyalty and learning more about them.  The ways you interact with them and decisions you make in the game, or have made in Mass Effect 1, have consequences both grand and subtle.  They combine to make the game one of the most personalized gaming experiences out there.Many triple A games aim to deliver an epic experience, and I won't claim that they fail.  But Mass Effect 2 is probably the most epic game I am familiar with.  Its epicness cannot be overstated and in fact its epicness is quantitatively thrice as large as the epicness of other triple A games whose epicness is the main selling point.  Yet despite the incredible epicness of Mass Effect 2 (and I am in no way discrediting the power of epicness), it doesn't neglect to add incredible depth to its characters and choices.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2012
												The second, and in my opinion, the best game in the Mass Effect trilogy. Improving upon the first game in every way, but NOT dumbing down many gameplay elements, it introduces a new, dramatic, exciting story full of unpredictable twists and turns, making it look like a spectacular, highly interactive space opera movie.The driving sections around barren planets from ME1 are gone (and replaced with planet scanning, and new driving sections if you own the appropriate DLC), even trivial sidequests have great direction, and seem important even though they do not tie in directly to the main story line. I loved the introduction of clearly Lovecraftian horror elements in the story, something that the third game completely ignored. The Reapers, ancient enemies of all sentient life, are basically intergalactic gods, dangerous even when destroyed, their huge spaceship-like bodies able to brainwash would-be explorers millenia after their "death". It feels you're fighting truly unknown and horrifying adversaries, which gives the game a very unique atmosphere.The characters are unique and believable, dialogue is well-written and interesting, and it's hard to leave the game once you've started playing.Playing ME1 is pretty much a requirement prior to playing ME2, though- after all, it is a continuation of a great storyline.The end is well-rounded, and even though it implies a sequel, it doesn't leave you hanging from a cliff, so to say :)Recommended!P.S. Getting the DLC for this game is a relatively hard process nowadays, thanks to EA's greedy, unoptimized and ham-handed decisions. Basically, you'll have to activate your ME2 copy on Origin, buy DLC on Origin, download them through Bioware Social website, and install them manually after installing (and running) ME2. Why would you do all that?Some DLCs (such as the Arrival and Lair of the Shadow Broker) have story-critical content, along with additional quality gameplay, which adds a lot of new content to the game. If you turn out to be a real fan of the game and hooked on the story of Commander Shepard, you WILL need to play through these additional stories, as they cover some moments heavily referenced in the sequel, Mass Effect 3.EA's way of selling DLC means they NEVER go on a sale, so be prepared to dish out some serious cash for them (individual DLC prices can be several times higher than the price of the base game!!!) and only purchase them if you're REALLY interested in the story. Also, you can safely ignore the "equipment" DLC, as they are really only a money grab, selling you variations of weapons or cosmetic "upgrades" to your team for real money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 adds another chapter in the Mass Effect trilogy, and it does so pretty damn well. It's been argued this game has the best plot out of the three games, and I'd say that's a fair statement. They really liven it up compared to the first Mass Effect. That being said, you'd be doing yourself a great disservice if you didn't play the first game before this one; you won't understand what ANYONE is saying. More importantly, you'll be missing out on crafting your very own story, making those important decisions in ME1, and that's what really stands out about this series. The gameplay is more refined, and smoother than the first, but dumbed down. A lot of the RPG'ness is sucked out of this one, which some people like. You can't customize your weapons or armor as extensively as you could like in one, but it isn't a complete loss; the game is still utterly fantastic and worth your time. All in all, this is an important step in the story of Commander Shepard, and until you beat it, you'll be absorbed.

												Good game, but my least favorite in the series. Being EAified practically everything is streamlined or made mainstream. Skills are fewer, you're limited to using only 1 at a time unlike all of them having individual cooldowns as in Mass Effect 1, ammo exists, and enemies can feel obnoxious rather than fun. It doesn't help that you have basically zero weapon choice as compared to Mass Effect 1, and all the worlds feel way smaller and infintely more linear.Still, the story is great, the music is awesome, and everything else is done well. Just because this was dumbed down so it woud sell to the masses doesn't mean it isn't worth playing, and is best experienced during a marathon of all three titles. If only Mass Effect 3 wasn't Origin exclusive...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												Widely considered by most to be the best in the trilogy, and for good reason. When it hit the scene early in 2010, it was a major step up from the already great Mass Effect. Combat, characters, overworlds, storytelling, atmosphere, Interface, sound quality, choices and side-quests, all of it was greatly improved with this game, and still stands strong to this day. The story follows two years after the events of Mass Effect 1. Due to reasons I will not reveal in fear of spoilers, Commander Shepard (the character you play as) has gotten off the public eye and is working with the pro-human organization called Cerberus, to deal with a threat the authorities choose to ignore. In order to do so, squad-mates must be recruited for a Suicide Mission to get rid of the threat.  And that's where you come in. Throughout a lengthy 35-40 hour campaign, you will travel to distant and varied worlds, making tough choices that can have devastating outcomes, to gain enough manpower for your campaign. The main plot of the game is actually really simple. Like, REALLY simple, close to shallow. All you do is find out where the threat comes from, assemble a team to deal with the threat, find a way to get to the threat and then destroy it. The real meat of the game is actually with the squad-mates, in fact there are far more missions centered around recruiting characters and later gaining their loyalty through other missions. It's more of a character study than a traditional RPG (though you still get to explore fascinating locations and all that good stuff). And it works, because these are some really great characters. They're layered individuals from fascinating cultures and backgrounds, with believeable and complex motivations, striking personalities and involving arcs that really invest you in their struggles and the galaxy they inhabit. It also helps that the conversations have been much improved from the previous game. In ME1, as well as other games, during dialogue characters would tend to stand completely still, maybe move their arms a few times with a bit of a stern, not very emotive face. That still happens from time to time, but often characters will now walk around the room while they talk, or maybe the camera will move around, focus on something or give interesting angles. The much improved camera work in this game is really welcome. Here they use shadows and light, colour, as well as other things to better create a mood, which really improves the quality of your interactions.There are a lot more things I could say about this game, but what it boils down to, is that I think this is a fantastic game that you should give a try if you are interested in a character-focused game that touches on very real and difficult themes and issues in a very mature and smart way. I recommend that you import a save from ME1, since choices you made there will show up again, either to shake your hand or kick you in the balls. It greatly increases your ability to create your very own Shepard with a unique history, and that is a great experience. Score: 9.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2010
												The Mass Effect series is Bioware's greatest masterpiece, in my humble opinion. Its writing and cinematic narrative are unparalleled in gaming. The combat improved as the series went on, and the story consistently maintained its level of quality. Player choice has never been the same since the Mass Effect games. No two players' Shepards are the same, and it is worth playing the series multiple times to see how different situations would play out with different choices.My biggest complaint has little to do with the game itself, but how DLCs are distributed. If you get the Steam version, you have to make an account on Bioware's social site, buy them, download and install them manually, and hope that you never have to have Steam check the integrity of local files. I recommend getting all three games in the trilogy pack; you know where I am talking about.Reasonable price: $20.

content:
Posted: February 12
												Yet another EPIC game from bioware, and the second installment of the Mass Effect Series, just as epic, if not moreso, as the first. Choices still matter,and you see some of your choices from the first game making big and little waves in your story; actions matter, who lives, who dies, who do you save....I only have 33.4 hours on steam with this game, but over 100 on Origin (more DLC available on origin). This game along with the first are beyond amazing, this second installment is much darker than the first game.  The Reapers are back, only this time they're using the mysterious Collectors instead of the Geth, whole human colonies are vanishing without a trace, no signs left behind, no struggle, nothing.  Its up to you, to find out why/how and put a stop to it.You have new companions, with returning faces, and a whole other side of the universe to explore and tame.I recommend this game whole heartedly, the graphics hold up to the test of time, the decisions still matter, and it still hits you right in the feels, and keeps on delivering with an epic stoy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
*DISCLAIMER: Don’t be fooled by my effectively non-existent playtime, I’ve beaten the non-steam verison of the game several times before.* In Mass Effect 2, you are assuming the role of the recently resurrected Space Jesus, also known as Commander Shepard. By doing so, you have the chance to kick some nasty-looking alien butts, gather an almost entirely new crew, make love and shed tears of joy, shake your @ss in the finest clubs of the Pirate Queen Aria T’Loak, make friendly conversations with an oh-so cheerful Reaper about things like 'leave the dead where they fall',  ‘assuming direct control’, 'the forces of the universe bend to me'  and ‘preserve Shepard’s body if possible’, and listen to the very model of a scientist salarian inexhaustibly singing on his terrible voice. Sounds fun, right? Well...Although gameplay-wise this game isn’t the most refined installment of the series (that title goes to Mass Effect 3 in spite of its horrible running animations) and the devs ripped out some RPG elements and the sense of exploration of the first game completely (actually, the latter part is not necessarily a bad thing, considering the tedious straggling across stark and empty terrain with the almost uncontrollably bouncy Mako was very...well, tedious as f*ck), overall Mass Effect 2 is hands down the best game in the trilogy. It represents a huge and very welcomed quality shift in the shooter part of the game, fighting and kicking butts here are far more fluid and enjoyable than it was in Mass Effect 1 with those clunky controls; the level design is finally decent and the new maps are especially memorable; and the soundtrack is so good, that I would say it’s beyond my comprehension how anyone could make such a thing...I declare here and now, that the composer Jack Wall must have been on demigod level when he composed those wonderful tunes. Of course the real bread-and-butter here are the characters. Except Tali and Garrus, they are all completely new and fresh-feeling faces. As I was getting to know them better realizing how distinct, flawed, interesting and (in deep down) fragile personalities they are, I just couldn’t help loving them more and more, which obviously applied to the game itself. This is the greatest achievement of ME2, the genuine and extensive relationships between the main hero and the seemingly plot device NPCs, the potent world-building through its characters and their lovely recruitment and loyalty missions.The biggest faults of the game aren’t even present in the actual game, which creates a kinda weird situation when it comes to evaluating it: The Reaper threat is always just lurking in the background, the main storyline doesn’t push the larger narrative forward (I mean what do we know at the start? The Reapers are coming, we are screwed, what are we going to do to stop them? No idea. At the end we know almost exactly that, nothing more...still have no idea what to do with the Reaper threat.) and the game introduces 10 completely new characters only to push the burden of closing their story arcs onto the third game. I’m sure that this situation (meaning ME2 is essentially not else than a long and exceptionally good side trip) created a big room of creativity for the devs to fill at ME2, and restricted their possibilities badly at ME3, ultimately making the second game better and worse the third.In the end, what really matters is that Mass Effect 2 is an amazing game, and it goes without saying that it is absolutely recommended to experience at least once in your life. Preferably more than once.

content:
Posted: February 19
												One day 7 years ago as a kid I was walking around the store and I see the sign "N7" It caused curiosty and I was interested so I picked it up for the 360 and boy... Was I in for a wild ride, immediately I went home, put it into my console I played it all day! It was marvelous! I felt like a space-fighting/ BountyHunter/ Badass commander of the Normandy. Ever since I've been a huge fan of the mass effect series, and I recently got it again for the PC to prepare for Andromeda. Anyways, enough of the life story. Should you get this game? Yes, but only if you played the first one. You will only enjoy this masterpiece of the trilogy if you play mass effect 1 then import your character into this game, due to all your actions carrying over such as "Friendships" "The Death of some squadmates" and the overall immersive experince. In my opinion this is the best out of all 3 mass effects, due to its solid-smooth combat, to it's thought out story. Quick List of why you should get this:- Play this after Mass effect 1, PLEASE!- It's combat is awesome, diverse classes to choose from. "I recommened the Vanguard"- Story is very well written.- Character depth is outstanding.- Soundtrack is awesome.- Graphics for a 7 year old game is fantastic! QUICK NOTE: Actions matter, it can lead to a wide array of events, such as a different approach to a mission, new allies and even death of a squadmate! Take your time, don't rush. This is a story driven game, you're meant to engage in conversations.For god's sake, don't skip dialogue!
