number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22
												So, I was a bit snarky on my Dragon Age Origins review, and this game closely follows in that vein wherein I have played this soul sucker of a game and delivered my life over to Bioware for the chance at space husband banging.  Im Bioware trash.  But, since I admit it you can take the review with a grain of salt right? Also, some spoilers because im terrible and you can hate me later.I've played a couple of times.  I like the game.  It's a great game, and I personally enjoyed the story, and the characters, and the animations, and the weaponry, etc etc.  Fundamentally, it's a good game, and made improvements to the combat system, in my opinion, over Mass Effect at the expense of the weapon and armor upgrading system that I preferred.  There are aspects that can be tedious (planet scanning, having to avoid Jacob because femShep refuses to not be a flirty ho with him, like really? Garrus is space husband not Jacob!).  There are aspects that can be infuriating (hello Kaidan, quit being ♥♥♥♥♥y!, occasional ultra sticky walls can be ultra sticky).  In my opinion however, no matter how many times I took a grenade to the face because I got stuck on cover on the front side, I still enjoyed the game.Overall rating: Recommended.  Would take more grenades to the face for Garrus.

content:
Posted: March 18
												Mass Effect 2 is likely the greatest sci-fi RPG of all time. I've only done one playthrough and I feel like I haven't even scratched the surface for what this game has to offer.Pros:- One of the most compelling stories in gaming history- Characters feel extremely real and dialogue with them is engaging- Great graphics for being over 7 years old - Mountains of content- Every mission has meaning (i.e. no boring fetch quests)- Your actions really do have consequences, although it may not seem that way at first- $20 is an absolute steal, I would easily pay $60 for it- Amazing endingCons:- Just another cover shooter in terms of combat- Dialogue options don't always do what you think they'll do (this is rare but still annoying at times)- You will cryIf you've never played this game, you're really missing out.

Posted: August 19, 2016
												______________________________________________________________!!!!!!!!!!!HEAVY STORY SPOILERS!!!!!!!!!!!______________________________________________________________Mass Effect's 1 and 2 are amazing games!the atmosphere is so good.STORY TIME!when i played mass effect 1, when i saw Tali for the first time i knew i was going to protect heruntil the very end no matter what, every time Tali needed to speak with me, i did it with open armseverything was going great!then came the final mission... i put tali in my group because i wanted shephard to protect her againsteverything collector's might have. I chose Thane for to pipes and garru's to lead second group.Thane dies while doors are getting shut, we found survivor's of normandy who were captured, i thoughtthe way was clear and signed them with no escort, they all died, then miranda lead me, Tali and Legionthrough collertor's area, right at the Legion get's taken (i didn't do he's loyalty mission, lucky orTali would have died).So we made it into the final room, we fight collector's and whatever Reaper they are creating, we win the fight. but then a cutscene comes up...Tali is sliding down into the huge pit to her death, i start ripping irl my hair while screamer at monitor as shephard lunges to save Tali. Tali's hold slips off shephard's hand is going off the edge, i start screaming, then shephard's hand graps Tali and pull's her up!, suddenly an explosion, Tali is now other side on the room now, not moving, my heart starts pounding again "no, this gannot be!" when shephard went closer to her, Tali awoke and signed she is ok, we helped miranda from under a huge steel pipe or something and made it to ship.I have never while playing felted like that while playing Mass Effect 2, perma death system is so great (perma death does not affect if one dies on random mission, they will get up, but in story mission's some of them have a change depending what you do)you learn to care for them (and if not for everyone, then at least for one you care) and the final mission will test you're nerves__________________________________________________________________________________!!!!!!END OF SPOILER'S!!!!!___________________________________________________________________________________i give this game 9/10, it is great game, i love the story.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Mass Effect 2 is a great sequel to an equally impressive game. While I do believe that this second installment is a bit over-praised, it is still an incredible game that builds on the successes of its predecessor very well.I do believe that most components of the combat system are improved. The only small detail that I don't personally enjoy is a matter of personal preference and doesn't really bother me, as it is present in most shooters anyways. The visuals are obviously much more impressive as well and make an impact on immersion in this case. Overall, the gameplay mechanics have been vastly improved as far as fluidity and functionality.What truly matters when evaluating this title, however, is the narrative and the ability of the game to make you care about its characters and its stories. While I personally believe that the first Mass Effect did a better job of making the player care about each and every character and his or her story, Mass Effect 2 still retains the important features that characterize the NPCs and make the story memorable and cannot be criticized for a lack of story; my personal opinion shouldn't have an impact on the validity and inspiration of the title. The fundamental RPG elements of Mass Effect 2 make it stand above virtually any other RPG on the market today.Mass Effect 2 is an amazing game and is undoubtedly a must-own title.

												An absolutely beautiful game that ran well even on my old PC, despite such beautiful graphics.In combat you control a squad of 2 other people, from a pool of recruitable companions who have their own strengths and backstories. The combat is basically an FPS game with some "magic" abilities in the form of biotics and tech, which can be learned by companions by leveling up and spending talent points.The graphics are so great, that I did not want to use any of the free armor in the deluxe edition, because they cover Shepard's face and ruined the immersion.The sounds of the game are also great. The disco music of the first night club that you go to really sounds disco-ish.The cut scenes and voiced conversations are great. I actually look forward to talking to people because the conversations are interesting.The main story and the mini-stories of your party members are very well done.The game makes you feel like you are in a sci-fi movie. It is a "sensory overload" to your eyes an

content:
Posted: March 25
 "Playing Mass Effect 2 is 100 times better than watching a movie."  Mass Effect 2 (ME2) is the sequel to the amazing Mass Effect (ME1). In Mass Effect 2, you play as Commander Shepard and recruit 12 powerful squad members (2 from DLCs) in your team to fight against the enemies. Compared to ME1, the features in ME2 have been tremendously improved and polished. Since I have played ME1, expect to find a few comparisons in this game review. The Good- Breathtaking cinematic cutscenes (So many feelings and goosebumps)- Beautiful music (More goosebumps)- Skippable conversations- Character and armor customization - Great story, unforgettable ending- Additional squad members (badass, mysterious, crazy, and funny individuals)- Same ammo used for all weapons (except heavy weapons)- Improved HUD screen and power wheel- Squad movements associated with key bindings (no more via HUD)- Enemies protections are color coded (barrier - purple, shields - yellow, armor and health red)- Space/Galaxy exploration- Progress status on space exploration- Interesting dialogs (Some of them are funny)- Shorter loading time- Purchasable mementos and pets for your cabin- No more annoying elevators- Two mini-puzzle to unlock research and credits  - Any classes can hack now (not only techies)- A few intense time limited missions- Missions can be continued after finishing the main plot- Pursue a romantic relationship- In-depth encyclopedia (Codex)- Arrow pointer in map- Tutorial at the start of the game- Introduction to newer species (Drell, Batarians, Vorcha) and creatures- Variety of alien species and enemies- Emphasize teamwork- Access to Cerberus Network (You'll get extra weapons, armor, missions and one more squad member)The Okay- Fewer skills/abilities (but it is fine since you have many squad members) - Weapons stats no longer exist (but weapons can be made stronger via research)- Specific weapons for specific classes (e.g. Infiltrator cannot use assault rifle) (but preferable than those in ME1 where weapon’s accuracy was affected)- Difficulty in reaching level 30 (possible if ME1 character is imported, completed all missions and DLCs, or continue a new game after first playthrough)The Bad - Other expensive DLCs (you'll need Bioware points to purchase them)- DLCs not sold in Steam - Mako missions replaced with probes- Possible wastage on buying probes and fuel (I did)- Scanning planets could be dull and repetitive over time- No running, only sprinting- The "Press 'F' to Finish Mission" blocked the dialog wheel- Failure to connect to Mass Effect 2 server error (popped up every single time after starting the game)Overall, the good outweighs the bad in Mass Effect 2. If you are a fan of Mass Effect or if you love action role-playing, sci-fi adventure and exploration, then this game is for you. Mass Effect 2 will definitely be one of the games where you will cherish the feel good moment. You will wish to replay it in the future to experience those nostalgic moments again.  Note: Be prepared to feel empty after you have finished playing this game because I do. A tip for those who are reading until this far, pay a visit to Uranus and launch a probe if you have not already.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20
												Just like with it's predecessor, Mass Effect 2's strong suit is the story, however this time around, the story telling and presentation have been upped quite a bit. Everything feels a lot more cinematic and dialog animations feel more organic than they did in ME1. Granted, there isn't that much that drives the overall plot of this trilogy forward. You essentially just gather a group to do your suicide mission with, which doesn't even really accomplish that much as a whole. It basically serves as a build up for ME3. However what will stick with most people are the multitude of characters you'll meet along the way, most with their own backstories and quests. Just like with ME1, I'd say that the best part of the game is just talking to other characters and enjoying the scenery.The combat and leveling system has changed quite a bit, in some ways for the better, not so much in others.The awkward and clunky combat of ME1 has been replaced with a relatively standard 3rd person shooting system. Think of it as "Gears of War with skills".The leveling system has been quite stripped down. You no longer level up things such as weapon accuracy or Charm/Intimidation. Now all you level up are your skills. Whether or not this is a good thing is up to you. I kinda liked the more intricate system of ME1 but I understand why they changed it. It makes things simpler and not having to level up accuracy means that weapons feel less clunky to use from the get go.However as a whole, I'm still not a huge fan of the combat system. Sure, most guns and skills are mos satisfying to use, but just like Gears of War, most scenarios devolve into a sluggish cover war, where you take peak shots from the same piece of cover until all enemies in your sight dead. This is especially true if you're playing on higher difficulties. It just slows down the pace of the game. It's also kind of a shame, because some stages have interesting level design, but you only really make use of maybe 5-10% of a room during a fight.So, just like with ME1, combat is a means to get you forward in the otherwise enjoyable story of this game. But it is probably more servicable in doing so than ME1 was.Overall, I'd absolutely recommend this game if you at the very least enjoyed ME1's story and want to experience more of the Mass Effect universe. If you hated ME1's combat system, you might actually get some more enjoyment out of this game.I do however highly recommend that you actually play ME1 first, as this is a direct continuation and not a whole lot gets explained to you. Also, you can import a completed ME1 save file into this game and have all of your choices affect this game, creating an overall more personal experience.

content:
Posted: February 12
												Yet another EPIC game from bioware, and the second installment of the Mass Effect Series, just as epic, if not moreso, as the first. Choices still matter,and you see some of your choices from the first game making big and little waves in your story; actions matter, who lives, who dies, who do you save....I only have 33.4 hours on steam with this game, but over 100 on Origin (more DLC available on origin). This game along with the first are beyond amazing, this second installment is much darker than the first game.  The Reapers are back, only this time they're using the mysterious Collectors instead of the Geth, whole human colonies are vanishing without a trace, no signs left behind, no struggle, nothing.  Its up to you, to find out why/how and put a stop to it.You have new companions, with returning faces, and a whole other side of the universe to explore and tame.I recommend this game whole heartedly, the graphics hold up to the test of time, the decisions still matter, and it still hits you right in the feels, and keeps on delivering with an epic stoy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												This is one of my favorite games of all time. The story and characters were great and so was the gameplay. I liked that you had to assemble your team and improve them in order for you and your team to survive the final mission. This has to be my favorite game in the Mass Effect trilogy. I would recommend playing all 3 of these games in order and importing your save each time if you really want to enjoy this. Mass Effect 2, like the rest of the trilogy, has great replay value and you can easily play it for hours. BioWare games always have a great story and Mass Effect 2 is no exception. I had previously owned all 3 of these games on PS3 but had to buy them again for the PC because they are just so good. Mass Effect was the first RPG I had really played and since then I have gone on to enjoy others. I would strongly recommend starting here if you are used to action games and want tho get into RPGs or just enjoy sci-fi. I would also recommend this to any RPG fan because it is a great RPG with an immersive sci-fi universe with an interesting backstory and memorable characters.

Mass Effect 2, like the rest of the trilogy, has great replay value and you can easily play it for hours. BioWare games always have a great story and Mass Effect 2 is no exception. I had previously owned all 3 of these games on PS3 but had to buy them again for the PC because they are just so good. Mass Effect was the first RPG I had really played and since then I have gone on to enjoy others. I would strongly recommend starting here if you are used to action games and want tho get into RPGs or just enjoy sci-fi. I would also recommend this to any RPG fan because it is a great RPG with an immersive sci-fi universe with an interesting backstory and memorable characters.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
WOW!Story:Let me start off by saying that this was the first Mass Effect I've ever played(Yes, I regret not buying ME1), it was simply beautiful in so many ways! I've seen other reviews for this game, and I gotta say - It actually is completely story-driven. Sure, there is gameplay, but mostly cutscenes, and that was suited well for this game. The optional character progression in "Loyalty Missions" provide extra play time, getting to know the people you recruit, gaining their trust & their respect. All in all, the story takes turns & provides new enemies to come in contact with.Soundtrack:I love the electric-orchestral vibes Mass Effect 2 brings to the table with its soundtrack! Every soundtrack definitely fits the mood for what's happening in that current situation, truth be told. The sound of electric synths with bashing drums really gets you in the mood for destroying those damn Reapers!Characters:I absolutelyLOVE each character that you recruit/meet. I couldn't seem to find a flaw in any of them, each character is written so well!1.MordinThe smarty pants of the crew, very cute as well, he learns mostly about each species he's around. As you continue through the story, he will help you with Armor, Weaponry, and squad upgrades - as well as your enemies information. Mastered in Biotics/Support.2.Garrus:Let's start off by saying that I do know Garrus was in Mass Effect 1, and meeting him in Mass Effect 2 was a huge suprise for the players. Anyways, he's pretty much the badass good-guy of the group. Caring, understandable, and pretty much down to earth savior! Mastered in Snipering.3.Miranda:My second favorite squad mate in this game, really really interesting, as well as her accent! Her excellent shot & biotic powers are damn good. Cerberus Officer for the win! Mastered in Leadership/Biotics.4.Thane:Quiet & swift, like the night, he prays before he takes the kill & afterwards as he lays down his enemies body. Thane is truly a poetic character, the vibes that come from his life makes you think how much will power you'd need in order to survive such events as he did. Mastered in Support/Snipering.4.Grunt:Brutal & large, this huge Krogan has a taste for violence & bloodlust. He joins Commander Shepard to satisfy his love for violence & to redeem himself as a true Krogan! Mastered in Fighting/Battle.5.Legion:However you firstly see it as an enemy, t provides very useful information to help stop the Collectors from defeating Humanity. Just becareful what it does around Tali, you must have high enough Paragon/Renegade to have successful cooperation between the two. Mastered in Hacking/Engineering.6.Tali:Such a sweetheart, very religious & royal. Tali is a long time friend from Mass Effect 1, as you meet her early on in Mass Effect 2, she will state that she cannot help you at that very moment. Later in the story, you must work together to fight the Collectors. Mastered in Engineering.7.Jack:Seen as a huge threat to the squad at first, but gradually they get used to her. Jack's attitude rides from stealing, killing for fun, to fighting with Commander Shepard. Dark past with this character, very saddening. Becareful how she re-acts to Miranda, you must have high enough Paragon/Renegade to have successful cooperation between the two. Mastered in Major Biotics.8.Jacob:"I'm good Shepard, ready for anything, if we win, we'll get loud, spill some drinks on the Citadel!" Ah, I love Jacob. He's my favorite squad mate, truth be told. Some people dislike him for his doubtful attitude, but I've seen through that, and if you get his loyalty, he's pretty much your best friend in Mass Effect 2! Mastered in Leadership/Support.Voice Acting:The VAing for Mass Effect 2 is pretty awesome, I noticed some familiar voices from other video games, which was a great suprise, honestly. The only complaint I have about the VAing is that sometimes the voice does-not match the character's facial expression. But I assume that's an engine problem, not a big deal.Conclusion:I gotta say, this was an amazing experience, definitely pulls on your heart strings as well!(EDIT), Woopsie, forgot Samara. She's a very useful & royal biotic trained killer!10/10. ♥

content:
Posted: December 10, 2012
												Mass Effect 2 continues from where ME1 ended, importing your character and decisions made into the second game, or allowing you to make an entirely new Commander Shep. The graphics are better, the gameplay is more fluid, and the storyline and decision making has (somehow, I'm not quite sure how considering the excellence of the first in the series) also improved. I'd consider this game marginally better than the first and, considering I gave the first an A+, that tells you something about how much I like this game.Pros:Did what Mass Effect 1 did betterCons:Not many, although itemization still wasn't done quite rightA great series any gamer should play. A+

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Bioware Sci-fi Masterpiece. Monte uma equipe de humanos e aliens pra trazer ao fim mais uma vez a ameaça dos Reapers, em um universo rico e vasto, com uma das crews mais carismáticas dos games. Pra mim a maior força do ME2 é porque diferente do primeiro ele não precisa introduzir o universo novamente, e ele se foca no que a bioware sabe fazer de melhor: Personagens. Tinha tudo pra ser aquele "middle dark chapter" da franquia(como aconteceu com o Dragon Age II), mas foi muito bem equilibrado e teve um plot principal que se fechou em si mesmo, com uma ameaça real o suficiente. O jogo tbm não tem pena, e gera pra você consequências que serão carregadas por save ao ME3, por erros que você cometeu, ou decisões erradas tomadas. Pra mim o melhor da série, e com certeza um dos melhores jogos de todos os tempos.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												Zaeed: One of the most powerful gang leaders in the galaxy, until he was betrayed.Legion: Completely unique hacker robot, envoy for a people exiled who want to belong.Jack: Experimented on to make her one of the most powerful biotics to exist. They weren't fun experiments. She's not happy.Grunt: He's basically indestructible, and really, really likes shooting things. He's also an adolescent, so that's fun.Jacob: Trained in the military, he's a straight up soldier. A reliable guy to have covering your back.Tali: A fragile-looking small girl in an isolation suit. She's an expert at hacking from a distance. Also, shotgunning enemies in the face.Garrus: He's a crack shot who led a team of freedom fighters against a series of gangs until he as the only one left. He also quite enjoys calibrations.Thane: An expert assassin with a terminal disease and a life of wrongs to right in the time he has left.Samara: Sworn an oath to uphold justice, she's spent hundreds of years hunting down criminals and her very deadly daughters.Kasumi: Expert thief, she's stolen things that were completely impossible to steal on numerous occasions. You've never heard of her. She likes it that way.Mordin: He is the very model of a scientist salarian. He has done things in his life that he knows were absolutely necessary, but that doesn't mean he won`t try to fix any damage he's caused.Then there's Miranda. She's genetically engineered to be perfect in every way, and it makes her life SO HARD. "Oh no, shepard" She often cries, "I am just too perfect, my life is SO HARD." Her only redeeming character trait is that 90% of the time she's on camera, the camera is focusing on the most interesting part of her character: the very tight clothing directly around her rear end.All in all, I give Mass Effect 2 an 11/12, one for every interesting companion.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Mass Effect 2 is a huge improvement over Mass Effect 1. It's adapted to appeal to a wide audience of gamers while still bringing the charm of Bioware's old-school RPGs. While Mass Effect 1 (in my opinion) feels like it could have been more if the studio had more time or budget to fully develop the different worlds which could be explored, Mass Effect 2 feels complete and gives the player satisfaction in the limits of the game. Mass Effect 2 marks an important transition of Bioware from KOTOR-esque DnD storytelling (which brought Bioware to the living room) to the new era of cinematic gameplay which can be enjoyed by anyone. TL;DR: This is the game EA wanted when they bought Bioware.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												If you liked the first Mass Effect, you will probably love this one.Pros:-You have more squad members, and each one has more depth and complexity than the original. They have personal stories and views to share, rather than exposition. A lot more character development happens, and the romances are more satisfying.-The movement and combat are much smoother.-There is more variation between the classes, making each one feel truly unique.-The weapons are varied, having different firing types and ranges, rather than just different stats in Mass Effect.Not-Pros:-The story seems to veer away from where the first game was heading. It’s still neat, but ultimately you’ll care more about the personal missions of your squad rather than the main campaign.-You need to purchase a large amount of DLC to really get the full game, especially if you want to continue to Mass Effect 3.-Thermal clips. In the first game, weapons heated up when fired, and you had to let them cool down. In this game, that mechanic has been replaced by thermal clips, which function similar to magazine in other shooters. This limits the “ammo” you have for your weapons. The old system was more fun, and made more sense from an in-universe perspective.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												10/10.Hands down the best CRPG I've played. Above and beyond Mass Effect 1. Buy it if you enjoy science fiction and engrossing stories!Yes, there's more action in Mass Effect's sequel, but with the better streamlined skill trees and in-combat control, it ties in very nicely with the overarching milieu's story and lore. And it's the story that really seals the deal here. The persistent characters, the evolution of your story and consequences from choices (arguably cosmetic, they still feel tangible to me),They took everything that worked in Mass Effect 1, pared off what didn't, and made it better. It's extremely seldom that sequels are better than the originals, but Mass Effect proves exceptions do occur.Not to be left out and this isn't intended to TMI or unncessary but merely an endorsement -- this is the second game I've played (ME1 being the first) that allows for romances that I actually participated in and enjoyed. (Note to self: I seem to play a lot of women that enjoy the company of women. Who knew?)

content:
Posted: January 7, 2013
												Another fantastic game from Bioware. Every bit as good as Mass Effect 1, if not better. The RPG system isn't quite as flexible/complex as the first one, but shooting elements are more fluid. UPDATE: Just finished playing Mass Effect 3. You can't get it here on Steam due to a tiff between EA and Valve.  If you haven't picked up any of the games, find the Mass Effect Trilogy on any of the other game stores.  As far as the game, it was fantastic as expected. Some people complained about the ending, but I though it was great and a fitting end to Shepard's story. Just be sure to download the free extended edition DLC with the expanded ending, which I think is already included if you buy the trilogy. My only gripe is the cost of the DLC.  This is one of a few game series where I actually bought all the DLC, because the game is so good, but also because they never release a "Game of the Year" edition that includes all the DLC.  For ME3, it feels like they doubled the price of DLC, but it is not as good as the ME2 DLC.  One of the DLCs costs more than I paid for the entire game, so I passed on it.  Not happy about that, but I'll just watch them on YouTube.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2010
												(Redone recommendation from scratch)The squel to Mass Effect (1)!In the sequel to Mass Effect (1) you will continue to play as Shepard from the first game (The same character if you imported him or her) on a new quest.This time around though you will notice something almost immediately; Combat has changed!Now the game has changed around more to a cover based shooter compared to what the first game was (I mean, there WERE some cover based shooting in the first, but now its radically different) and also you are now using limited ammunition.Some people welcomed this change, some didn't. I personally am still on the fence about the changes to combat.But its quicker, more actionny than ever. Also you can only use one power at once since other powers will be put on cooldown once you activate a power (In the first game you could maybe use 8 powers at once but had maybe a minuter cooldown).The question is though, is it fun? Oh hell yes, the combat is fun. It also makes it more interesting trying other classes and trying out different choices in the first game in order to see what will change in the second game.Storytime eh? Yeah yeah.This time Shepard will be summoned by the corporation "Cerberus" and is tasked to find out why an alien race called the "Collectors" are kidnapping humans, so its up to you to find a new crew on you voyage amongst the stars and find out the grim truth about the kidnapping of humans...One thing is sure; this game is more grim than the first and third game. No dance on flowers here.While the story to me is not good as the first but the interactions with the crew and characters keeps this game going. They also cut out the unnecessarily exploration bits (Love it or hate it) and major loot collecting has been removed entirely (Although you can do some cool research/upgrades in your lab).**And yes,i need to put this into here; Mass Effect 3 mini-review!**Mass Effect 3 is the last game in the Mass Effect Trilogy. While the combat was the best out of the three (According to me), the story took a major backlash thanks to the ending.But, while the ending in the third game is absolotely horrible i can tell you one thing; The journey is a good one.The sad truth though is that if you want to play Mass Effect 3 you have to buy it elsewhere than on Steam...

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												I'm a big fan of BioWare games, and Mass Effect 2 does not disappoint when it comes to great gameplay, awesome characters and a plot I can have fun with.  I played Mass Effect 2 the most out of the three games in the IP, because it has so much replay value.  Taking Shepard through different choices, or experiencing companions in different lights, be it romantic or just friends, you learn more and more each time you play.  The Mass Effect world itself is all I could ask for in a sci-fi setting.  There are not enough games like this series, and this game specifically is still my favorite of the bunch.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 was the very first game I ever brought on its release day, It took me completely by surprise when the original teaser trailer was released, as I was a big fan of the first game - regardless of its issues -, I was hyped and could not wait for the sequel, when it finally arrived, It blew me away and remains strongly one of my most treasured and favourite video game experiances of all time.The Story takes place 2 years after the first game, without attempting to spoil anything, I'll keep it as brief as I can:On the far edges of space known as the Terminus, a mysterious enemy has begun abducting human colonies, there are no signs of any sort of attack, only that every man, woman and child is gone. as Commander Shepard, you must assemble the most deadliest and fearless team in the galaxy to travel through the Omega 4 Relay - a "jump-gate" in which no one has returned after using- and take the fight to this new enemy, the chances of survival are slim. A Suicide Mission.Whilst Mass Effect 1 had you travel through civilized communities throughout the galaxy, Mass Effect 2 takes you into its dark underbelly, where crime, slave trade, corruption, mercenaries and drug trafficking run rampant and freely with no ill will on the criminals part. This gives the galaxy a more intimidating feel as you travel to recruit many of the Soldiers, Scientists and Mercenaries that will assist you throughout the game.Of course, recruiting people for a Suicide Mission isn't as easy as it may sound, Missions in this game are nicely structured and area enviroments give each mission a differant feel, what makes the missions so fun is the revamped combat system and classes, combat feels satisfying, reliable and fun and the differant player classes are reason enough to replay the game, Soldiers and Vanguards are seriously a blast to play with.Everything you do in the game is building up to the Final Mission, throughout the game a sense of foreboding looms around you as you get one step closer to passing through the Omega 4 Relay, in which everyone on your ship may not return from, as your decisions throughout the game will have impact upon Suicide Mission.A highlight of this game is that each crew member has their own loyality mission, your crewmate will ask for your assistance to help resolve a past, or present issue, allowing you to bond with said crewmate and learn what makes them who they are and how they tick, the assasin character is more than just an ruthless killer, the scientist is more than just a book worm.DLC is also some of the best I have ever seen in a game, the Cerberus Network houses free Downloadable mission packs and even some bonus weapons, there are some priced DLC but all is worth picking up, if you can only choose one, Lair of the Shadow Broker.All the praising I give this game, there are only 4 issues I have with it.Weapon selection feels very limiting, alot of the customisation was removed, streamlining the experiance for better or worse, without DLC packs, you have pretty much 2 choices for each gun type (Save for 5 heavy weapon choices) with a powerful version you can obtain later on in the game.Although extremely rare, it is possible to get stuck in the enviroment, but this does not happen often enough to ruin or tarnish the experiance.Where Mass Effect 1 was fair in its Renegade and Paragon options, this game might as well force you to be one or the other, as I don't see this much as a spoiler, but I would say it is mandatory to be pure hero, or pure badass.The last point I can make a paragraph about:Do I recommend this to those that haven't played the first game?No. Alot of the revelations that will occur in the game will not go over strongly with you if you havent played the first in the series, I would strongly recommend that even with Mass Effect 1s problems, you push through it, as your decisions in the first game will be carried over into Mass Effect 2, making the story feel so much more personal to you and you alone.With all that said, Mass Effect 2 is an astonishing achievement, Winning over 90 awards and Game of the year 2010, It's graphics still impress me making the aliens and the galaxy around you feel so alive and real, The soundtrack is superb with special mention going to Suicide Missions theme itself, it's fast, fun combat with class based powers is vastly entertaining and story grips me each and every playthrough, if Mass Effect 2 isn't my favourite game of all time, it's Top 3 for sure.They say it's a suicide mission, you should prove them wrong.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Mass effect 2 is by far one of the greatest games ever created. From story and gameplay to the amazing musical score and action packed sequences, Mass effect 2 is truely a game that rivals any other title in its generation. Mass effect 2 brings the best of the mass effect franchise to the table and completely immerses the player into its universe. From the opening scenes to the ending credits the player remains engaged right through till the end. It remains in my mind as well as in many others the best sci-fi space opera on the market as well as the best mass effect title in the series. With great companions and amazing voice talent the game pushes the boundaries in story telling and allows the player to make his or her own decisions as well as leaves them with the consequences of their actions. While some players may argue that the lack of customizeable weapons in this game takes away from the rpg experience, i would have to disagree. While customizing may be a part of an rpg i think that many gamers would agree what makes a great video game is a fantastic immersive story. The writing in this game takes you through the highs and the lows and makes you feel about the characters and what is happening in the universe, and thats something i cant say for a lot of games. If you are looking at this game and thinking about picking it up i will save you the trouble...BUY IT!! Though i havent really played the game on the pc yet, i have played each game multiple times on the consoles and look forward to my pc experience with the franchise.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Very nearly the full kiloI enjoyed Mass Effect 1 but was only able to give it 3/5 due to some pretty annoying flaws. I’m glad to say that most of those flaws have been eradicated in ME2. Gone are the endless slow elevator rides. Gone are the tedious, bouncy buggy rides on dull, lifeless planets. And gone is the ridiculously complex HUD. What hasn’t changed are its strong points, which remain in the storyline and RPG elements. Once again there is a detailed and compelling story along with many side plots and missions, which are more diverse and creative than those in ME1. The voice acting is excellent throughout as are the character models and animations, which are fluid and naturalistic. Graphically it’s very good for a four-year-old game, although there’s little in the way of physics, which is a shame. The combat has also improved, although it remains rather clunky and lacklustre compared to other games. The Mass Effect franchise is clearly about providing a rich and developed universe in which to place the player and to give that player a full-bodied RPG experience peppered with combat and action along the way. And in this respect ME2 really delivers. If not for the so-so combat I would have given it 5/5, but as it is I give it 4/5.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												The gameplay is little bit different than the first Mass Effect but the storyline just as good. Many new interesting NPCs in addition to recurring characters from the first game. The missions are more interesting than the previous series because the levels are better defined compared to ME 1 where the interior of any building looks very similar.There is wider selection of squad members so you can employ many different tactics according to a mission's need. The squad members also have unique personalities and history that they can share with you, given you spend some time to talk to them. The loyalty missions, squad members confrontation with each other and romance really adds flavour to the game. Squad members can die in the final mission (dubbed as the Suicide Mission) resulting from failing to secure their loyalty, not making ship upgardes or choosing non-ideal person for a task in the mission. This forces the player to carefully plan and prepares for the mission. The were so many different way the game progress and ends, even the main character may be killed in the suicide mission. This gives the game a very high replay value and the player did get a bonus to the character and resources should we choose start a new game after finishing one. Overall, Mass Effect 2 is a story rich game that continues the greatness of the first game. If you want to play the game, I suggest you finish ME1 first and carry forward your character into this game. Forget about wikis and walkthrough (except when you completely stuck of course) and just follow your heart and be yourself when making decision throughout the game and you will find out the Commander Shepard you're playing really reflects the person you are (Paragon and Renegade choices). You always can play it again later if you want to experience another options that you missed before, or choosing different character to romance or whatever different options the game can offer. But remember, the outcome of the decisions can be carried to Mass Effect 3. For score, I'm giving ME2 a solid 9/10

content:
Posted: October 24, 2011
												Belated review. Refer to my previous recommendation for Mass Effect 1 for general thoughts on the series (short version: get it). Continuing on that, Mass Effect 2 takes everything that was great about ME1 and makes it better, and at the same time completely fixes everything that was wrong. It's the perfect sequel. The only slight misstep in ME2 is the tedious planet mining mechanic. But aside from that, I really have no complaints about this game at all. It's an absolute must-play if you have any interest in the upcoming ME3. One of the coolest aspects of the series is that all of the choices you made in ME1 carry through to ME2, and will further carry through to ME3... and there are many choices to be made. It becomes a very personalized game. I should also mention that there are a number of DLC missions available as well, which are worth checking out (especially the last one). And with that, I shall say no more, as this is a game that must be played, not written about.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												A highly anticipated sequal to the genre-defining excellence of Mass Effect, we have Mass Effect 2. I may be some filthy casual with a love for choices, RPGs, and hot pixelated women - but damn it, this is my review!Ahem.Mass Effect 2 continues where Mass Effect left off, leaving Shepard in a rough position between those who are hesitant to believe his claims and that of a rise in human political power. Taking things into his own hands, Shepard is required to find a new crew - and embark on a mission that could very well be his last.The gameplay is streamlined from the previous, enjoyable, though with its own shortcomings. The shooting is perhaps a bit more fine tuned, not that the first really warranted much issue. The addition of ammunition makes for a more traditional shooter feel, which I didn't mind - seeing as how it's explained in the very first loading screen (though I have a couple questions). The only downside really is the large departure from Abilities in place of Shooting. Classes sucha s the Sentinel and the [Insert other Tech class here that isn't the stealth class] feels a bit unloved, and even Vanguard seems to have been lacking its zeal.The soldier and the stealth class lead in this game, it seems - given their weapon-natures and ability to dish out the love with many of them. Playing as a Vanguard through all three games, ME2 seemed to have the least options for my progression.Having said that, I'm a sucker for character development, and I really appreciated the handling of many of the Mass Effect characters. Some have a traditional 'you helped me, I love you know' mentality - whereas others feel more real. Jack seems to really soften, though I've never gone through with a romance with her. The relationship you can build with one of the previous crewmates is rewarding as she didn't just pounce on you in the first game after you punched your locker in anger for saying nice things to her. She has a developed character, and I doubt my restraint in using the name really fools anyone.I'd try to continue, but I've typed enough. Buy the game, play it. If you hate it, damn son - that's hard. If you love it, then we probably share some opinions on Sci-Fi and RPGs.Was it a worthy sequel to ME1? I'd say so. It may focus more on action, so if that makes it Gears of Halo, then I guess it's a good thing I never saw it that way. The exploration is reduced in favor of a more freeform progression with a number of characters and personal options. If I had to choose, I'd say ME2 was probably my least favorite installment in the entire series - however, that's hardly an insult.(Yes, ME3 was a fantastic game - minus the last six minutes or so of the game. But my opinion on the need for the Dark Energy ending is an entire matter entirely.)

content:
Posted: March 4
												The story in this game is good, but the gameplay is what kills it for me. The areas you venture through are basically point A to point B with a maybe one or two different ways of getting there. The environment looks cool and all, and the game does a great job of looking like a futuristic world, but you can't help but feel like you're in a hallway that leads you to your goal. Which is fine, but at least give me a few ways of getting there. The main reason I can't recommend this game is the gameplay. While the story, voice acting, and dialogue are all great - the gameplay is lacking. Firefights are just tedious and boring. I usually use the sniper to take out the idiot enemies further back, then the pistol or assualt rifle for the ones closer up. Still the combat is so dull and unchallenging. I'm sure it probably gets better later on in the game, but I'm over 6 hours in, and it just isn't doing it for me. The squad abilities are cool and all, but the fact that you can finish almost all firefights without using them at all lets you do just that. So the abilities end up being flash instead of a necessity. There are little things that bug the hell out of me. For example if you decide to switch to the sniper rifle, but accidentally click on the grenade launcher, you have to switch to the GL and then switch to the sniper rifle. Even thought the game is basically paused, you can't cancel your mis-click and re-click on the weapon you wanted to switch to. Then the AI on the enemies isn't the greatest. They'll stand near the edge of cover, and you can easily shoot them. But instead of moving away to protect themselves they just keep taking fire until they poke out to shoot or die. Also, they pop out to shoot on a timer it seems like. The enemy AI is so predictable it takes away any difficulty.The game is positively received by most, so you should probably give it a shot anyways. But I just wanted to share my opinion. Personally I dislike the game, but that doesn't make it a bad game. The story, voice acting, characters, environment, are all great, but the gameplay leaves me bored.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												I played this game a lot when I was younger (like, A LOT), so I returned to see if it's still is like the old times, and boy if it isn't. This is one of the few games I have next to no complaints about. - The graphics are beautiful, possibly better than some games that come out today - The combat is exciting with the big arsenal and variety of powers- All characters are interesting, especially your squad members; they are not just hollow shells that follow you around, they are actually people you begin to care about, and your decisions decide whether or not they will remain loyal to your cause- Dialogue is simple, but effective, and actually feels like you're talking to people, not just some NPC- The space travel aspect is awesome- There are so many alien races to interact with- THE ♥♥♥♥ING CODEXI can't say anything about the story, since I haven't really completed it yet, but I am definitely liking it so far.So yeah, buy this game.

												/A great sequel to the original Mass Effect with several returning characters and more. Several new guns, and even greater graphics. Stellar voice acting and unique characters. However fans of the entire trilogy will agree that this was beginning of the DLC-itis affecting the series and also in the grand scheme of the whole trilogy's story, a stepping stone and a chance to bring new characters. Also you'll see some of the choices are slightly less "morally grey area", but still retains the spirit of the Mass Effect. Several RPG elements of the game are somewhat sacrificed, some for better, some for worse but overall, the experience and impact of your decisions make this a very very very entertaining game. 9/10.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												Completely disregarding all of the awful DRM stuff and bad UI overhaul, I've composed a list of reasons why this game sucks, as compared to the first one. The intro starts with 2 characters talking who you don't care about, nor will you ever Then your ship explodes, in no way advancing the plot because they just bring you back Everyone pretends that you didn't just spend the entire last game fighting the evil Cerberus corporation Commander Shepard actually gets a conversation option saying "What's Cerberus?" Shepard, despite being a spectre, takes orders from some guy you don't care about Everyone conveniently forgets about the reapers or anything that happened last game Jacob, Ashley, and The Illusive Man are completely useless characters plot-wise When you actually do make a decision, it doesn't matter. (see: Shepard demanding he doesn't want AI on the ship) Hacking minigames are actually skill-less matching games now AMMO, despite having ammo-less guns in the original Can't change equipment unless at a specified place to do so Psionics are now worthless Teammates are now less valuable than ever before Fewer, and less humorous, Elcor New spiky-teethed race of aliens shoehorned in, conveniently immune to all diseases which doesn't make sense, biologically speakingAll-in-all, you'll find yourself skipping dialogue and cut-scenes for the first 3 hours of this game because no one says anything useful or interesting with an awful UI and key-bindings that has "Use" and "Sprint" bound to the same key, poor optimization, over-burdening DRM, and just all-around ♥♥♥♥♥♥ness in what was otherwise a perfect game previously.In all fairness, I haven't finished the game yet, but it's not about the destination, it's about the journey, and if they journey's rubbish, how good can the destination really be?

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Quite possibly the very best game experience I've ever had. This is, however, due in large part from playing ME1 first and establishing history in both the game and within myself. The first was great too, but there were certain aspects about it that made it boring and/or frustrating at times. For example, combat was too short. The skills in teh game are designed for more of a prolonged battle to use flanking techniques and weapon strength mixtures... that sort of thing. In other words, battles could be fun, but it was rarely long enough to fully enjoy and the time between battles was quite long in lots of cases. Inventory was a constant burden as well, which also took away lots of enjoyable play time. Others might say it was too boring, but role playing games are simply more designed around a story. And this story of Mass Effect is absolutely wonderful. That said, they fixed the inventory and leveling problem completely in ME2, as well as the lack of combat. Add an extension the story that got even more eipc and you have what I believe has been my best gaming experience ever.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												First Review in my career.  I have more like 60 hours as the internet went out for a while as oppossed to the 40+ that is shown.  I have played through the game 2 times once (and most recently) as a male Shepard and another as a female Shepard.  Copnstructive critism is wlcome as well as advice because I plan to review some of the other games I have.  So please, enjoy.   Disputably, this is the superior game in the Mass Effect Series.  Personally I hold this opinion, but do NOT just buy this game.  In order to get totally immersed in the story and develop connections to the characters, purchase the original Mass Effect and possibly Mass Effect 3 (but use Origin at your own peril).  The story itself is extremely engaging.  Traveling the galaxy and assembling a suicide squad is interesting as each character is found in different places and missions associated with the character's loyalty to you are also unique.  I never once came across a moment when I thought "I've seen this before".  While enemies are mild repeats (you will be fighting armored aliens, sheilded ones, boss ones, and various types of mechs), the NPCs are always very interesting even if they are flat.  The role-playing aspects of the game are handled well.  When starting the game, you can choose between 6 different types of combat styles which range from being a pure biotic (using magic), an infiltrator (turning invisible), and being a soldier (regular combat grunt/bad***).  Each of those classes have 5 upgradable abilities that either give you interesting ammo mods or special attacks like slamming a person to the ground or turning invisible for a short time.  On top of that once you chose your character class, you can select another special ability from a list.  Every time you level up, you recieve one point for spending it on abilities.  Initially, all of them cost 1 point and once they are upgraded, they incriment (go up) by 1.  At the end of the skill bar for each skill you can chose a significant bonus ability.  For an ammo mod, this could be giving yourself an upgraded form of it or allowing your entire squad to partake in it.  The latter thing I find most useful because I tend to hang back and pick off enemies from range and let my squand soak up most of the enemy fire.  Speaking of combat, I love this 3rd-person style.  It leans heavily on cover and utilizing the abilities of your allies.  You can direct your 2 squad members simply pressing a key (one per member).  To use your abilities and your squad member's, you hold down a button and select the ones you wish to use.  Your team can deploy at most 3 separate abilities (one per person).  Aside from that, regular combat with guns is point, aim, shoot.  You can hold a maximum of 6 guns, however this depends on which class you pick in the beginning.  The adept class doesn't even carry weapons while the soldier can hold all 6.  You can have a sniper rifle, assult rifle, shotgun, speical weapon (missile launcher,mini-nuke launcher, etc), pistol, and submachine gun.  Acquring of these weapons range from finding them in levels, recieving them, and making them. There is melee combat, but it is rather sloppy.  If you were to use it (which I don't) you leave yourself open to enemy fire which will destory you if you aren't in cover even on the easiest difficulty.  The enemy A.I. is capable of flanking, putting down suppressive fire, and charging indescriminantly, so it always keeps you on your toes.  Sometimes the enemies get stuck behind obstacles, but the pathing for them are solid.  They use cover and can go through your suad members quickly.  The graphics are exceptional even for a game from 2010.  The textures are good, but in combat it really shines.  The laser beams, mass-effect bullets, and ammo mods are a sight to behold when they are flying everywhere.  The sounds are also good.  The soundtrack is also pretty good.  The place where this game falls short is the map system.  Like from the previous game, you travel across the galaxy using Mass Relays.  That is carrried over, but the actual physical exploration of planets and moons from the previous installment is scraped in favor of a mining minigame which is tedious to do for an extended period of time.  It is also worthwhile though as the resources you get from mining is used for upgrades which are found in the course of missions and from purchashing them.  The upgrades are rather significant improvements which range from increased damage to reduced cooldowns to even additional equipment for the ship.  I highly recommend consulting your team for ship upgrades because they will make the difference between life and death in the late game.  Some do cost a lot of stuff, so you will get aquainted with the mining monstrosity.  However, this is overshadowed by the characters you interact with.  While I briefly went over this in the beginning, I feel I must describe how great it is.  Every character on your ship have a story, opinions, and remarks about your progress.  And yes, the infamous romance options are back and "better" than ever.  I will let you explore them to see for yourself because I have not explored them yet.  The lore is wonderfully explained to you through the codex, accessable via the pause menu.  As you interact with more things, the condex articles explain everything.  Overall, I give this game a 9 out of 10.  The strong character customization/upgrading system teamed with the strong graphics, good teamwork elements, and the immaculate NPC collection are what make this game a must-own for Sci-Fi fans.   If you are bored by generic first-person shooters and want a more engaging combat system, this is a good game to look into.  I know that there is a multiplayer to the game as well, but I have not exlpored it.  I would suggest skipping it.  To me, this is a single-player experience through and through. So long and good luck.

content:

												I compare every game against the Mass Effect trilogy. The Mass Effect games are the centerpiece of my gaming experience. Mass Effect 2 is simply beautiful. It has an incredbile story and some great memorable characters. If you played Mass Effect 1, you're experience in this game will be riveting. It's rare for a game to suck me into it's story, Mass Effect 2 deliveries on that front. The gameplay has some improvements over the original Mass Effect, and that's saying a lot. The gameplay experience is somewhat more intuitive and the freedom you enjoy in terms of your choices is very satisfying. The combination of action and RPG are a great balance. It's been a few months since I completed this game and I'm still pondering some of the decisions I made.Mass Effect 2, and the entire trilogy for that matter, will provide you with some of the best experiences a gamer can ask for.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Mass Effect 2 is a masterpiece. It features some of the best combat, interesting missions and by far one of the biggest and most compelling stories that has ever been told in a video game. From the original they continued the story of Commander Shepard and his/her role in one of the biggest sci-fi universes ever seen. The game instantly sets out being darker than the previous game with the immediate destruction of the Normandy and Shepards death. Fortunately Shepard is reconstructed pro-human organisation Cerberus. They outfit Shepard with a new crew, a new ship and one mission. Deal with the Collectors.Without spoiling the story the adventure you go on is full of thrills, twists and moral choices that you can make, and an elaborate dialogue selection that influences the story. There are numerous interesting characters to meet on the way who join your crew, each with their own background and personality, including the return of Garrus, Tali, Joker and Dr Chakwas to the crew from the first game. The combat is extremely engaging and creating a new game upon the completion of an old save is worth it just to choose a new class an experience battle in a different way. The inventory and weapon management has been improved since the first game and it is now much more fun to use biotics and tech powers. There is so much to this game it is hard to express in a small review so I shall use this closing statement.A legend that you craft. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												The controversy with EA and Mass Effect 3 being an Origin exclusive when that program was getting considerable bad press for spyware and peeking into people's computers remains a bitter memory for me. It went from my #1 wishlist item to becoming the first and most trying test of my resolve to never buy anything from EA again. I still have never played Mass Effect 3 because of it, and might not ever because of other issues that that game had. Though... not having played that allowed me to be insulated from ME3's ending, which♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥a huge number of fans of this series off enough that it led to Bioware redoing the ending (a bit).What does all this have to do with my opinion on ME2 do you ask? Well, it's important because it points out that I ended the series with ME2, and therefore cannot make a review of this game in context as the middle part of a trilogy, but just as the second chapter to a story that I may never finish. So how is it? Well, "#1 wishlist item" might have tipped you off to this: it is one of the best games I have ever played. Which is why that ME3 stuff bit as hard as it did for me.It is true that this game is considerably different from ME1 in its gameplay, and some don't like the loss of some "traditional" RPG elements that resulted from that. But it wasn't a real problem for me because it also got rid of much of what was wrong with ME1 and replaced it with a more solid game attached to the quality storytelling that the first game had. If there's anything bad i'd have to say about the gameplay, it's this: it plays much more like a shooter than an RPG in combat (which can be exhausting for a game this long), and whoever thought that planet scanning stuff would be fun needs to have their head examined. Preferrably with a sledgehammer. Oh and a note about how Paragon and Renegade are lame and limiting on your ability to roleplay stuff (kinda did in the first game too, but not as much).But that's it. The gameplay is solid, reasonably difficult at times, and, if you imported your save from ME1 (which you did because continuation of your specific storyline is a major selling point of this series), it makes for a great storytelling experience. This game is a smaller, more personal, story than ME1, which leads to considerable investment into the characters in your party. It's a mix of excellent characters, with a few notable standouts that probably are obvious due to their huge fanbases. And the answer to the question that just popped in your head is no. I never romanced Tali despite her being one of my favorite characters. I never played a male Shepard beyond the intro level of ME1. Come to think of it, I never romanced my favorite character (Garrus) either.And it is this focus on characters that makes the final mission of this game all the more affecting. At least the first time you play it and/or if you don't just grab a guide. Seriously, for your first go at the final mission, or really this whole game in general, don't read a guide. It will ruin it for you. And if you play it without knowing what's coming like I did, then you are likely in for one of the darkest and tragic final missions of any game out there when those party members you have spent dozens of hours getting to know and like start dying like flies. It makes the term "suicide mission" much more impactful if you go in with nine party members and walk away with only two and feeling lucky for that.And that's all i'll say about the gameplay. I think this is a great game, and even my sour feelings about ME3's various controversies did not dampen that opinion. Still, I would only play this if you went through ME1 first, because importing saves is cool. Whether or not you want to continue beyond this into ME3 depends on how high your tolerance for EA's BS is. Mine, sadly, is nonexistent.Have fun. :)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
												My favourite game (and it will stay like that for some time), Mass Effect 2 delivers a great story within this excellent RPG. I didn't really like the way the game starts and some controls are really horrible for keyboard users (sprint, cover and interaction are on the same button), but after a while it starts to become great. The game is filled with quests and manages to deliver a nice story while you're playing it. I really reccomend playing Mass Effect first, because this game imports your save file and all your important decisions with it (although you may change your appearance and class at the start of the game). Choice is again an important element of the game and it makes it into a personal experience. The combat mechanics are again pretty good and the ai is a bit smarter than in the original game. The voice acting is once again great, as well as the supporting characters whose personal storylines make the game even better.One minor flaw exept for the pc controls is that the graphics aren't always the best (low-res textures), even on the highest settings, but you need to keep in mind that the game is getting pretty old.Windows 8 users might need to use Windows xp sp3 compability mode and (if you're using it) you need to turn of Lucid Virtu MVP to play without crashes.Summary:Story: 9,7/10Gameplay: 9,5/10Graphics: 7/10Sound: 8,5/10 (+ excellent voice acting)Score: 9,8/10

Posted: November 28, 2013
												pretty decent/10i assume you're one of the types that played mass effect 1 before and not one of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that jump in mid series. why the ♥♥♥♥ would you do that, anyways? controls are solid, though if you're left handed like me and use insert, home, pgup and end for keybinds, you can't keybind i think either delete or pgdown for an ability. so that's disappointing. no weird mouse acceleration [i think. been years]ui is kinda dumb since things are so streamlined for console users. weapon switching hud feels dumb and i just want everything laid out instead of things fanning out when i hover over a gun.graphics are okay. i don't give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about mass effect graphics and neither should you. although the design for human faces look dumb. they should've worked on that.ship is really fun to explore, and so is talkin w/ my alien bros [human characters are terrible just like mass effect 1]i'm in the minority here, but i don't like how me2 is essentially gears of war in space. i rather liked the [extremely basic] rpg elements in me1, and managing inventory w/ the different types of armor and weapon and implant mods. the changes to classes is pretty great, though, and the various abilities are nice. story is meh. they hint towards some interesting things which would've been great if they had some impact in mass effect 3 but they lead to nowhere due to the♥♥♥♥♥♥writers at bioware ♥♥♥♥ing things up. speaking of which, the story for me2 is entirely pointless. the reveals and♥♥♥♥♥♥have no impact in the galaxy at large. things that should. but don't, because bioware employs middle school level fan fiction writers. also everyone has daddy issues and most of the game is focused on fixing the problems of crewmembers. which wouldn't be an issue if they didn't ♥♥♥♥ing matter in me3. nothing matters♥♥♥♥ biowareanyways, def would recommend/10, and ignore my conflicted feelings of the series. just don't pay money for me3.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Quite possibly the very best game experience I've ever had. This is, however, due in large part from playing ME1 first and establishing history in both the game and within myself. The first was great too, but there were certain aspects about it that made it boring and/or frustrating at times. For example, combat was too short. The skills in teh game are designed for more of a prolonged battle to use flanking techniques and weapon strength mixtures... that sort of thing. In other words, battles could be fun, but it was rarely long enough to fully enjoy and the time between battles was quite long in lots of cases. Inventory was a constant burden as well, which also took away lots of enjoyable play time. Others might say it was too boring, but role playing games are simply more designed around a story. And this story of Mass Effect is absolutely wonderful. That said, they fixed the inventory and leveling problem completely in ME2, as well as the lack of combat. Add an extension the story that got even more eipc and you have what I believe has been my best gaming experience ever.

Come to think of it, I never romanced my favorite character (Garrus) either.And it is this focus on characters that makes the final mission of this game all the more affecting. At least the first time you play it and/or if you don't just grab a guide. Seriously, for your first go at the final mission, or really this whole game in general, don't read a guide. It will ruin it for you. And if you play it without knowing what's coming like I did, then you are likely in for one of the darkest and tragic final missions of any game out there when those party members you have spent dozens of hours getting to know and like start dying like flies. It makes the term "suicide mission" much more impactful if you go in with nine party members and walk away with only two and feeling lucky for that.And that's all i'll say about the gameplay. I think this is a great game, and even my sour feelings about ME3's various controversies did not dampen that opinion. Still, I would only play this if you went through ME1 first, because importing saves is cool. Whether or not you want to continue beyond this into ME3 depends on how high your tolerance for EA's BS is. Mine, sadly, is nonexistent.Have fun. :)

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												Before we begin: This game is a masterpiece and one of the best games of the recent years. Huge respect for Bioware/EA for creating a Universe this rich, immersing and believable. But as with nearly all Bioware games, characters and writing from heaven meet mediocre at best gameplay, so if you're looking for an interesting gameplay experience, you're dead wrong here. This is a typical cover-based third person shooter and nothing else. But the stories it has to tell are so great that I've replayed this game over and over again and can call it my favorite game ever. Buy this game.Now I will ramble a bit about the story. While I try to keep it spoiler free, you should skip this part, if you want to start this game absolutely blind.Commander Shepard, the player-created main character from the first installment of the series, ends up working together with Cerberus, a pro-human organisation that often crosses the lines of morality to achieve what it regards as good, to stop the abduction of human colonists by a mysterious alien race called the Collectors. The games theme is darker and grittier compared to Mass Effect 1, and you're really free to handle any situation the way you want. And while you can't part from your boss, it's your choice to become a good guy or giving in to your dark side and getting the job done no matter the costs. Both sides of Shepard are so well written that he/she is easily one of the best video game characters ever.Your Party members are even better than the already very well written one from the first. And while some characters don't seem very interesting/likeable at first, digging further through their pasts unveils deep, twisted at times, personalities that bleed quality. Also they have different views and opinions about you, your employer and the mission. While some are fanatically loyal to Cerberus, others hate the organisation with the heart and soul, which leads to interesting conflicts.I'm sure you've heard about the train wreck ending of Mass Effect 3, even if you have no interest in the franchise. Well, the ending of Mass Effect 2 is absolutely fantastic. Doing side missions and upgrading your vessel really has an impact on   the outcome of the final battle, which is something great. And the way it was presented to us is so good, my jaw literally fell to the floor when I first played it.SPOILER ENDFrom the technical side, the graphics have massivly improved compared to the washed out, low-detail textures of the first game, although the overall texture resolution is really bad from time to time. The art style of the game is great and easily as memorable and immersive as Star Wars or other behemoths like that. And the fact that Bioware created a Universe that can rival franchises that feature books, movies, comics and more over three decades, just for a video game franchise is simply amazing.So buy this game if you're interested in a amazing story with the option of choice and rich, memorable characters, if you can stand yet another stereotypical third person shooter.

												Undoubtedly the most amazing game I have ever played. Breathtaking cinematics, engaging storyline, original characters. Everything about this game makes it a perfect 10/10 for me. The worst part about this game is that I didn't search every nook and cranny of the universe in order to make the game continue; I hate how it's actually over. 												The second game in my all time favourite franchise!Completed it 6 times and don't regret a thing!Continuing on from the adventures of the first, you'll encounter new enemies, meet up with old friends and make new ones to once again save the galaxy from an impending threat. content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Mass Effect 2 is a masterpiece. It features some of the best combat, interesting missions and by far one of the biggest and most compelling stories that has ever been told in a video game. From the original they continued the story of Commander Shepard and his/her role in one of the biggest sci-fi universes ever seen. The game instantly sets out being darker than the previous game with the immediate destruction of the Normandy and Shepards death. Fortunately Shepard is reconstructed pro-human organisation Cerberus. They outfit Shepard with a new crew, a new ship and one mission. Deal with the Collectors.Without spoiling the story the adventure you go on is full of thrills, twists and moral choices that you can make, and an elaborate dialogue selection that influences the story. There are numerous interesting characters to meet on the way who join your crew, each with their own background and personality, including the return of Garrus, Tali, Joker and Dr Chakwas to the crew from the first game. The combat is extremely engaging and creating a new game upon the completion of an old save is worth it just to choose a new class an experience battle in a different way. The inventory and weapon management has been improved since the first game and it is now much more fun to use biotics and tech powers. There is so much to this game it is hard to express in a small review so I shall use this closing statement.A legend that you craft. 10/10

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Mass Effect 2 is the biggest and most well made of the Mass Effect games. It is massive. Unlike in ME3, where you can only freeroam a couple of tiny spots around the Citadel, in ME2, you can free roam around massive spaces in the Citadel, Illium and Omega. I was incredibly surprised! In ME3, you have like 3 choices of where to go in  the Citadel, such as Earth Embassies, Presidium Omertia hospital and some other crap like that. In ME2, there is a massive space. Why did they leave out places like Illium?? Anyway, this review is about Mass Effect 2. THIS GAME IS HUGE! I cannot stress that enough. Following up to Mass Effect, Bioware dramatically improved the character relationship system. Your squadmates now offer loyalty missions which you can complete and they begin to trust and respect you more. I found this quite awesome. To be honest, the ME series is the only series that made me feel any sort of emotion that wasn't sadness and frustration. I enjoyed making friends with virtual aliens. I enjoyed traveling halfway around the universe to get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on by Collectors and their fancy♥♥♥♥♥indoctrinated swarms of zombies. At times, the gameplay can be very repetitive. Kill some enemies, move forward, loot bodies, hack systems ,move forward, one of your squadmates says something, move forward, kill enemies, interact with an enemy, gain paragon or renegade. kill them.That is the basic formula to most missions.I am also pleased to see that they improved on the Normandy piloting system. In ME1, the Normandy was shown as a icon. Now you can see it, you can fly around using the mouse and you can scan planets with an awesome scanner that shows you mineral readings. The storyline advances forward, introducing new friends, enemies and continuing the story of the Reapers and you stopping them.Great game, best game in the series, what more can I say?

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												So the Mass Effect series is amazing, The third Mass Effect, due to EA's continual flighty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥tting, is only available on Origin, so those of you looking for that solid 10 out of 10 (well, except for the ending) will not be finding it here.HOWEVER, I can inform you that Mass Effect 2 is still worth your time. It is relatively easy to pick up the series at this game and still know what the heck is going on without having to play the first game, which is often stated as being pretty "meh" compared to the rest of the series. Perks of this game are good character customization, the new ability to romance some of the alien crew, good combat gameplay, non-linear storytelling, excellent voice acting (especially from Femshep), and AMAZING story / lore, whether you chose to play as paragon or renegade.The gameplay great for a game from 2010, even though I now laugh at how Shepard runs in the second game (it is pretty comical). Keep in mind, though, that if you choose to play as a Sentinal (my choice in class) your raised shield matrix DOES NOT automatically activate at the beginning of combat, as it does in the third game. Make sure you do that, folks, or you are wasting class perks!The fact the storyline changes based upon Shepard's critical decisions in the game gives this game HUGE replay value and the story / avatar are importable from the first game and completed files of the second game.The main missions were excellent, but some of the necessary loyalty missions are a touch dry, but I found that Amara's and Thane's were very refreshing, especially when I got some renegade point-free oppertunities to go all badass and theaten to chop off a guy's balls and sell them to a Krogan.I may not run like a cheetah or fight like a Krogan but I sure as hell can dance, flirt, and hold my liquor better than Commander Shepard!!

I can warmly recommend this game to any that still haven't tried it.
