content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												The original Mass Effect was about the story and the setting, which was fantastic for a lore junkie. Unfortunately, the gameplay itself was somewhat slow and deliberate. Mass Effect changes all that.The story is much tighter, more focussed and personal. Your crew are fleshed out, and writing characters has ever been the strength of Bioware's team. Combat snaps from point to point, with the character being much more fragile, but also quick and active. Overall, a vast improvement.ME2 is well worth playing, even years later. A+.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												TOTALLY WORTH IT.There's a well-written storyline and plot, excellent voice acting and dialogue, tons of options and choices that actually DO make a difference, loads of colorful, well-written characters, and stunning graphics. It's worth exploring and replaying and seeing all the wonderful things that are available to you. Your choices really do affect the outcome of your game.Blast your enemies into space particles.Romance your alien crewmates.Interesting and fascinating conversations, arguments, and dialogue.Go on crazy adventures with a deep, compelling storyline.Discover each characters backstory and fall in love with the depth of every character.The attention to detail. The funny jokes the doctor tells you (or when he SINGS!)Oh and y'know guns blazing or mind powers. Pretty awesome battlefield action with your crewmates at your side spouting off catchphrases. Action, adventure, romance. IT'S LIKE PLAYING A MOVIE.It's the whole package. Go for it.GAMEPLAY 10/10STORYLINE 10/10VISUAL EFFECTS 10/10The digital deluxe version is WOOORTH IT!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 is superior in most categories of the first one. While there has been a shortage of Mako ridings, they are made up for in probing (somewhat). Elevator rides in the Citadel have been replaced with...stairs. While there is a lack of RPG elements (Micromanaging weapons, wide variety of skills to spend), the characters make up for it.  There will be some old allies along for the ride, and lots of new ones. There is a character for everyone, whether it be a crazy psycopath littered with tattoos, or a reformed avenger (among others). Action is more heavily worked on, and makes it feel better compared to the first game. Conversations have been improved on, and interventions from Shepard can take place in most situations, whether you want to push a guy off from a high building, or give him a chance to give you some answers. In conclusion, Mass Effect 2 is a great continuation in the Mass Effect series.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												Mass Effect 2 is the biggest and most well made of the Mass Effect games. It is massive. Unlike in ME3, where you can only freeroam a couple of tiny spots around the Citadel, in ME2, you can free roam around massive spaces in the Citadel, Illium and Omega. I was incredibly surprised! In ME3, you have like 3 choices of where to go in  the Citadel, such as Earth Embassies, Presidium Omertia hospital and some other crap like that. In ME2, there is a massive space. Why did they leave out places like Illium?? Anyway, this review is about Mass Effect 2. THIS GAME IS HUGE! I cannot stress that enough. Following up to Mass Effect, Bioware dramatically improved the character relationship system. Your squadmates now offer loyalty missions which you can complete and they begin to trust and respect you more. I found this quite awesome. To be honest, the ME series is the only series that made me feel any sort of emotion that wasn't sadness and frustration. I enjoyed making friends with virtual aliens. I enjoyed traveling halfway around the universe to get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥on by Collectors and their fancy♥♥♥♥♥indoctrinated swarms of zombies. At times, the gameplay can be very repetitive. Kill some enemies, move forward, loot bodies, hack systems ,move forward, one of your squadmates says something, move forward, kill enemies, interact with an enemy, gain paragon or renegade. kill them.That is the basic formula to most missions.I am also pleased to see that they improved on the Normandy piloting system. In ME1, the Normandy was shown as a icon. Now you can see it, you can fly around using the mouse and you can scan planets with an awesome scanner that shows you mineral readings. The storyline advances forward, introducing new friends, enemies and continuing the story of the Reapers and you stopping them.Great game, best game in the series, what more can I say?

content:
Posted: November 16, 2011
												Following on the heels of one of my greatest gaming experiences, Mass Effect 2 does not dissapoint. The game inetegrates decisions made in the first game in suprising ways and the story line thickens even more. The perfect analogy to compare the games of Mass Effect story-wise is the old Star Wars trilogy. ME 1 is like A New Hope, everything is new and exciting. Mass Effect 2 is The Empire Strikes Back, the story is a little darker, and more serious and things aren't what they seem to be. Old Friends have left you, Your new friends will die. Like I said, the story is one of the greatest tales I've been lucky enough to experience. A great 2nd act that sets up the end to the trilogy perfeclty.

												This game is f***ing amazing. Alright, alright. The combat basically plays like a cover shooter and the RPG elements are severely lacking. But, buuuuut. On the point of companions, the characters in this game are just great, they are excellently voice acted and by the end, hell by the middle of the game you'll feel genuinely connected to your companions. The choices made throughout this game kind of matters in the game but if you play the whole trilogy from the first Mass Effect then you'll see the real effect of your choices on the galaxy. So what are you doing reading this review, you're wasting time not playing Mass Effect 2, buy it now and save the galaxy.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Bioware seems to have perfected story writing, at least at this point in the trilogy. They lose some points for changing the control system completely from the first game, and from the stantard fps control; it would be O.K. except for laziness in not teaching the dialogues to adjust to custom controls. It hurt in a few time-sensitive, unique settings.Ammo was a big change and having the entire canon universe switch in two years is a little hard to swallow. I guess that with the addition of regenerating health, they had to make your character weaker somehow, and they dump loads more enemies on you this time around. I kind of missed how easily you could get pwned in the first one, even while I mowed down armies in this game.Dislike the shallow skillsets of the characters. Companions literally have 3 abilities, and then a bonus one after loyalty missions.These are the only problems, and literally every other part of the game is, at worst, 7/10. I rate 88/100 overall. Will probably play again.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												A solid sequel for Mass Effect 1. The story is interesting, the visuals are fantastic, and the gameplay works. I personally prefer ME1's gameplay and story over this one but it's still a game worth playing. If you're into third person shooters, this is your game. I'm not so I didn't enjoy it quite as much as Mass Effect 1. ME1 was more of an RPG than a third person shooter while here it is the opposite.----[Rating weighted based on the genre]----Story: 3.5/5Gameplay: 4/5Challenge: 3.5/5Discovery: 3/5Replayability: 3/5Aesthetics: 4/5Visuals: 4.5/5Atmosphere: 3/5Music: 3/5

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												I played this game a lot when I was younger (like, A LOT), so I returned to see if it's still is like the old times, and boy if it isn't. This is one of the few games I have next to no complaints about. - The graphics are beautiful, possibly better than some games that come out today - The combat is exciting with the big arsenal and variety of powers- All characters are interesting, especially your squad members; they are not just hollow shells that follow you around, they are actually people you begin to care about, and your decisions decide whether or not they will remain loyal to your cause- Dialogue is simple, but effective, and actually feels like you're talking to people, not just some NPC- The space travel aspect is awesome- There are so many alien races to interact with- THE ♥♥♥♥ING CODEXI can't say anything about the story, since I haven't really completed it yet, but I am definitely liking it so far.So yeah, buy this game.

The "digital deluxe" version includes next to no DLC despite the misleading title.  Do not expect to be able to play Lair of the Shadow Broker, Arrival, or Overlord.  Kasumi Goto likewise requires a purchase to have as a follower and Zaeed Massani appears to be completely unplayable as a code is not provided with the Digital Deluxe Edition and a download/purchase is not listed on Bioware's website where the rest of the DLC can be purchased.Similar to Xbox Live, purchase of Mass Effect 2 DLC for the PC requires purchase of "Bioware Points".  The total cost of all DLC listed above is 2480 points and once again similar to Xbox Live, these points can only be purchased in predetermined amounts.  This results in being able to purchase 2400 or 2800 points, leaving either a deficit or a surplus,  meaning you are forced toeither not purchase certain DLC or essentially throw away some money due to an inability to use the remaining points effectively.  Overall, purchasing game changing DLC costs $35 and all DLC costs $50.Other DLC such as cosmetic changes and weapon/armor add-ons are also not included in this edition, but are not game changing and add no additional content beyond minor tweaks to the game.  Make no mistake, the full edition of this game costs an additional $35 to the $30 required for the base game, meaning the full Mass Effect 2 costs $65.  Buying the game while 50% off brings it down to $15, making the full game cost $50.Despite everything listed above, I recommend the game as it is my personal favorite sci-fi RPG and the base game while on sale for $15 is definitely worth it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2011
												Let me make this clear from the start... I don't think this is better than ME1. Yes, it has a couple of very well implemented new features, but it also removed some of the best features of the first one. Let me explain why it has some shortcomings. First of all; they removed the elevator loading scenes, which is actually a major plus. They also removed the random loot, and the ability to upgrade these weapons. Now, I'm one that loves loot so why oh why did they remove it ? I really hope they will implement it back into the third one. And why remove the optional buggy ? It was kinda cool (but not always fun). A major plus is that there are different planets, a few of them with their own atmosphere. I really wish there were more of these planets because there weren't enough of them. Maybe something for ME3 as well. Last but not least; it's shorter. Know this, it's a great game and you really should play it, but if you loved the first one like I did you might get disappointed.[Rating: 92/100]

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Would you read or watch a trilogy and then stop right before the end? Do you like cliffhangers that will never be resolved? Do you like to having the feeling you are in control while playing a game, only to be railroaded into doing something stupid later on? No? Then this game is not for you. Mass Effect and Mass Effect 2 are solid, if not excellent games. They have their flaws, but I can live with them. But it is a continuous storyline that runs across three games, not two. Mass Effect 3, the third installment, not available on Steam, but only on Origin, has a very controversial ending that ends the trilogy on a sour note. If you've somehow missed the controversy, just google Mass Effect 3 ending, read some of the many things that have already been said about it, and weep. Weep for the loss of something that could have been epic. Weep for the hurt feelings of countless gamers. Weep for the sorry fate of a couple of epic fictional characters, that felt like friends to so many of us.If you think you will be able to live with the above and also love RPGs, and especially if you liked Mass Effect, then by all means, buy this game now, no hesitation, just make sure to get the Digital Deluxe Edition and the various add ons. Or just keep reading and then make up your mind.Mass Effect 2 continues the story that began in Mass Effect, but with some changes. You need to assemble a new crew and won't be able to play with your friends from Mass Effect, with two exceptions, although there is DLC that will allow you to play, briefly, alongside Liara as well. A very large part of the game is spent assembling a team for a mission that will determine the fate of the Galaxy. Although it is a roundabout way, it does allow you to make new friends and new enemies alike. With a better game engine, the game looks far better than Mass Effect and is much less dated. You can now select additional actions, good or bad, to determine how your character, Shepard, is viewed. The various classes are structured differently from the first game and you no longer get a new weapon every 10 metres, there are far fewer flavours availble. But although it is certainly different from Mass Effect, it is not vastly different. The voice acting is excellent, the music is good, the storyline could be a bit better and straightforward, but is still very good. In and of itself, it is arguably the best game in the series.The only real drawback of this game is the lack of a satisfying ending in Mass Effect 3. So be aware of that before you purchase this game.

												I haven't played much of this game in Steam, but I have put 100 hours of this game on the Playstation.  This game is very entertaining.  Mass Effect 2 continues Commander Shepard's story for keeping the galaxy safe.  Many of the original characters return, but some may or may not be dead depending on what you did in the first game.  Even though I think this version does not include Lair of the Shadow Broker or Kasumi's stolen memory (which if you trust EA I would definetly recommend you buy them they are very very good DLCs), this game is still very worth it.  Gameplay is much better than 1, making it easier to get in and out of cover.  They did take away crouching which was kind of usefull, and the team this time around is much more expansive.  If you are planning on getting Mass Effect 2, you can play it without playing the first one though you kind of are missing a lot of decisions which kind of help with making your Shepard super badass (I didn't play the first one since it had not come out on PS3, but when it did, I bought it in a flash and went through 1,2, and 3 about 4 times)  Buy It, it is worth every penny. 10/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												One of the first things to note about ME2 is that, especially with relation to the PC version, this game was originally intended for controller use.  This is primarily because there is a one-button-do-all feature that, while the mouse may provide more accuracy for hacking and small tasks (aim assist in console versions making up for accuracy loss), shows us that this game is intended for primarily "A" button usage.  The PC versions DO NOT feature any controller support, and the 'mods' that are out there do not let you properly use your weapon/power selection radial, making them completely pointless (in my opinion, maybe if you memorize it it'll work, but the stick is still inverted-upsidedown on the menus).To get deeper into the controls, there are a number of people who like to jump on those who indicate that the controls are clunky, compared to other TPS games.  First and foremost, I would address that Shepard can apparently only sprint for about 4-5 seconds.  Now I get that he is in a space suit, but that armor is pretty thin given his actual size and is likely light-weight so that should not be slowing him down, and if he is a military trained individual we should all hope that sprinting would in actuality be near-infinite since his normal movement is a light jog at best (thinking in comparison to Gears of War or Army of Two).  Now to get to the cover combat; yes it's nice that he sticks his head around the corner like it's realistic, but there are many places where for some reason you cannot aim around corners for no reason, unless you are perfectly locked into the flush-opening position.To wrack on the controls a little bit more (which aren't bad to get used to, but lets face it Resident Evil 4 had better mobility at higher skill training), there is no intentional crouch and zero jumping, and very few places where you can actively leap over cover despite a very slight slide into some cover spots.  The lack of jumping has created a number of instances where, for example, the character gets stuck on top of a medical bed with the only fix being to reload your game (hope you used your quicksave) due to the lack of full world programming.  Not being able to crouch greatly reduces the ability to move throughout the battlefields as well, and makes you feel like a derp sandwich running around with your head up between cover spots.  So for all of you who have said the controls are not clunky or are looking for a smooth combat experience, you now have a nice detailed explaination of what to expect and why, compared to other games, ME2 is still lacking.However, the game is not 100% a combat game, probably not even 50% to be honest, so this really creates less problems for game enjoyment than I make it out to be.  The dialogue is really fantastic, especially in that when you choose a dialogue option it is what your character is thinking, not your exact words.  You can effectively play the game from a Cpt. Picard standpoint, making just about the right decision and resolving issues in an acceptable manner.  However, city affect (yes I mean 'affect', not 'effect') and conversations really do feel like KotOR, almost like it's just a reskinned version of the game with surprisingly more realistic characters.  The paragon/renegade options do work nicely in the dialogue, which is enjoyable to watch in and of itself and good that it is since it makes up a large portion of the game.  Unfortunately, there is no chance to fail in dialogue options, most likely to ensure that all dialogue is spoken and not simply text-based.  A trade-off most gamers can live with for the experience, but limits replay value to an extent.  I mean lets face it, many gamers would be quicksaving before every room and reloading if they didn't get their dialogue to go the way they wanted if there was a chance to fail.Overall the game is very fun, and I do recommend at least experiencing Mass Effect for the visuals and cinematic feel to the game, though the lore seems a little cheesy at times with how it is presented (though that could just be satire).  Also it's very odd to deal with well-known actors voices; I spotted Seth Green's voice immediately but had to look up when I heard Martin Sheen's; I knew I knew that voice!  It's a nice touch in the end however.Final rating; 81% approval; lots of things could have been better, yet it's good for a playthrough or two, but I would not pay top dollar; wait until it's $5-10 to pick it up.

												I rarely write reviews and much less serious reviews, but after everything they've given me, Bioware deserves something back. The Mass Effect series is amazing and Mass Effect 2 is Bioware's masterpiece. I've honestly lost count of how many times I've played through this game, but it's at least 11 (as of June 13, 2016) and I will continue to play it until I physically cannot do it anymore. Mass Effect 2 possesses the best characters, storyline, and gameplay out of any game I've ever played. On top of that, the soundtrack and graphics are no joke either. Mass effect 2 is a masterpiece in every sense so much so that I have a hard time writing a coherent review without leaving to go start the game myself. If you are having doubts about starting or continuing the series, then erase them and buy this (of course buy ME1 if you're starting.)10/10 best game in existence, changed my life

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												One of the first things to note about ME2 is that, especially with relation to the PC version, this game was originally intended for controller use.  This is primarily because there is a one-button-do-all feature that, while the mouse may provide more accuracy for hacking and small tasks (aim assist in console versions making up for accuracy loss), shows us that this game is intended for primarily "A" button usage.  The PC versions DO NOT feature any controller support, and the 'mods' that are out there do not let you properly use your weapon/power selection radial, making them completely pointless (in my opinion, maybe if you memorize it it'll work, but the stick is still inverted-upsidedown on the menus).To get deeper into the controls, there are a number of people who like to jump on those who indicate that the controls are clunky, compared to other TPS games.  First and foremost, I would address that Shepard can apparently only sprint for about 4-5 seconds.  Now I get that he is in a space suit, but that armor is pretty thin given his actual size and is likely light-weight so that should not be slowing him down, and if he is a military trained individual we should all hope that sprinting would in actuality be near-infinite since his normal movement is a light jog at best (thinking in comparison to Gears of War or Army of Two).  Now to get to the cover combat; yes it's nice that he sticks his head around the corner like it's realistic, but there are many places where for some reason you cannot aim around corners for no reason, unless you are perfectly locked into the flush-opening position.To wrack on the controls a little bit more (which aren't bad to get used to, but lets face it Resident Evil 4 had better mobility at higher skill training), there is no intentional crouch and zero jumping, and very few places where you can actively leap over cover despite a very slight slide into some cover spots.  The lack of jumping has created a number of instances where, for example, the character gets stuck on top of a medical bed with the only fix being to reload your game (hope you used your quicksave) due to the lack of full world programming.  Not being able to crouch greatly reduces the ability to move throughout the battlefields as well, and makes you feel like a derp sandwich running around with your head up between cover spots.  So for all of you who have said the controls are not clunky or are looking for a smooth combat experience, you now have a nice detailed explaination of what to expect and why, compared to other games, ME2 is still lacking.However, the game is not 100% a combat game, probably not even 50% to be honest, so this really creates less problems for game enjoyment than I make it out to be.  The dialogue is really fantastic, especially in that when you choose a dialogue option it is what your character is thinking, not your exact words.  You can effectively play the game from a Cpt. Picard standpoint, making just about the right decision and resolving issues in an acceptable manner.  However, city affect (yes I mean 'affect', not 'effect') and conversations really do feel like KotOR, almost like it's just a reskinned version of the game with surprisingly more realistic characters.  The paragon/renegade options do work nicely in the dialogue, which is enjoyable to watch in and of itself and good that it is since it makes up a large portion of the game.  Unfortunately, there is no chance to fail in dialogue options, most likely to ensure that all dialogue is spoken and not simply text-based.  A trade-off most gamers can live with for the experience, but limits replay value to an extent.  I mean lets face it, many gamers would be quicksaving before every room and reloading if they didn't get their dialogue to go the way they wanted if there was a chance to fail.Overall the game is very fun, and I do recommend at least experiencing Mass Effect for the visuals and cinematic feel to the game, though the lore seems a little cheesy at times with how it is presented (though that could just be satire).  Also it's very odd to deal with well-known actors voices; I spotted Seth Green's voice immediately but had to look up when I heard Martin Sheen's; I knew I knew that voice!  It's a nice touch in the end however.Final rating; 81% approval; lots of things could have been better, yet it's good for a playthrough or two, but I would not pay top dollar; wait until it's $5-10 to pick it up.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 is the product of artfully mixing certain genres. On one hand, it's a third-person shooter. On the other hand, it's an RPG with sandbox, open-world sensibilities. BioWare has brilliantly blended together these genres and influences to craft an experience that's not only much better than the admittedly-fantastic original Mass Effect, but also better than virtually all of the like-minded games on the market today. It provides a more streamlined experience than the original, with more focus on character development and action and less on some of the small details that screwed up the first game.It's a must buy,even if it was released a few years ago.My Verdict: 9 out of 10 interracial sex scenes.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Pros:-Characters and their interactions with each other. As you build your team, you stumble upon some very interesting people. The best aspect of the game was getting to know everybody between missions, hearing their stories, and delving deeper into the Mass Effect universe. Especially Garrus with all of his calibrations, which is everything he wants to talk about.  Then there’s the fact that you’re able to romance some of the crew members. I really felt like I was invested in and torn between some of them. Whether it was flirty Kelly, shy Tali, or (insert your description of) Miranda. -Loyalty and crew missions. One of the reasons why you do care about the crew is permadeath. In order to get all of the crew out alive, you have to go on some loyalty missions. As you get to know everybody, crewmembers will tell you that there’s some personal problem they would like solved. Loyalty missions were the best kind of side mission because they weren’t random things to do. There was a sense of purpose—gaining a more meaningful understanding of the crew. All of them played out like a good movie should, with everybody gaining some type of character growth and a solid resolution. -Combat is decent and can be challenging. While it reinvented the wheel, I wasn’t bored senseless. In fact, there were a few parts that I had a difficult challenge. This one part of saving Garrus took me at least ten or so tries. Mostly due to the fact that enemies will use cover effectively, (generally) work as a group, and at times actually attempt to flank you.  Mixed Bag:-Dumbing down of rpg elements. It really seemed like there was much less of a focus on weapon diversity and putting together your gear. While it doesn’t kill the game, it certainly does make it more confusing when you buy upgrades. The upgrades tell you that it will do XYZ% more damage, but there’s no indication of how much that would be. -Interiors seem a lot smaller. The Citadel is pathetically tiny compared to the original. And the same could be said of a lot of the places you visit. They felt small and often very linear. I really wanted to explore some of these places, but to no avail. -No Mako, scanning only. The Mako is totally gone, which also felt like exploration was severely curtailed, and has been replaced with scanning planets. While this may on paper sound like getting resources has been streamlined—it isn’t. I did have this Minecraft mentality of collecting everything everywhere, but It’s downright boring a tedious after the fifth or so planet that you’ve scanned in the same system. By the time that you’re done with scanning every planet you’ll have an astronomically huge collection of resources.Overall:Mass Effect 2 is a masterpiece. There was not a lot of time that I felt like I was disengaged from the story or that I was bored doing ho-hum quests. The mythos of the universe, the strength of the characters, and the story is what elevates this game into what I consider to be near legendary. 9.5/10

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												A well-rounded and very solid sequel to the original. It improves on the first game in almost every aspect. The combat feels more fluid and much more fun, the graphics, story, and sound are better than ever.It plays much like the original - an over the shoulder action/RPG. If you liked the first one, you will love this. There are reoccurring characters from the first game and the ability to import your ME1 character, along with all the decisions (and consequences). A really nice touch.My only (minor) gripes is that the inventory and level-up system seems even further dumbed down compared to the first one. A definate con for those of you that like customisation in their RPGs. The galaxy map is also a little silly (and pointless). These however, are nit-picking an otherwise superb game - a game that it probably on my top 10 games of all time. Everyone should play it. Period.Jimbo Rating: 9/10

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 is the product of artfully mixing certain genres. On one hand, it's a third-person shooter. On the other hand, it's an RPG with sandbox, open-world sensibilities. BioWare has brilliantly blended together these genres and influences to craft an experience that's not only much better than the admittedly-fantastic original Mass Effect, but also better than virtually all of the like-minded games on the market today. It provides a more streamlined experience than the original, with more focus on character development and action and less on some of the small details that screwed up the first game.It's a must buy,even if it was released a few years ago.My Verdict: 9 out of 10 interracial sex scenes.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Apart from all of hype this game generated and the positive feedback from players everywhere, it REALLY made sad. The gameplay is linear and utmost generic, the story doesn't even compare with its predecessor (the real "glory" of this game in my opinion comes from the heritage from the first game), and drives out heavily the initial proposal; for me at least, it's a lot generic too. There's a LOT to complain, but I don't intend to do so.To me, it was a perversion from one of the games that I loved most, ME1; that of course have its flaws, but it INTENDED to be a deep experience, and not only sell.The few people that share my opinion usually bash Bioware, but not me. My grudge is on EA. I can sense the lack of budged on ME1, and the lack of depthness (but not budget) on ME2. It's like the same old story: the tycoon gives someone some money and a shot, the person (in this case, a smaller company) create something beaultiful and unique. Then the tycoon, full of resources and ignorance says: "step aside, kid, now we will do this as I want, and we will make real money".Sometimes this is clearly noted in the general public, like what happened with Perfect Dark and Conker franchise after RareWare was sold to microsoft, like what became of Mafia franchise, etc... Not in the majority od cases, like this one.Of course, this is just my opinion. But for me, this franchise died well and with glory in the final of the first game.

number of helpful: 10 of 21 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2016
												TL;DRMass Effect 1 is better IMHO. Mass Effect 2 isn't ALL bad, but there's alot of stuff that is wrong. Get Mass Effect 1 first, and if you want, force yourself through Mass Effect 2 for the story like I am._______I wish there was a neutral choice for a review, this game is ok. But playing it just makes me want to go back to mass effect 1._______First of all I'll list the things that are in mass effect one that aren't here.Infinite ammo: Mass effect 1 had infinite ammo that made combat more "fun" and less about ammo conservation, I find my self firing really slow while playing mass effect 2 to stop my weapon from overheating, just to realize it has a magazine system where you reload after X shots.Different Armour Types: I miss holding on to the Scorpion IV armor even though it wasn't that great because I thought it looked cool. Mass Effect 2 doesn't really allow you to change armour but it does allow you to change the colour scheme of your default armour.The Old Cast/The Original Normandy: I'm fine with them removing the normandy and the old cast the way they do in the story, but I just wish that the old cast was a little more than a picture on your desk or a "Hi how are you? Wanna come with me for old times sake?" "Nah I can't I have a life now. I know we like saved the galaxy together and all(Or in the case of certain characters, made sweet love on a spaceship), but it's been two whole  years and I have more important things to do than saving the galaxy with you again." I also really liked walking around the old normandy and talking to the crew, but the new normandy has areas that aren't accessible from the start, "I'm the ♥♥♥♥ing captain, let me look around my damn ship!!!"Long Elevator Rides/More "Open World" Feel: I don't know about you, but I liked to walk everywhere I went in Mass Effect 1. The long elevator rides listening to the news or walking around the citadel doing side missions, I completely ignored all the fast travel stations. In mass effect 2, the different levels of the citadel (And even your ship [more later]) are all seperated by loading screens, I spent a good ten minutes walking around my first time on the citadel only to realize I HAD to use the "fast travel" station. The new normandy also has ~4 different levels and a central elevator which you have to use to access the storage bay/crew quarters/main deck/captains quarters. I miss walking down the curved stairs and the short elevator ride to the storage bay on the original normandy.    Each time you complete a "mission" it presents you with an equivilent of a "Mission Complete" screen, which I feel shouldn't be there as it only detracts from the experience by making me feel as if I'm just running around completing arrands as opposed to going on one giant journey to save the galaxy.My Character's Scars From Mass Effect 1: When importing my character from Mass Effect 1, Mass Effect 2 removed my character's eyebrow and lip scars. This wouldn't be a problem if I was allowed to edit my imported character, but I wasn't. It was either "Take what we give you" or "Start from scratch". I spent a good ~20 minutes in the Mass Effect 1 editor making my character PERFECT. I'm not doing it again just to wind up with a character that's slightly different. So I have to live without my cool scars.(Why do I like the scars so much?)I picked the "Sole survivor" psychological profile and felt my character needed scars to show they had actually "Survived" something.Kaiden Alenko(Romance Subplot): If you import a character who completed the romance subplot from Mass Effect 1, you can't continue that "plot" until Mass Effect 3, you also can't do anything with any of the new characters because reason(Ask EA). So all you get is a picture of Kaiden/Ashley/Blue Lady from Mass Effect 1.(You might not even get a picture for the other characters, all I know is I completed the Kaiden one and have a Kaiden picture on Shepards desk.)Paragon/Renagade System: Mass effect 1 allowed you to choose dialogue options that were either "Paragon/Renegade" whereas Mass Effect 2 puts prompts in the bottom corners of your screen to either right click or left click for "Paragon/Renegade" actions. I missed these prompts the first few times because I was too busy paying attention to the characters to notice two tiny blue and red icons in the corners of my screen.Combat: Special abilities (The tech and biotic powers) felt like they had more weight in Mass Effect 1, you opened up the command menu and clicked the icon, then there was a cast time on the attack. In Mass Effect 2, the abilities cast instantly and feel so... Weightless. Having to conserve ammo means that you'll eventually run out and end up using a weapon you don't want to or is wrong for the situation. I went through almost all of Mass Effect 1 using only the pistol. In Mass Effect 2, I find myself constantly being forced to use weapons I don't want to(Looking at you machine pistol).Health: I miss sitting in the corner on low health desperately waiting for my medi-gel to come off of cooldown or even worse trying to beat the boss because I'm out of medigel. Mass Effect 2 offers no such experience, there is no health bar, the shields run out, then the screen grows veins(Which get darker the closer you are to death), then the veins go away over time, then the shields recharge.Controls: Almost everything has changed. Worst of all, spacebar is originally bound to do three things(Run,Take Cover, and Interact). There's no crouch button, I miss running around crouched and slowly peaking over stairs and balconies in Mass Effect 1. Ordering squadmates where to move is no longer in the nice command menu, but is instead bound to seperate keys. The controls are jacked, and going from Mass Effect 1 to Mass Effect 2 is really hard without sitting down and changing all the controls to atleast resemble those of Mass Effect 1.Galaxy Map: The  galaxy map in Mass Effect 1 involved clicking on planets and systems to choose a destination, the new galaxy map featured in Mass Effect 2, involves driving the ship around onscreen to choose a destination. Makes me feel as though the developers thought they might lose my attention if I wasn't playing some "cool" minigame while choosing where to go.I probably missed something but I'll move on to what I like about this compared to Mass Effect 1.__________"I'm Commander Shepard, and this is my favorite store on the Citadel.": Basically you can go around and endorse every single store on the citadel and then Shepard's voice is played over the sound system whenever you enter a door and She/He says that.Buying Stuff for the Captain's Quarters: I think it's neat. I like the hamster, fish, and the little replica of the good Normandy.Being Able to Change Casual Clothes: In Mass Effect 1 whenever you're on your ship you're forced to walk around in a space suit thing. Mass Effect 2 allows you to wear differen't types of clothes when you're on your ship or in other non combat zones. Granted you don't get many choices, but it beats no choice.Joker is Still The Pilot(?) of The New Normandy: I mean, it's no Kaiden Alenko, but atleast I get someone from Mass Effect 1 for a majority of the game.________I can't recommend this game to be the first "Mass Effect" game that someone plays. It just doesn't live up to Mass Effect 1. I'm still going to play it for the "story" and probably get Mass Effect 3. But if I go back to relive the Mass Effect games, I might just play Mass Effect 1 again.

												A better-than-average sequel. Many of the gameplay elements have evolved from the first game--for better and for worse. Many of the RPG elements were stripped out, leaving the overall RPG-ness feel less fulfilling than the original Mass Effect. The gameplay and action sequences, however, were much more enjoyable. Surprisingly, the addition of the thermal clips greatly affected this. The continuity of the storyline and decisions from the last game was quite refreshing, and at the end of the game it really left me craving for the next installment.

												I just finished my first playthrough of ME2. I could immediately see why it's such a classic trilogy in the gaming world. It added a lot of dynamics to the game which were and still are somewhat uncommon in shooters. It's very similar to a Gears of War combat system, except with the ability to pause, review your surroundings, and command your allies to execute attacks or movements. That alone added an element of strategy with an excellent and unique cover system.The character development was also a treat. I was always running to my allies, wanting to talk to them and uncover their individual opinions and pasts. Each character was likeable in their own way, having a bit of complexity that never fit into a stereotypical mold, and a visual appearance that was distinctly original.The dialogue options and the lasting effects of choices, especially if you've played through the first game, made the dialogue more interesting. It's funny because the actual gameplay is seldom affected by your choices, much to the regret of many ME3 players. Without the expectation of some grandiose conclusion based on my actions, I was able to see the game for what it was. It's a present experience, not a build-up, and it does it extremely well. Like a good book when you're done, you wish that you have that anticipation back that you had as you read it. It just proves that the story was very compelling.My only complaint was the research gathering system, which took several hours of my time for a very uninteresting mechanic added ot the game. I'll admit that it adds a reward for exploration in that sense, and it gives a way to interact with things in space, but the very limited scope of it is more of a time sink to justify the upgrades. I'd rather that the more you used certain characters, the more experience it added to the upgrade. It would've given incentive to change up your party members and have them use different weapons.I'd personally give this game a 8.5 / 10. I really enjoyed the story and gameplay, which were captivating enough for me to actually finish a game for once, I felt like the experiences were linear, although very original and interesting, full of background information on each character and always relevant to some immediate concern. I never wanted to get something "over with." Every part of the game was enjoyable (except a certain Hacking mission in a city). I think that if the game incorporated some of the last mission choices into other areas of the game, it would've made things feel a lot more dynamic and weighty. Excellent game, looking forward to ME4!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2012
												Nothing much to say about this game. Except that's in my opinion, its the best out of the Mass Effect Trilogy. That sad, I'll say I prefer Mass Effect 2 to Mass Effect 3. The story, the dialogue, the music and the atmosphere makes as if you were in Shepard's shoes. Combat is great and simple, although the melee system still stinks badly. The most interesting thing about Mass Effect is always the story--it keeps you wanting to play on, wanting to know what happens after your decision. Not many games nowadays have that ability for the player to keep pressing on just for the story. The plus side of the Steam version is that you'll be able to import your ME1 / 2 saves into this. However, you won't be able to get the DLCs for ME2. That seriously sucks big time because in my opinion, the DLCs are worth getting. You're paying for extra content, but you know you're getting a good deal. I own the disk of this game, bought it twice on Origin and Steam is my 3rd copy. Yes, Bioware deserves the money for the amount of awesomeness in this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I'm honestly shocked that so few of my Friends own Mass Effect 2. It's a crime.My first impression of this game came about 10 minutes after I'd completed the original Mass Effect, as a sequel, this does almost everything right. The classes are much more specialised, so you'll get much more enjoyment out of multiple play-throughs, but the real gem is the people. From interesting one-off characters to familiar squad-mates, every one of them is well designed. Each of your squadmates has unique details that the game explores.I really don't want to say any more. If you haven't played this series already, do - if you like video games at all, especially RPGs or shooters - you will love the Mass Effect series. Honestly the best game series I've played, ever. Stop reading this, play Mass Effect.Sure, the game has a few flaws - what games don't? In the long run, you won't really care - you'll be immersed in the game's world, and that's exactly what's so good.P.S. Jennifer Hale's voice acting is miles better than Mark Meer's - if you've only ever played this through once as DudeShep, you owe it to yourself to have a second run as FemShep - there's enough different choices to make it totally worth your while.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												POTENTIAL SPOILER WARNING: 8/10. 8.5/10 if I could have saved Yeoman Chambers :/ Not quite as great as Mass Effect 2 but they tried and it's obvious. The story is good in most of the right places. The way the game handles your squad members is too cookie cutter for my taste, and many of the side missions feel out of place, reptitve, boring, and kind of a waste of time when you're supposed to be saving the universe. The ending started out excellent, particularly the space battle, but the rest of the ending drags on. The human reaper thing was like something out of a classic video gaming that didn't at all fit with the Mass Effect universe and it completely broke immersion for me. I get it, they wanted to give you an even more epic boss battle than in the first game, but this was over the top and almost laughable. Joker is the best part of this story for me. He is the only crew member that I actually liked and didn't feel like a complete let down or a really dark character. Miranda's okay but she's some type of clone/experiment and so I don't really feel any attachment to her. Legion is the best squad member you can have...only for me I didn't get him until the end of the game after I already completed practically all the missions, so I didn't get the time with him/them that he/they deserved. All in all, the story is alright only I didn't like the fact that I was forced to work for Cerberus and support them in all of my dialogue when I didn't intend any of that. The sound in this game is excellent. There is litterally nothing I can criticize about it. I love the attention to detail they give with the noises and ambience. Must be experienced to understand. The graphics are a little better than Mass Effect 1 and overall pretty good. There were some annoying things for me like the walls of light at the entryway to Illium but nothing too serious. The combat is not quite as good as ME1, most of the time the game was easy enough that I didn't time. As a matter of fact, there was only one time that I remember having to rush it in order to acheive something and that it was in the end game.Well, I could go on and on but I'll leave it at that. It's worth playing and I highly recommend play the Mass Effect games in order. Everyone should play these games :D

												The first game was not great.It did not really enjoy it.But know this, playing it was made worth it by this game as your choices carry over.This game is amazing.This game has a great story, gameplay and combat.Each character has their own deep and interesting backstory. Except Jacob.The only problem with this game is the sheer amount of combat. Although fun and epic at times, it gets repetitive as it is used soo much. Eg.Activate this door...You approach doorOh no! A wild mech appears.You kill itOpen the door.Oh no! Another hour of combat to flick a single switch to continue into the next area to repeat this cycle to find somebody something of no value or importance to continue with saving the galaxy.You can get through it. And it's worth it.To summarize:9.5/10Epic and fun. If you have not played you have not lived.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2016
												Pros:+Great combat+Great story+Lovable characters+Decent graphics (at least for the time)+Occasional bursts of humor+Plenty of missions to keep you going (for long enough)+No time pressure (at least until the Collectors kidnap your crew)+Not to be taken seriously (there are plenty of moments without humor that I couldn't help but laugh at. Hell, get some friends, get drunk, have a good time)+Funny glitchesCons:-Feels empty without a ME1 save file-Game presumes you would've made all the bad decisions in ME1-Hubs feel too small for a RPG-Awkward clipping/animations (like I said, not to be taken seriously)-Teammates all have a death wish (no sense of cover)-Miranda's a ♥♥♥♥♥-Planet probing exists for the sake of game length (even if it does grow on you after a while)-DLC   DDDDDDDDD:-Not enough tapping of Garrus' booty-Glitches have a tendency to ♥♥♥♥ immersion. A few rare occasions where a glitch will prevent progression, but nothing a loaded quick save can't fix. -♥♥♥♥ logic8/10, drove me insane.

It's not the best for it's time but far from the worst. Other than that, the mechanics could use a little tinkering. If we use Gears of War as a base 10 for TPS , then this is a 8.3. The only annoying part is that the space button does everything from  sprinting to actions to taking cover. They should have split some of these actions into different keys. Also no jumping. But besides that, Bioware has made their Tour de Force, a masterwork in storytelling only Naughty Dog and Telltale games could trump and maybe Rockstar. This installation will be the reason why Mass Effect Games continue to comeout forever.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2014



YouTube™ Video: What is James Playing - Mass Effect 2 

			Views: 0		

			A review of Mass Effect 2 For more of my reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/		

The first BioWare game I ever played was Knights of the Old Republic. I admittedly picked it up mostly cause, you know, it's Star Wars! But I actually thought it was mostly a pretty good game. Then Mass Effect came out. I freaking LOVED the first Mass Effect game. Even without the Star Wars license, it was an undeniable improvement over KOTOR in every way. It had a much more interesting and engaging combat system, it had more impactful narrative decision making, and it had more interesting characters and better told story. But maybe most important of all is that the in-game world felt so real and immersive. It had massive lore and backstory and I could read as much or as little about all of the locations and technologies as I wanted. The voice acting and writing was excellent and the game pulled off humor and sarcasm better than most other games at the time. Plus the game looked (and still looks) pretty darn impressive.Mass Effect 2 is all of these things and more. I believe it to be the epitome of the Mass Effect franchise. ME3 is a good game too, but it didn't feel as refined or complete of a game as ME2. It seemed like one of the design goals of ME2 was to trim a lot of the excess fat that was present in the first Mass Effect. Gone are the clunky vehicle sections. Gone are the annoying canisters of useless extra weapons and armor that you trip over every 5 steps. But returning is the excellent writing and character design. The crewmates on the ship were so varied and interesting, even more so than ME1. Arguably the least interesting characters were the ones that returned from the first game which isn't so much a slight of the first game as much as it is a compliment to the excellent character design of the second. I loved that you also got to see some of the impact of the decisions you made in the first game. It's also a nice reminder that the impact of a lot of the important decisions you make in ME2 will be felt in the next game. Or at least felt at the end of ME2.Perhaps the most notable improvement in Mass Effect 2 is the combat system. Combat in the first game was somewhat clunky and awkward. It was sometimes hard to tell if you were actually hitting your target and shots tended to clip into invisible barriers or sometimes seem to miss for no reason at all. The combat in ME2 is much more polished and visceral. You KNOW when you get a kill and it feels satisfying. My favorite change in the combat system is with the different weapon types. It's much more rare when you acquire a new weapon, so it feels more exciting. And it's not simply a binary "Is this gun better or worse?" like in ME1. The weapons are all different and have varied strengths and weaknesses. They all play and feel fundamentally differently with different reload speeds, ammo clip sizes, range, and also varied damage and accuracy. You have to play around with the weapons a little to see which one best suits your playstyle. And I love that. Also the excellent level design in ME2 facilitates constant changing of weapons. Some levels are close quarters with lots of short hallways that are perfect for strong shotguns while others can be long, open courtyards perfect for sniper rifles. And the refined abilities and powers are a nice added touch that separates Mass Effect from other action-shooter games. While the refinements to the combat system are nice, the real reason I come to ME2 is to get my story on. I loved the darker or at least somewhat more mysterious themes of ME2. I liked that Commander Shepard was no longer a pawn of the Alliance, but was a renegade in league with Cerberus who were villains in the previous game. Sure, Shepard sort of takes orders from the mysterious "Elusive Man" throughout the game, but you're always free to pick your own destinations on the map and unfold the story at your own pace. It gives the game a more open-ended "explore the galaxy on your own terms" kind of feel. The game seems thematically closer to Star Trek than Star Wars which is ironic considering the development team's pedigree. But I loved exploring and discovering the game world in ME2 and the set pieces are all so well written and memorable. Especially at the end of the game. I won't spoil what happens for those who still haven't played it, but ME2 nicely and meaningfully wraps up all of the choices and decisions you've made in the game up to that point. And it does it in a way that is both exciting and memorable.Mass Effect 2 is a great example of a perfect marriage between excellent gameplay and storytelling. It's an excellent sequel that refines everything that was good about the first game in the series and trims out everything else that was not. It should be a must-play game for fans of shooters and fans of great storytelling alikeFor more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												One of the best games I've played in a long time. The main story (trilogy-wise), the sidestories and the characters are just great and you can't wait to be back on your ship after each mission so you can hear more about the background of your squadmates. The universe is captivating, the atmosphere makes you feel you must visit every location and hear every dialogue between the NPCs. The combat system has been significantly improved since the first game (which was not the most enjoyable from this aspect): it is both dynamic and easy to get used to. I strongly recommend this game to everyone who likes sci-fis and elaborate universes with plenty of opportunities to blow up bad guys.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
												It seems odd to have mixed feelings about a game I have spent so much time on, but the good outweighs the bad.  First, the good.  The world is well-drawn and looks good for the most part.  The combat is much better than ME1, which I found unplayable for the most part.  The choice of male or female, paragon or renegade, and different classes gives the game quite a bit of replayability.  I even played through ME1, which I hated, just to have different choices to carry over into this game.  The look of the armor is fun to customize.  Most of the characters are interesting and I wanted to do their loyalty missions because they are worth caring about.  The best part was the spam emails, odd conversations to overhear, and the overall lore of the ME universe.  I may even check out some SF books based on this playground.  And the game made me laugh out loud many times, which was unexpected and great.  "But all haggis tastes like♥♥♥♥♥anyway."  "True, but in the right hands, it can taste like mighty fine♥♥♥♥♥"  Priceless.   Unfortunately, things that were not so great in the first game were not fixed, they were discarded.  Convoluted and over-complicated inventory, gone.  Mako, gone.  Scanning for resources gets boring, but it was quicker than running around with the Mako, but I wish these things could have been improved instead of lazily scrapping them.  Elevator simulator replaced by load screens.  Fish that are impossible to keep alive.  Most of the extras included in the DD edition I didn't care for.  Zaeed mission was okay, but the character seemed to be a concept piece discarded in the original then just tossed in to grab some case in DLC.  The cerberus and collector armor that is part of the DD edition I didn't like and never used.  The godawful ugly armor from the first game is just gone, leaving your squadmates in the same slick outfits on the ship as in combat.     The biggest problem, however, is the DLC.  Digital Deluxe seems to describe a comprehensive collection, containing all of  the expansions.  Not by a long shot.  Romance Liara in the first game?  Shepard gets a only a kiss, since you have to buy Shadow Broker.   Submachine gun is useless.  Buy Kasumi, etc.  These DLC cost much more than I paid for both complete games I bought on steam, thanks to the unholy trinity of EA, Bioware, and Origin.  Now either get ripped off or find a pirate copy, and still have to deal with Origin for the third game.  Oh, smeg!

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Mass Effect 2 sums up what I like the most about a Roleplaying game -- *Well written and interesting characters that I actually CARE about with their own cool backstory. I actually found some of them to be even more interesting than the main story. And I LOVED the main-story.*Meaningful dialog-choices for YOUR Commander Shepard which creates a unique experience. *A mysterious plot that leaved me guessing until the very end. *... aaand something usally NOT featured in other RPGs; awesome, action-filled COMBAT. That's ME2 in a nutshell. ;)

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												I only originally decided to play this game on the XBox 360 because I watched my wife playing the game and it looked quite fun.After playing the original Mass Effect, I built up my character and made choices during the game that I reckon I would have made in Shepherd's shoes.  It's quite revealing to see a path I thought I was making actually head down a completely different route.I enjoyed the game so much, I purchased it from from Steam.Yes, the ability to use the controller is non-existent but once you get used to the controls on the keyboard, it just seems to move a lot more quickly in battle.The only negative I have on Mass Effect 2 is the scanning of planets for resources; it's ok when you get started but does get a little boring and repetitive after a while.Good, addictive gameplay and I'm looking forward to seeing how my choices in the first two games pan out in the final installment.If you have not played Mass Effect at all, please look out of the deals for the first two games - well worth the investment!I might create another career while I'm at it...

content:
Posted: December 13, 2012
												Stripped of RPG elements, this is a disappointing sequel given the premise that was built in the original. It seems the popular thing to do nowadays is turn every franchise into Gears of War or Call of Duty because that's what Bioware did with this game; Mass Effect 2 is effectively Gears of War with a chat wheel. On it's own it would've been an excellent spin-off but calling this an RPG shows what a sad state of affairs the game industry is in. If you played the first you can import your character and your actions from the previous game do have some weight but this also presents the problem of killing the replay value. This is a good squad-based third person shooter but it's no RPG.

												This game continues the greatest gaming series ever...and I don't bestow such a title lightly...the game basically ties in much of the epic first game, while makes the side missions much more story driven. Despite a somewhat weaker story with respect to the team building as opposed to the first one, still better than any RPG I've played new or old. Its worth whatever they are charging you in your region. BUT PLEASE BUY MASS EFFECT 1 FIRST....playing them in order is too awesome....oh did I mention you get to customize/design your own lead character?

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												If you liked Mass Effect 1, odds are you'll enjoy this one, since it mostly improve on the previous episode. Still, the game remains a rpg/shooter/dating sim hybrid, with all the flaws that implies.+ The firefights are cooler and much more enjoyable than before.+ The individual dialogues make more sense; it is now impossible to romance someone by mistake.+ The secondary characters are more interesting (and fleshed out) than in the first opus.- The rpg part is far from what it could have been. The scenario is pretty bad, and while you can go everywhere on the map, there is no real point to it.- Hunting ressources feels like a chore. It's rare to have such a boring crafting system.- The cover mechanism could have been improved upon. Sometimes your character will just jump over a crate/rock instead of taking cover, resulting in his death.The Mass Effect franchise is great for people looking for their science-fantasy fix, but it suffers from a number of problems.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												I just finished Mass Effect 2 and really enjoyed it.  Even though I prefer more open-ended FPS games, the story line really drew me in.  The final battle was beautifully orchestrated and rendered. As far as game play is concerned, getting used to the total change in the combat system from ME1 was a challenge.  However, I preferred it once I got used to it (though I never got a handle on using multiple player's powers on a single opponent).  I also liked the changes to terminal/safe hacking.  I wasn't willing to spend points on the skill in the first game.  I liked how ME2 just turned it into a puzzle.  The only criticism I have of the game was that the developer's efforts to ease game play seemed to have made the game much easier to play overall.  In Mass Effect 1, I really had to struggle to succeed in some of the missions and the final battle was a real challenge.  I did not find that to be the case in ME2 which reduced some of the sense of satisfaction of successfully finishing the game.
